TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Mabo
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully submit that:
The High Court's Mabo decision has caused division and dissension, uncertainty, resentment and economic damage in Australia.
Mabo will not solve the social, educational, housing and other problems of Aboriginal people.
Mabo is an attack on our Federal system of government, under which the absolute control of Crown lands and management of land titles have always rested with the States.

The only solution to Mabo is a referendum of the Australian people for a law to overrule the High Court and re-establish equal land rights for all Australians, under the normal procedures of State and Territory laws.
And we strongly urge the Senate to reject any other proposed solution.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Campbell (from 169 citizens), Senator Crichton-Browne (from 169 citizens) and Senator Ellison (from 221 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Chemical Registration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to introduce legislation that will require the National Registration Authority to provide all available information on registered chemicals.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
There is general dissatisfaction with the effectiveness of the legislation and industrial award provisions for occupational superannuation, and

We the undersigned therefore respectfully request the Parliament of Australia to amend the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Legislation so as to place the responsibility for providing superannuated retirement benefits onto the person who will eventually receive the retirement benefit.

We call upon the Parliament to convene as a matter of urgency a National Summit involving representatives from Trade Unions, Employer Organisations and State and Federal Parliament to develop a national strategy for an equitable mechanism to provide retirees with an adequate retirement income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the increase in excise of 7 cents per litre on leaded petrol and 5 cents per litre on unleaded petrol resulting from the Budget. This rise in petrol tax:
1.discriminates against low income families and those living in rural areas
2.increases business costs and will cause further unemployment
3.adds further to the price of an already heavily taxed product
4.breaks Mr Keating's election promise not to put up tax.
And your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate oppose these increases in petrol excise.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act: Fathers' Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Parliament will consider the plight of the father in the Family Court of Australia.
Fathers, according to the Laws of Australia, should have equal rights to their children, in both custody and access applications before the Family Court.
Immediate amendments to the Family Law Act should be implemented for inclusion of parental rights as distinct from children's rights.

It should be made possible for fathers to obtain a fair deal in the Family Court and be able to continue involvement in their children's upbringing at all times throughout every stage of their children's development, thus being in the best interest of the children themselves; without incurring exorbitant legal costs and manipulated by many of the legal profession.

Access Orders from the Family Court should be implemented without delay and at no cost to the non-custodial parent, thus eliminating denial of access. We humbly urge Parliament to direct the Family Court by way of immediate legislation to jealously guard visitation rights and become more liberal with them.

We further do humbly seek that a private member's bill be introduced on an urgent basis to consider the plight of John Zabaneh, a fellow citizen and a father of four children whom he had no access to for nearly eight years despite that he had obtained unenforceable Orders from the Courts.
John Zabaneh has been denied any input in his children's development and upbringing and has little or no knowledge of his children's progress and wellbeing.
As this matter is of human-rights nature, of paramount importance, it is specially requested that this petition be read to Parliament assembled in full.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Detention of Asylum Seekers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: that the Australian Government's current practice of detaining asylum seekers is inhumane and has been the cause of profound psychological damage to detainees;
that this practice contravenes the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Convention on the Rights of the Child; and
that detention has in particular cases been found to be illegal.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate assembled should request the Government:
to end immediately the practice of long term detention of asylum seekers, and
to recognise that those who have suffered prolonged detention should be able to claim resident status on humanitarian grounds.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child-care Assistance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned parents and friends of three childcare centres draws to the attention of the Senate that the Federal Government is seeking to link accreditation to eligibility for Childcare Assistance and in the opinion of your petitioners this link will only lead to higher fees for parents and no guarantee for improvement in quality of care for children. We know that quality care cannot be legislated for—it comes from the heart. Please help us help our children.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to reject accreditation being linked to Childcare Assistance.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned residents of the State of Victoria shows:

our deep concern of the Federal Government's proposed legislation concerning the implementation of the National Child Care accreditation guidelines affecting pre-schoolers in Community Childcare Centres.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Senate should:

seriously consider the National Child Care accreditation guidelines which will affect the future generation of citizens, in particular those guidelines that assert compliance on Childcare Centres to accept rules that either prevent or discourage the predominant teaching and learning of mainstream family values based on our Nation's Judeo-Christian ethic, and rules that clearly discriminate against the natural gender bias of children.

Dear Senator

I am writing in reply to your letter dated 21 October 1993 regarding the Migration (1993) Regulations Amendment, Statutory Rules 1993 No 235, which was considered by your Committee on 21 October 1993. Your reference is cttee\511.
You stated that:

"the new Part 774 (designated persons (spouse)(temporary)) entry permit expressly excludes a de facto relationship from the definition of marital relationship for the purposes of that Part. The Committee would appreciate the reasons for this exclusion and for your advice on whether the exclusion could be considered a breach of personal rights.
In this context, the Committee noted that the principal Regulations define marital relationship to include a de facto relationship."

The background to this regulation is that I decided it was necessary to provide a special concession for people in custody pursuant to Division 4B of the Migration Act to be able to apply for an entry permit if they were the de jure spouse of an Australian citizen or permanent resident.

In developing the regulation my Department consulted with the Attorney-General's Department on the question whether Commonwealth law requires the extension of any benefits being given to a de jure spouse to a defacto spouse. The advice of the Attorney-General's Department was that there is no such legal requirement, it is a matter for policy consideration in relation to each relevant provision.

PARA.TAB: "De facto spouse" is defined in regulation 1.3 to have the meaning set out in regulation 1.6. Subregulation 1.6 (1) provides that at the time of the relevant application the persons must be living together as spouses in a genuine domestic relationship that has continued for the period of 6 months or a lesser period specified in subregulation (2). The Committee will note that the provisions of subregulation 1.6(2) require that the Minister is satisfied that there are exceptional circumstances affecting the persons to whom the particular application extends and there are compelling reasons for specifying that lesser period.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly it would be extremely difficult, if not impossible, for an applicant in detention to establish a de facto relationship with a person not in detention. As a result of the foregoing, and to ensure there could be no doubt as to the Government's policy intention, a decision was taken to extend the concession in this class to a de jure marriage and not to a de facto relationship. I do not believe that the exclusion of a de facto relationship could be considered to be a breach of personal rights.
Yours sincerely

Dear Senator

I refer to your letter of 28 October 1993 about the Training Guarantee (Administration) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1993 No. 252, in which you raised concerns about the lack of review of decisions made under new subregulations 2CC (5) and (6). The following explanation is based on advice from the Attorney-General's Department.

The regulations provide for the Minister to recognise a training scheme as a recognised alternative training levy scheme (RATLS). If a scheme is given RATLS status, the employer is not required to pay the training guarantee charge in respect of the employees receiving training under the scheme.

Subregulation 2CC (5) obliges the manager of a scheme to notify the Minister if, as a result of a change in circumstances, the scheme may have ceased to qualify for (RATLS) status or to comply with a condition in relation to the scheme. It is appropriate to require the scheme manager to give notice of any change that might affect the status of the scheme, because the occurrence of a change is something peculiarly within the manager's knowledge.

Subregulation 2CC (6) provides that if the manager of a scheme does not fulfil his or her obligation to notify the Minister of changed circumstances and, as a result of the change, the scheme ceases to qualify for RATLS status, then the scheme is taken to have ceased to be a recognised alternative training levy scheme when the change occurred.
Neither subregulation 2CC (5) nor (6) confers power to make a decision that could be reviewed by the AAT.

Subregulation 2CC (6) is designed to impose a sanction relevant to the scheme if the scheme manager does not comply with his or her obligation under subregulations 2CC (5). In effect, instead of providing a criminal penalty for failure to comply with subregulation (5), the penalty for the failure is a renewed liability to pay the training guarantee charge. The liability to pay the charge as a result of the operation of subregulation (6) can be avoided at any time merely by notifying the Minister that a change in circumstances has occurred. The Minister will consider the nature of the change and will either continue to recognise the scheme or will revoke the decision to recognise the scheme under subregulation (3). The decision to revoke is reviewable under subregulation (7).

If there is a change in circumstances that would disqualify the scheme, but the manager does not notify the Minister of the change, then subregulation 2CC (6) would operate so that the scheme would cease to have RATLS status at the time the change occurred. If, on becoming aware of the change, the Minister took the view that the scheme ceased to qualify for RATLS status, it would be appropriate for the Minister to revoke the relevant scheme decision under subregulation 2CC (3). The decision to revoke the scheme decision would then be reviewable under subregulation 2CC (7).

If, as a result of the manager's failure to notify the Minister of the change in circumstances, the employer was required to pay the training guarantee charge, the employer could object to the assessment under section 53A of the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990, which provides for objections to be made in the manner set out in Part IV of the Taxation Administration Act 1953.

It would in any case remain open to the manager to notify the Minister in accordance with subregulation 2CC (5). As mentioned above, that would require the Minister to consider the matter, and any decision that was adverse to the employer would be reviewable under subregulation (7).

In summary, for the reasons set out above, it is not appropriate to provide for any additional review of the effect of subregulations 2CC (5) and (6). Neither subregulation confers a power to make a reviewable decision. If the occurrence of the change has an adverse effect on the employer, there is adequate recourse under existing provisions of the regulations and Act. If the Minister revokes the scheme, the employer may appeal under subregulation (7) and, if a training guarantee charge becomes payable because the manager failed to give notice of a change, the employer may object under section 53A of the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990.
I trust I have answered your concerns.
Yours sincerely
Ross Free

Dear Senator Colston

Thank you for your letter of 28 October 1993 concerning Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC) Order No. M62/93 made under section 16H of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977 (AMLC Act).

The Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Act 1990 (Quotas Act) empowers the AMLC to establish quota schemes for the export of meat from Australia to particular countries where restrictions on exports of meat are, or in the opinion of the Corporation will be, imposed by the country concerned or by Australia. Under section 5 of the Quotas Act, the AMLC may by notice in writing given to exporters impose a limitation on the total quantity of meat that may be exported to the countries concerned. Allocations of quota to individual exporters are made by the Corporation under section 6 of the Quotas Act. Any variation to quota allocated to individual exporters is made under section 16X of the AMLC Act.

The scheme for the export of meat to the USA, which is the subject of the Order, has been established and administered by the Corporation in accordance with the Quotas Act and the AMLC Act. The Corporation set a limit on the total quantity of meat to be exported to the USA under section 5 of the Quotas Act and allocated quota to individual exporters under section 6 of the Quotas Act. The Order was issued by the Corporation under section 16H of the AMLC to, amongst other things, detail the obligations of exporters under the scheme and explain the mechanism for allocation of quota to individual exporters.

In establishing the quota scheme, the Corporation set aside a quantity of 10,000 tonnes, the "New Exporters' Allocation". This quantity was to be allocated in accordance with the Order and was intended to give the opportunity for new exporters to enter the USA meat export trade. The New Exporters' Allocation formed part of the total limit specified in the notice under section 5 of the Quotas Act. Allocations of quota from the New Exporters' Allocation to individual new exporters were made under section 6 of the Quotas Act. Variations to individual new exporters' quotas were made under section 16X of the AMLC Act. As required by section 16W of the AMLC Act, the granting of quotas to individual new exporters was done in accordance with guidelines set out in the Corporation's corporate plan.

The words "or such other amount as the Corporation may determine from time to time as constituting quota . . . which . . . is to be allocated to New Exporters" in the definition of "New Exporters' Allocation" in the Order were intended to recognise the Corporation's powers under the Quotas Act and the AMLC Act to determine the total quantity of meat that is to be exported to the USA and allocation of quotas to individual exporters.
I can assure you that the issue of quotas and variations to those quotas will at all times continue to be made in accordance with the AMLC Act, the Quotas Act and the guidelines.

In relation to your query on paragraph 3.3 of the order, l can assure you that all decisions made in respect of paragraph 3.3 are subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Applications may also be made for reasons for such decisions under section 28 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 (AAT Act) and section 13 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 (ADJR Act).

The AMLC has assured me that there is no intention to limit or exclude in any way the jurisdiction of the AAT to review decisions made under the AMLC Act or the Quotas Act or to affect the rights of any person to seek reasons for decisions under the AAT Act or the ADJR Act.
Yours sincerely
Simon Crean

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Chamarette) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act relating to Native Title.
Motion (by Senator Chamarette) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

I have introduced the Native Title (Status Quo) Bill 1993 today to provide an opportunity for the parliament to legislate an effective interim means for the Commonwealth to deal with the concept of native title arising from the High Court decision in Mabo and others and Queensland 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: The last month has seen the parliament being faced with the unenviable decision to vote through the Native Title Bill 1993 while doubts remain over its effect and without allowing time for the bill to be given full scrutiny and greater public debate. There have been a number of arguments put for pushing ahead with the Government's answer to the Mabo case. Those advocating the swift passage of the bill say that any delay will see the collapse of the `fragile consensus' which has been built to support the legislation. May I state consensus is never fragile. Deals can be fragile but consensus is strong. They also argue that there is an urgent need to block the gross discriminatory Western Australian legislation that has already been made law. Anyone paying attention to the evidence given to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs would be aware of the enormous feeling of disempowerment and consternation throughout the community, but particularly amongst Aboriginal people throughout Australia. The lack of consultation and understanding at a `grassroots' level has led to the strong feeling of disempowerment. But this is also due to the complex nature and massive impact of the Native Title Bill 1993 on large numbers of Aboriginal and Islander people. The real fear of Western Australia's Lands (Titles and Traditional Usage) Act 1993 has caused many people to turn to the federal bill as a way of stopping Richard Court. The Keating Government has used this fear to its advantage and caused many people to be distracted from the detail of the federal bill and to rely on the Prime Minister, fine words in assessing the desirability of his legislation. Both Richard Court and the Prime Minister have used one another's legislation as a means of forcing through their respective Mabo responses. The government has already said that they will not support this piece of legislation. They may argue that it is unconstitutional and I shall come to that issue later. However, I believe that their motives are far less pure. They simply wish to rush through the legislation so that any time for real scrutiny and reflection is gone. So that they can get away with passing a piece of legislation which is discriminatory against Aboriginal people while the facade of justice remains.

The Government is more than happy to allow the fear generated over this issue to work in their favour. They simply want to use the quickest, simplest and least inconvenient way of acquitting themselves of finding justice for Aboriginal people. Meanwhile the Opposition is also unwilling to support the opportunity that this bill presents to properly assess the Native Title Bill 1993.

They are urging us to support a select committee to enquire into and allow greater consultation on the federal bill, because they hope that any delay will see the government lose its bottle in the face of rising public opposition. For them it is a win—win situation. They win public support for opposing the legislation anyway and they win if a delay causes the bill to fail. In truth there is little in the Government's bill which they, in principle, would oppose. It is the political advantage which draws them to their position. This bill provides a real and valuable opportunity to take a deep breath and fully review the more comprehensive legislation which is before the Senate. It is the traditional role of this chamber to do that, yet neither the Government nor the Opposition is willing to abide by democratic principles and open the way for that to happen. It is being presented as a model of what the Federal Government could and should have done. It would have served to protect Aboriginal people from extinguishment of their barely recognised rights before they could enjoy access to any of them. It would have allowed time for a solid consensus to develop.

The Northern Territory Land Rights legislation lay on the table in the House of Representatives for three months before receiving bi-partisan support. It is an indictment of the current political climate that the legislation being proposed by the Government doesn't even come close to reaching the mark of that land rights legislation or gaining cross party support.

This bill opens the way by converting the native title as recognised by the High Court in Mabo and Others and Queensland (1992) into the Statutory law of the Commonwealth and not allowing any law of the Commonwealth, State or Territory to extinguish or modify native title until this parliament provides otherwise. This is necessary because any State or Territory legislation passed after the 30th June 1993 can affect native title. This provides an effective means of protecting that native title until a comprehensive piece of legislation can be agreed on by this parliament. Any question of the constitutionality of this legislation will throw into doubt the constitutionality of the Government's bill as the primary clause (clause 4) in my legislation is based on clause 11 of the Native Title Bill 1993. Clause 5 of my bill is merely an extension of the legal protection provided by the previous clause.

Senator Margetts and myself make up only 2 votes out of the 76 Senators in this place, we can do nothing by ourselves to put in place the legislative mechanism to allow for that scrutiny and consultation to take place. The responsibility of any failure to fulfil our democratic obligations will firmly rest with all of us. I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on its inquiry into the provisions of the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Amendment Bill 1993 and the Overseas Students Tuition Assurance Levy Bill 1993 together with the transcript of evidence and submissions received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: ESOS Amendment Bill 1993
Overseas Students Tuition Assurance Levy Bill 1993
This report is the latest in a series of reports presented by the Committee over the past two years dealing with international students attending private educational institutions in Australia.

It is the unanimous view of the Committee that the ESOS Amendment Bill 1993 will achieve the necessary level of protection for the interests of international students, and prevent any further drain on those students and on the public purse in the event of failure of a private education provider. The Committee reiterates its support for an industry-based tuition assurance scheme by which displaced students of a failed college would be able to complete their course of studies in another institution. However, such a scheme must accommodate the wide range of education providers operating in the industry, and must provide for exemptions where appropriate. Details of a suitable scheme or schemes are still in the process of being developed by a joint Working Group of departmental officials and industry representatives. The Committee is therefore reserving its judgment on the structure and details of a tuition assurance scheme until that consultative, developmental process has been completed.
A.Olive Zakharov
Chair

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS REFORM BILL 1993INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS COURT (JUDGES' REMUNERATION) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 8 December.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee is considering clause 4 of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 and the Australian Democrats' amendment No. 1 moved by Senator Spindler. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

—Last night I asked Senator Spindler a question in relation to the effect of this amendment because there had been media comment about what the Democrats were proposing to do. I seek again to have Senator Spindler explain the exact effect that his amendment will have on the operation of the bill and, in fact, on the act.

—I answered Senator O'Chee's question last night by saying that my amendment to this particular clause has nothing whatever to do with leave for same sex couples. That is in an entirely different clause of the bill. This clause amends the objects of the act to further the prevention of discrimination on the grounds of sexual preference, age, physical or mental disability in situations of employment.

—So that means, I assume, that sexual preference of any kind cannot be used as a basis for refusing to employ a person in a particular job. If that is what Senator Spindler is saying, I must object very strenuously to what Senator Spindler advocates.

—The prohibition is, of course, related to the provisions of this bill. The import of the amendment is that discrimination must not occur on that ground. It does not mean that there will be no circumstance where this cannot be taken into account. It depends on whether the performance of a particular job relates to that particular sexual preference. There may well be cases where that can be justified under the provisions of the Industrial Relations Act.

—I thank Senator Spindler. Let me outline my concern. I understand that Senator Spindler is trying to do his best to outline the effect as he sees it, but I think there is an unexpected consequence of this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Let me give a perfect example of where discrimination on the basis of sexual preference is perfectly justified. The amendment that Senator Spindler makes would prohibit discrimination in employment solely on the basis of a person's sexual preference. Now that sexual preference need not be men for men or women for women; it could well be adults for young children. That is one of the consequences of an amendment that precludes discrimination against a person's employment upon the basis of sexual preference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Paedophiles.

—Exactly. As Senator Parer says, it includes a paedophile. This amendment says that we cannot refuse to employ a paedophile in a kindergarten. That is the consequence when one uses the words `sexual preference'. It means that we cannot refuse to employ a paedophile in a kindergarten. Frankly, I believe that we have certain responsibilities.
—Paedophilia is an illegal act. That is nonsense.
—But it is sexual preference. That is the problem. If one wishes to move an amendment to a bill, the amendment has to be appropriately worded.
—And it is.
—I think we have a problem—
—You think but you don't know.
—The number of things that Senator Bell has said he has thought about but has not thought about is quite miraculous. I think perhaps his interjection would be better withheld.
—You do not have that capacity.

—If Senator Bell keeps quiet, we might get on with this debate in a more intelligent fashion. The problem with this amendment is that it says `sexual preference'. Sexual preference can clearly be construed to include the preference of an adult for young children. That is why I believe this amendment should not be supported.
—I am advised that Senator O'Chee is wrong. The wording—
—Advised by whom—Senator Bell?

—Could I please continue with my explanation? Under the terms of the act, `sexual preference' does not include paedophiles. I believe that this is correct and that Senator O'Chee is wrong. Perhaps the government with its advisers can clarify the position.

—I wonder whether Senator Spindler could explain to the Senate why. He has just stated the fact that he does not believe that is the case, but could he tell us why he does not believe that is the case?
—Because I have been advised that, under the terms of the act, this is not included, and I have suggested that we give the minister time to confirm that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a more fundamental point that goes to dispel the very dangerous attempt that Senator O'Chee has made to create a scare campaign when the basis for none exists; there is a much more fundamental basis. The act makes it absolutely clear that the non-discriminatory section, with regard to termination of employment, does not prevent such a matter being a reason for terminating employment if the reason is based on the inherent requirements of the particular position.
—What section is that?

—It is on page 80, 170DF(2). It is absolutely crystal clear that Senator O'Chee's deliberately provocative choice of example falls at that hurdle and must not be allowed to lie on the table any longer. I support Senator Spindler's amendment, although I can understand some of the arguments that people raise against it; that is part of people's philosophical framework about life which I do not share but which they are entitled to have. But even if we disagree with the amendment, we cannot have the situation where a legitimate debate about the rights of individuals in employment generates a scare—and I will not call it a `scare campaign' because that attributes motives to the person who raised it which I am not trying to do—amongst people that in some way their children might be in danger, and that is without any foundation.

PARA.TAB: The act makes it absolutely clear that, if there is such a fundamental conflict between the inherent requirements of a particular position and any of these grounds of discrimination, not only this one, it is a legitimate ground for termination of employment. That is quite clear, so that problem does not arise. I think we have to remember also that the amendment we are dealing with goes to the objects of the act and states that they are to help to prevent and eliminate discrimination on these grounds as articulated. So let us get this back into some proportion.

TALK.START.PARA: —What clause are you referring to?

—Page 18, clause 170DF(2). I think that deals with the issue in question, but I am trying to make a broader point that we are currently looking at the objects of the act. It is hard for me in this debate to understand that someone would be saying it is not desirable for us to seek to eliminate discrimination on the grounds of sexual preference. That is a legitimate debate, but let us not get up and running this argument of paedophiles in the kindergarten; it is explicitly dealt with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has identified clause 170DF(2), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Subsection (1) does not prevent a matter referred to in paragraph (1)(e) from being a reason for terminating employment if the reason is based on the inherent requirements of the particular position.
Subsection (e) states:
race, colour, sex, marital status, family responsibilities, pregnancy, religion, political opinion, national extraction or social origin—
and I presume this will be amended in due course if we continue to include sexual preference.

PARA.TAB: Could the minister give us a precise definition of what `the inherent requirements of the particular position' means. He is basing his argument on those words and I believe that from what he has said so far, that argument is flawed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously nobody can give a comprehensive definition of everything that is ever going to be deemed to be an inherent requirement of every employment position in the country. That is much too comprehensive a brief. I was trying to say that, quite clearly, Senator O'Chee's example falls outside any such definition. It would be a matter for employees who were seeking to exercise their rights under this clause. If they claimed they had been dismissed contrary to this, in the normal course of events I assume they would need to indicate that it was not reasonable, and challenge. Depending on the circumstances of the case, an individual might need to establish that it was reasonable. I do not want to get into the argument about where the onus lies; that may well be determined by the nature of the case in question. I do not think that it was the point of Senator Crane's question either.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane's point was: what are the inherent requirements? Inherent requirements change. There are nine million people in employment and there are hundreds of thousands of different jobs. The inherent requirements of those vary immeasurably. There is no narrow definition that will describe the inherent requirements of all positions. What I would have thought was sufficiently clear to satisfy any reasonable person is that criminal acts against children conflict with the inherent requirements of a position of taking care of children. I would have thought that was not an unreasonable proposition. If anyone wants to suggest that in some way performing criminal acts against children does not breach the inherent requirements of being in charge of children, go right ahead; I will be fascinated to hear the argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to deal with what Senator McMullan has said. As my colleague Senator Crane has pointed out, there is no clear definition, and I do not think Senator McMullan's arguments are well-founded in law. I wish to deal with the burden of proof, which Senator McMullan said might be a changeable thing depending upon the circumstances. That may well be the case but when one looks at the structure of clause 170DF, the first subclause says:

SPEECH.PARA: An employer must not terminate an employee's employment for any one or more of the following reasons . . .
Subclause (2) says:
Subsection (1) does not prevent a matter referred to in paragraph (1)(e) from being a reason for terminating employment if the reason is based on the inherent requirements of the particular position.

That is a defence. Subclause (2) sets up a defence to an action by an employee who claims wrongful dismissal. To the extent that it sets up a defence, the burden of proof is on the employer, not on the employee. I can imagine one or two situations arising where the employee might have to discharge a burden of proof but, on the whole, the burden of proof rests with the employer. That is the first qualification of what the minister has said.

PARA.TAB: Let me go to the substance of what the minister has said. Subclause (2) applies only to subclause (1)(e). That refers to race, colour, sex, marital status, family responsibilities, pregnancy, religion, political opinion, national extraction or social origin. There are clearly cases where those things are an inherent bar to the requirements of a particular position. For example, in Western Australia there is a busy trade in selling sheep that are slaughtered according to Islamic tradition. One obviously cannot be Jewish and work in one of those slaughterhouses. In fact, one cannot be Christian and work in one of those slaughterhouses; one must be Muslim, and even then there are particular requirements—I understand they have to have a mullah and so on.

Such situations are a clear case of where being of a different religion bars one inherently from meeting the requirements of a particular position. Another example would be people who are not Jewish working in a Jewish butchery, where there are similar religious requirements. What we have to deal with here is the word `inherent'. That is the important word, because sexual preference may well be different from sexual practice.

I can imagine the situation of a person who has previously been convicted of an offence of paedophilia not disclosing that conviction when applying for and gaining employment in, for example, a kindergarten. When it is subsequently revealed that this person has a conviction for paedophilia, that person could say, `No, my sexual preference is not an inherent bar to my meeting the requirements of this particular position on the basis that I no longer practice paedophilia. I was previously a paedophile and I am undergoing counselling and I am not doing it now', or whatever. Such a person would say that the important thing is not the preference but the practice. I can very clearly see a case like that coming up and maybe that person even winning under the wording that is here. That is why I do not think the clause the minister has referred to does, in fact, answer the question. We have to have the peace of mind of the families at heart, and that is why I believe this amendment should not be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to question the minister further with regard to this particular clause. One cannot look at a clause in isolation when there is a series of them—although I know that we are dealing with some. We cannot look at them without also looking at the exemption relating to institutions, because they all relate to one another.

PARA.TAB: The minister noted `the inherent requirements of the particular position' relating to this clause. There is an exemption with regard to a person's employment as a member of the staff of an institution that is conducted in accordance with doctrines, tenets, beliefs or teachings of a particular religion or creed. My interpretation is that that relates to private schools which are run from a religious base, whether they be a convent, a grammar school or a school of that nature.

Going back to those words, `the inherent requirements of the particular position', and noting that exemption, I ask the minister: what is the position if an employer has particularly strong Christian or Muslim beliefs? What rights do people have in, for example, the situation that was highlighted by Senator O'Chee a moment ago, which related to the slaughter of stock in this country for export overseas? What is the position of individuals who have particularly strong beliefs—which some people in this country quite legitimately have—under that wording?

I would suggest to the minister that, in fact, their position and their right to that belief are not covered. I would also suggest that consideration has not been given to that in subclause (1)(e) and the additional words which will come into play. One might well ask Senator Spindler why that particular aspect has not been covered. It is all very well to amend one part of an act but one should look at the consequences which flow into another part of the act.

I know myself—and I am sure that Senator Spindler knows—that there are some people who hold particularly strong beliefs about certain things. In fact, some people take a stance according to their religious creed with regard to the impact of this clause. So why is it necessary to go beyond what is already included in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act? These matters are covered in that particular act. This is cluttering up an industrial relations act and causing a lot of confusion. It will cause a lot of heartburn for a lot of people—and quite legitimate heartburn. Why cannot this matter be left where it properly belongs in our view—in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Crane for raising that because it does go to the broader questions of principle that were being discussed last night and to which I was looking for an opportunity to respond. But I want to reiterate very clearly that it is inconceivable, even with Senator O'Chee's very fertile imagination, for which he is to be congratulated—
—That is not necessary.

—I am not trying to put him down. I thought he put his argument as well as it could have been put, but it is not conceivable to put together a case in which any judicial authority in Australia would find that it is a reasonable requirement that anybody could be required to employ a paedophile to take care of children. I have to say that is stretching the bounds of credibility. When the issue was first raised without subsection 170DF(2) having been pointed out, I could see how people could think that this was a problem. That is why I quickly sought to point out to them that it was not possible because of that subsection being there to protect against those sorts of concerns.

PARA.TAB: The broader question that Senator Crane now raises, which is similar to that which Senator Harradine raised last night, is important. This is the so-called cluttering up issue. On the face of it, we can see why people raise it because, for example, the amendment Senator Crane is now talking about, which modifies the anti-discrimination provisions of the bill in the ways to which he has referred, duplicates the exceptions that are already set out in the definition of `discrimination' in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act of 1986.

So on the face of it we can say the same anti-discrimination provisions are there, the same exceptions are there; why do we need it? There are two closely related issues that I want to address. One is that we need to recognise that the way in which, the conditions under which, the reasons for which, people are dismissed are not infrequently the basis of industrial disputes. Anybody—and that includes several people, as I look around this chamber—who has been involved in one way or another in industrial relations would know that disputes often arise, and some of the most difficult disputes often arise as a result of the dismissal of employees and the grounds on which they are dismissed.

Quite clearly, there is a fundamental industrial relations issue involved here. We are not introducing some new and alien concept that there is an industrial relations issue around the termination of employment, the rights of people to go to the Industrial Relations Commission to deal with issues to do with termination. There has been debate around what should be the powers of industrial relations bodies to deal with this. For more than 20 years—because I was involved in it in the early 1970s; so it is not a new issue—industrial relations authorities have had power in this area on and off in various states. So it is not as if this is some bolt from the blue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Being in the IR act is a bolt from the blue.

—It has been in industrial relations legislation in at least one state in the past. I know because I appeared before it. It is a pretty hazy recollection—it was more that 20 years ago—but I know we certainly debated these issues in Western Australia in the early 1970s.

PARA.TAB: There is a significant extra element. The first is that, as I say, there is a profound industrial relations issue involved. It goes fundamentally to the relationship of an employee to his or her employer. Therefore, it is a question fundamentally in relation to the contract of employment.

More than that, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act does not give any enforceable remedy to the individual who is discriminated against on the grounds of sexual preference. So it is fundamentally different. That is not to denigrate the very useful assistance that can be provided to people who have been discriminated against in other areas. Such assistance has been provided by the human rights commission and its various agencies over the period of its existence. It has been very worthwhile, but it does not lead to a situation of any enforceable remedy for the dismissed employee.

Firstly, there is a fundamental industrial relations issue involved, so there is nothing inappropriate about its being in the industrial relations legislation. Secondly, it is not a mere duplication of the human rights act provisions because it provides for the employee that which they would not otherwise have—an enforceable remedy. It is a question of being able, through the Industrial Relations Commission, to find a resolution that is both fundamental to the rights of the individual worker and central to the resolution of the industrial relations dispute that might ensue as a result of the termination of employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address one particular point made by Senator Crane. He referred to the position of an employer who holds a very strong philosophical view which may be contrary to the disability, age or sexual preference of the person who is an employee. I think that, as a matter of very strong principle, we should distinguish between a disagreement on philosophy, on values, on opinions or on preferences, and the right to disadvantage a person on the basis of that disagreement in an employment situation. I think that is precisely what anti-discrimination legislation is about. I think that is precisely what the principle of equal rights in a democratic society is: that people may hold particular preferences, that they may be part of a group in society that holds that preference.

PARA.TAB: In very many cases I think it is generally agreed that it is not their choice. I think it would have been better, instead of terming it sexual preference, to home in on that example, to call it sexuality. Very clearly, people cannot make any decision on what age they are at any particular moment or what disability they have. The argument here is that, because we disagree with what they are, what they think, what they say or what their preference is, the employer should have the right to disadvantage them. I think that is contrary to every principle of equal rights that a civilised society should subscribe to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put this problem to Senator Spindler because I think it effectively illustrates the problems one gets into when one becomes very prescriptive. I would have thought that if the Australian Democrats discovered they had on their staff an activist from another political party, say the ALP, with access to Democrat records, that would be an absurd state of affairs. I think if that person did not propose to resign, it would be perfectly in order to sack that person. I ask Senator Spindler to address that example and see how the philosophy he has just described to the Senate ties in with it.

—I am very happy to address that matter. As it happens, there has been at least one member on our staff belonging to another political party. There is also a member on my staff who, while maybe not having membership of the Liberal Party, certainly has in the past been a staffer for a Liberal Party parliamentarian. In both cases I have looked—and other Democrat senators have looked—at their employment performance.

PARA.TAB: I refer Senator Kemp to proposed new section 170DF(2)—the minister drew attention to this—which relates to exclusion where the inherent requirements of the job may require it. If I thought that the political activity of those people was in conflict to such a degree that they could not perform the inherent tasks of their jobs, obviously under that exclusion I would have to look at that situation. But this has not been, is not, and should not be, an automatic exclusion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to pursue that particular tangent. I have been waiting for confirmation of something which I assumed to be the case but which I wanted to get from the Attorney-General's Department before I went any further. I want to make it absolutely clear that the Attorney-General's Department's advice is that sexual preference in these amendments means heterosexuality, homosexuality and bisexuality—nothing more. The Attorney-General's Department has confirmed—
—What other options are there?

—There is an option, and that is the one that Senator O'Chee has raised, to which I wish to directly refer. I am trying to respond directly to a point which he raised seriously and to which he is entitled to a response.
—It is just a variation.
—One must fit into one of the three.
—The capacity of adults to talk about sex without laughing is a judgment of their maturity.
—Cut it out. That is not necessary.

—I find it hard to cope with people who break into a fit of the giggles every time the word `sex' is mentioned. Attorney-General's has confirmed that discrimination because of paedophilia is not because of sexual preference. I want to make that clear, in terms of any subsequent interpretation of the government's intention with regard to this legislation. I understand that the explanatory memorandum or similar supporting documentation—I am speaking from memory and limited advice—to the human rights legislation makes that distinction clear.

PARA.TAB: In case anybody subsequently seeks to interpret this legislation other than in the way that it is intended and other than in the way that the human rights legislation has been interpreted and implemented, I will reiterate absolutely that there is nothing in the intention of the words, or in the government's intention to accept this amendment, that in any way implies that discrimination against someone because of paedophilia or any actions taken in that regard against children is not intended to be protected by this amendment. It is up to Senator Spindler to say whether he meant it—I am sure he did not, but I cannot officially say that; I am not inside his mind.

There is absolutely no question but that this amendment would never have been accepted if the government had felt that it had that possible interpretation. It is not supported on the basis of any question that it might so be interpreted. Our legal advice is that it should not be so interpreted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I come back to the question that I asked before, which neither the minister nor Senator Spindler answered, with regard to people who hold a particularly strong religious view. I will not go into the detail that I went into before.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler tried to hide the issue by using a philosophical view. I think one can say that there is a certain philosophical view on the opposite side of the chamber and a particular philosophical view on most things on this side of the chamber. But the Democrats are not sure where they fit in. They are a bit all over the place.

When it comes to a strong religious view, one would find that a lot of people on the opposite side of the chamber, or on this side of the chamber, or down the other end of the chamber, will hold a very strong position which is very similar. They will take their position under the same religious creed. It is very different from relating it to a philosophical view. It is just the same as if one happens to belong to a particular religion, whether it be Muslim or Buddhism, or whatever it might be. I do not hold any personal or particular brief for any of those. But certain people have a strong, legitimate, legal position which they adopt in their lives.

The amendment which has been put forward will force those people to accept a particular thing which is very strongly against their own personal beliefs and the creed under which they operate. That is what the minister cited in this act as being what gave those people their protection. I say that it does not give them their legitimate rights of protection because it is the inherent requirement of the position. Will the minister answer that question or tell us how the government intends to deal with it? It is a very legitimate, valid question. It is one which could be of concern to a lot of employees in the workplace.

The minister also made reference to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act. The amendment that is being proposed for the exemption is word for word, as I understand it, a lift-out from that act. Once again, that goes back to the basic question, which I am not going to ask the minister to answer again. It is an absolute nonsense to duplicate part of another act which already deals with the matters in a much broader perspective. It would clutter up the industrial relations situation.

Finally, I return to those individuals who have quite legitimate beliefs in terms of their position in society—those beliefs have nothing whatsoever to do with philosophy—and how their rights will be protected under this legislation and the amendments which have been proposed by the Democrats. It goes far beyond the staff at an institution or a particular religious school.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The thing to remember is that this legislation—particularly this part of it—goes to the behaviour of the parties to the industrial contract. This legislation does not constrain the rights of individuals or employers as to whom they employ. What it says is that after an employer employs someone—that is, after the contract is entered into—then the employer has to recognise the rights of the other party to the contract—that is, the employee—as well as the employer's rights. Once the person is employed, that person has rights also, and is entitled to have them respected.

PARA.TAB: None of the clauses in this legislation constrains the right of employers to choose whom they employ. But after they employ them, it constrains their capacity unilaterally to sack them, because there are conflicting rights and it recognises that workers have rights as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I return to a point that was made before. I want to make my point before the debate goes too much further. I confirm in particular that we have taken advice from the Attorney-General's Department, just as the minister has, that the definition of `sexual preference' in this legislation is confined to heterosexuality, homosexuality and bisexuality. It definitely does not include—we rely on this advice—paedophilia or any other criminal behaviour.

—I follow on from where Senator McMullan finished. Unfortunately, I found his answer a little offensive. He was saying that before employers hire people they have to find out from them their sexual preference. He was saying exactly that, and I find it offensive. What consenting adults do in their private lives is their own business.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan said that the only option of employers is to find out beforehand about the private lives of prospective employees because otherwise the employers would be caught in this act.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your point?
—That is my point, because that is what he said.
—I do not want anyone to do that, so explain to me the point you're making. I have missed it somehow.

—The point I am making is that Senator McMullan said in his answer, and these are not the exact words, that if employers found out after hiring their employees that their employment particularly contravened—this was his answer to my previous question—the employer's particular religious beliefs, the employers were caught up in this legislation. So the only protection they have from getting caught up in this is to ask individuals before they are employed what, in my view, is a very private and personal question. I find that unacceptable. There has to be a better way of dealing with this concern which many people have.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps I have it wrong. I do not think I have, but I will read the Hansard very carefully. Senator McMullan said that once people are hired, the employers are caught with them under this legislation. I presume that Senator McMullan was answering my particular question. That is my concern.

There are rights on two sides of the ledger. Many things are legal in terms of individual preferences in personal situations. We are dealing with a very difficult situation, and I make no bones about that or any apology for it. There has to be a way through it. People who have a particular belief or position should not be put in a position down the track where, in effect, they are discriminated against because they happen to hold that belief.

The government is able to make an exemption by taking clauses out of another act and putting them in this bill. The government has to go a lot further to satisfy decent ordinary Australians before it proceeds any further down this path.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will extend Senator Crane's question and query what the minister has just said. Is the minister indicating that if a potential employer who has a particular moral conviction, whether it arises from a religious position or a moral view, is aware of a particular characteristic held by a potential employee, whether it is a characteristic relating to sexual preference or some other characteristic which does not accord with the potential employer's moral position, before he employs the person, is he still required to employ that person? Is the minister also saying that if he employs that person while not being aware of that particular characteristic, under this provision he could not then dispense with that employee's services once having found out that the person has that particular characteristic to which he has a moral objection?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a convoluted way of saying the same thing. I will reply to Senator Crane and if for some reason what I say does not cover Senator Chapman's point, he can pursue it. But I do not think his point added anything. There are other laws which regulate how and when one can discriminate against individuals outside an employment contract. People have to obey those laws; but I am talking about this legislation.

PARA.TAB: I understand how Senator Crane could have interpreted what I said in that way. But I make it absolutely clear that I am not advocating that anybody should discriminate against anyone at any stage in the process. I am totally opposed to the sort of discrimination that would be inherent in the actions that Senator Crane was expressing objection to and with which I would also strongly disagree.

I think Senator Crane is right when he says that people should not discriminate in that manner at the time of employment. I also think that they should not discriminate in that manner after the time of employment. I share Senator Crane's view, but I take it a bit further.

Such matters are the private business of an individual and they ought not be a basis upon which a person is dismissed from employment. This is not just some contract to supply a piece of wood to a builder; this is a contract about an individual's capacity to earn a living in our society and to have the capacity to earn an income and support those dependent upon it. We cannot say, `I am sorry someone does not like what you did at home last night. I do not like the house you did it in. So you no longer have an income.'

That really has nothing to do with a person's employer, provided it does not interfere with the satisfactory discharge of that person's duties. If it does, it is legitimate for the employer to say, `You are not satisfactorily discharging the duties for which you were employed so I do not want to continue to employ you.' That is part of industrial contracts and no-one can quibble about that.

I make it very clear that in no way am I advocating that employers should discriminate against individuals at the time of employment. This legislation does not interfere with that principle; it goes beyond it. The government says there are rights in this regard. I do not regard it as discrimination against individuals when we take action to prevent them discriminating against others. By any proper definition it is not discrimination. Frankly, I do not think we will advance this debate much further because all the issues have been traversed. It must be getting close to the time when we should find out what the majority view of the chamber is.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the minister back to what he said about hiring homosexuals. He was saying that an employer may have a legitimate reason for refusing to hire homosexuals if that employer is morally against them.
—The minister was saying that you haven't got that right.

—I thought I heard the minister say that if an employer has strong moral objections to having a homosexual in the workplace, the employer may have a reason for refusing to hire. I thought that is what the minister said. But if the employer finds out that the person is a homosexual after he has been employed, the employer cannot unload him. I do not believe that having a homosexual in the work force is the end of the world. It depends upon the situation.

PARA.TAB: In a mixed work force, where the staff report for work at 9 o'clock and leave at 5 o'clock, I believe it would work very well. But there are situations where it would not work and where conflict could arise. An example of this, just off the top of my head, is a shearing team that is made up of all males, although that is changing rapidly now; a lot of females are working in shearing teams. Senator Murphy was a shearer and he knows that they work in a closed camp situation. I believe that conflict could be started, not necessarily by the homosexual, but by the rest of the crew. That being the case, I think the employer could have a good reason to remove the homosexual from the work force.

The situation is different again in a big work force. The employer may find the homosexual something else to do. But in situations where there is only one job for the homosexual, I think the employer has a legitimate reason to move him sideways or to put him off. Of course, I believe that should also apply to lesbians.

While I am on my feet—and I do not want to be on my feet for too long in this debate—I refer to the reference in Senator Spindler's amendment to `sexual preference, age, physical or mental disability'. I would also like to address that. What we are doing at home now is taking the crop. We employ header drivers or combine harvester drivers. The driver has to climb up a couple of metres to get into his position on the vehicle, so we have to employ someone who is physically fit. If the driver has an accident, he is covered by employer's liability. If he needs time off after that, he is covered right down the track. But if that poor, unfortunate driver has to use a walking stick or is in a wheelchair for the rest of his life, can he be removed from the work force? He may receive a pension for the rest of his days or he may not.

The point is that in that sort of employment of driving and operating machines—whether it be headers, loaders, tractors or trucks—the employee needs all of his faculties about him, both physical and mental. When I say `mental' I am talking about whether or not the employee is mentally unstable. Even age is relevant. I know that I could not drive a truck now for as long as I could when I was 21. I ask Senator Spindler: what happens in situations where there is only one job and there are no other jobs that the employer can pass down the line?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The first question asked by Senator Panizza was directed to me. What I have to say may answer the question that was asked of Senator Spindler—he may subsequently do it better; that is up to him. With regard to the shearing team analogy, we could all have an anecdotal discussion but that would not take us far. I understand the point that Senator Panizza is trying to make, but I do not understand why he thinks it is fair that, if we have a shearing team, one of whom is discovered to be homosexual, and there is, as he put it, unrest in the shearing team not necessarily caused by that individual, the person who is not causing the unrest should be sacked. That does not seem to me to be fair.

PARA.TAB: If someone else is causing a problem, that person should be sacked, not the person whose sexual preference that individual objects to. If the person causes unrest in the shearing team by engaging in some activity, then that person can be dismissed for such an action. People may behave unreasonably by fighting with an individual or attacking an individual. If they behave unreasonably they do not have any protection over and above any other individual who behaves unreasonably. But people cannot be sacked simply by virtue of their sexual preference.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about their own protection, Bob?

—If somebody attacks them, that person ought to be sacked, not them. One cannot sack somebody for being a victim. If somebody attacks a homosexual worker, it is the attacker who should be sacked, not the victim.
—What about a person who refuses to join a union, then?
—We will deal with that when we come to it. If someone threatens them, it is the threatener against whom action should be taken, not the person who was threatened.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the question directed to Senator Spindler, can I just give this response, and if the honourable senator wishes to add to it he is welcome to do so. If people with a physical disability are unable to discharge the fundamental requirements of a position, it is not discrimination not to employ them. It is appropriate and desirable under other legislation, such as the disability services legislation, that one takes every reasonable action to find a way to do so. I know that Senator Panizza agrees with that. I did not want to leave my statement unqualified because that might have created the wrong impression. I am not suggesting that Senator Panizza does not agree. One should try to make it possible, and I know Senator Panizza does share that view.

But if there is something inherent in the physical limitation or any of the other grounds under proposed new section 170DF(1)(e) that means that a person is inherently unable to discharge the requirements of the position, then it is not discrimination to terminate the employment because the person cannot do the job. What we are saying is that if an individual can by all other standards do the job, it is not reasonable to dismiss an individual simply by virtue of the characteristics listed in 170DF(1)(e) and those proposed to be added by Senator Spindler's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his explanation. It was a good one. May I add that I have known many heterosexual troublemakers on jobs who were dismissed or otherwise dealt with because they were making trouble, not because they were heterosexual. Clearly, on the question that Senator Panizza asked about a person with a certain disability carrying out a particular job, we need to look at the duties that person has to carry out and whether the disability excludes the person from carrying out those duties. But if that person is perfectly capable of carrying out those duties, he or she should not be discriminated against purely on the grounds of disability. I think we have agreement on that.

—So far, this debate has talked about a person's ability to carry out a task. But it neglects one very important situation; namely, whether that person will damage the business of the employer. I will give the Senate a perfectly good example of this. Let us suppose that I am an employer running a sports physiotherapy practice and that my practice is based principally on treating sportsmen—football players, cricketers or whatever. Let us assume that one of the physiotherapists blatantly states, after being employed, that he is homosexual and as a consequence my clients refuse to be treated at the practice. If that happens, I will, of course, suffer a loss.

PARA.TAB: Under the provision that has been referred to by Senator McMullan, that is, clause 170DF(2), I am not permitted to terminate that person's employment because it is not something which is an inherent bar to that person's carrying out the position. Of course they can carry out the position, they may be a very good physiotherapist, but there is no use employing a very good physiotherapist if none of my clients will be treated either by that person or within the practice. How then am I as an employer to be protected under this bill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister might be able to answer Senator O'Chee at the same time that he responds to me. No-one in this chamber would deny that the rights to employment of persons who are homosexuals or lesbians should be upheld. I do not think there would be anybody in this chamber who would suggest that any action taken by an employer in respect of those persons—because of what those persons did which was not relevant to the particular milieu in which that person is employed—under those circumstances would not be appropriate. In other words, if the action of the person because of the person's sexual preference is a relevant consideration, then that surely is a relevant consideration when it comes to action by an employer.

PARA.TAB: The rights of persons to employment are very important. I have been in the situation of protecting rights of employees in respect of these questions. But we also have an obliga

SPEECH.PARA: tion to protect the rights of others, and in particular to protect the rights of the vulnerable and the impressionable, such as children. In that circumstance it comes down to the question of employment in schools. Parents have a prior right over anybody in respect of the education of their children. If we have a situation whereby a homosexual teacher is acting in a manner which is likely to influence the impressionable students, then surely an educational institution and the parents have the right to try to uphold and protect the rights of their children.

PARA.TAB: Let us not just deal with this in a vacuum. A recent editorial in a teachers journal urged teachers to urge children of nine, 10 and 11 years of age to try to discover whether they were homosexuals or lesbians; it said they should be coming out—that was the term used. In my view, under those circumstances, parents have the right to go to the head of the school and request that, if such a person is to continue to have some sort of influence over children, that person should be removed from that situation. I hope there are not too many people around this chamber who would disagree with that, but where is the protection in this measure for the rights of parents under those circumstances?
It might be said that section 38 of the sex discrimination legislation covers an:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . educational institution that is conducted in accordance with the doctrines, tenets, beliefs or teachings of a particular religion or creed, if the first-mentioned person so discriminates in good faith in order to avoid injury to the religious susceptibilities of adherents of that religion or creed.

But that is an exemption in the Sex Discrimination Act. I think I asked a question last night that I have not really had a response to yet, although the minister gave me some sort of response. Apart from the question of remedies, what does this legislation do that is not already covered—inadequately, I believe—by the sex discrimination legislation and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission Act? I would like the committee to be provided with specific details, by the minister or the mover of the amendment, as to how this amendment is different from, and affects, the operation of the Sex Discrimination Act and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission Act.

PARA.TAB: There are other areas of vulnerability as well. A number of us have been involved in counselling and supporting certain institutions such as women's shelters. I know, and honourable senators will know, that situations exist where the last thing a woman who is seeking refuge after being battered wants is somebody who has a hatred of men telling her all men are crook. That is the last thing she wants. She does not want that sort of ideological approach. She needs care and understanding, she needs her dignity to be recognised and all these sorts of things. Under those circumstances, she does not want to have an ideological earbashing from a lesbian.

If the managers of such an institution have that view, are they able to suggest under this particular piece of legislation that that person should be removed, or transferred to some other job in the institution or, indeed, be told that that is inappropriate counselling and that if it is repeated to the distress of the woman concerned, she will be out of a job and can look for a job somewhere else? What is the effect of this? The minister is talking about violence against women. I know of examples of this situation having occurred where the woman has been absolutely distressed because she has received this ideological earbashing.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's the problem—the sexuality.

—It is an ideological earbashing from a lesbian, actually. I really want to know how this will operate. I would also like the minister to advise at some stage the effect of this amendment as it refers to the convention concerning discrimination in respect of employment occupation—I think that was the 1958 ILO convention—and also the recommendation that is referred to in this legislation. I do not know whether the preparatory papers for either the convention or the recommendation refer to this question of sexual preference; certainly none of the articles do.

—I want to comment on some of the statements that Senator Harradine has made. There is an assumption that lesbians do not like men or basically have a hatred of men. I know of a number of misogynists—which has nothing to do with their sexuality—and I know of a number of radical feminists who are not lesbians. We have made some assumptions that people's attitudes somehow are necessarily based on their sexuality or sexual preference. I refute that. Sexual preference should not be the basis on which we make decisions in relation to employment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of issues have been raised in this discussion, not all of them directly relevant. Some have been quite central to concerns that people have. I want to respond to the concerns that were raised by Senator Harradine. I think they are concerns of a type that have been raised by others. It may go some way towards meeting Senator O'Chee's concern as well.

PARA.TAB: If individuals—homosexual or otherwise—are engaging in unreasonable behaviour, they should be dealt with under their employment contract as a consequence of that behaviour. If they are harassing distressed women, they ought not be allowed to continue to do so, whether they are lesbians, male homosexuals, heterosexuals or whatever other category people might wish to contemplate. But if they have such a sexual preference and are behaving reasonably, that sexual preference should not be a ground for dismissal. That is the point.

Nobody could suggest that it is unreasonable for the management of a woman's refuge to protect women from being harassed by anybody. I certainly would not. The government does not and the amendment does not give anyone grounds to do so. We are saying that one should not assume that lesbians are going to harass other women—the overwhelming majority of them do not—or if male homosexuals happen to be school teachers, they are going to behave in a manner that is unreasonable by way of encouraging other students to develop a sexual preference or whatever.

That is not reasonable behaviour from any schoolteacher, irrespective of sexual preference. Therefore, that unreasonable behaviour is legitimate grounds for remedy by the employer, but it is not remedy based on the fact that that person has some particular sexual preference. That is the distinction. It is an important distinction, and the nature of the legislation is designed to protect that circumstance and to establish processes for distinguishing between those two circumstances.

Nobody is contending—and the government certainly does not accept this amendment on any assumption—that people, because of their age, disability, sexual preference or any of the other issues under subclause (1)(e), or various other subclauses where they arise, get more rights than anybody else. They have no right to behave unreasonably to coworkers, their employers, their customers or people in their care.

It is true that difficult circumstances for employers can arise, and Senator O'Chee has raised one. I have to say that, although he was careful in the way he expressed it, it is not my experience that that level of discrimination is likely to occur in this circumstance.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you were in the changing room you might.
