—Well, actually I have been, and I know a large number of homosexual people engaged in sport, none of whom have abused their position, but I do not see why there would be discrimination against a physiotherapist for that reason. I know that there is prejudice in the community; we have all had to deal with it from time to time on various grounds. Let me put it to Senator O'Chee like this: if we had a circumstance where a black physiotherapist was employed and a number of people said, `We are not going to go to that establishment because one of the workers is black', I, at least, would not—and I do not believe the Senate would—think that that was reasonable grounds for dismissal. It is reasonable grounds for considering what views one might form about the people refusing to go there, but it is not grounds for sacking the black worker. It is a very difficult situation. It is a very rare situation—I am not saying impossible—but it is, again, a `blaming the victim' situation, where someone who is discriminated against has that discrimination compounded.

PARA.TAB: In any business, the capacity to employ the number of people on one's staff is determined by the amount of business one has. If the amount of business falls, then, logically, the number of people one employs falls and the opportunity for redress without discrimination may well then arise. I do not want to pretend that moving to a society in which there is less discrimination than there is now and less legal sanction for that discrimination will be without difficulties. If someone is trying to tell that story, it is not me.

We had similar debates at the time of the introduction of the human rights and equal opportunity legislation. There was a bit of Chicken Little debate then and there were some reasonable concerns raised. There has been difficulty and controversy around this country and in other countries in the decade about the various pieces of anti-discrimination legislation but, on balance, I think it is unquestionably the case that our country is better for having had that legislation, notwithstanding some difficulty.

Senator O'Chee's problem could arise under any of these terms, not just under Senator Spindler's amendment. The problem could arise under proposed subsection 170DF(1)(e) without Senator Spindler's amendment, on the basis of other sorts of discrimination, but to the best of my knowledge—and I am not trying to put words in anyone's mouth—the opposition is not opposed to proposed subsection 170DF(1)(e); it is concerned about the amendment.

We are not raising a new problem. I accept a new element of the existing problem; we live in a society in which people are discriminated against on the grounds of `race, colour, sex, marital status, family responsibilities, pregnancy, religion, political opinion, national extraction or social origins'—all those discriminations happen and three others. We are not raising a new problem, although we are raising new elements of the existing problem.

So Senator O'Chee's problem could exist without this amendment in other circumstances. I do not see why we should say that it is all right to discriminate against a person who is behaving reasonably because of his or her sexual preference. Of course, if that person is behaving unreasonably then—

TALK.START.PARA: —What if you lose your clients?
—But what if one loses clients because a person is black? The opposition is not opposed to (1)(e), which says—
—If a person by his presence in that place is causing the businessman to lose clients, what choice does the businessman have?

—I accept that Senator O'Chee is raising a point that needs to be pursued. The bill as it exists and the clause to which I understand those opposite are not opposed already raises the issue that they are concerned about because it says that one cannot terminate an employee's employment on the grounds of race. I know that Senator O'Chee would be very concerned about racial discrimination; he has spoken about it in this parliament. Obviously, I know he shares that concern.

PARA.TAB: What I am saying is that exactly the problem that Senator O'Chee alludes to can arise now because we are saying, `You cannot sack people merely because of their race even if your clients are racially prejudiced'. It has been the law of this country for a long time that one cannot discriminate against people on the grounds of race. The remedy would be the conciliation processes of the human rights commission rather than this parliament.

We have not been awash in those years with cases of problems arising under this matter, so I think what Senator O'Chee is talking about is an obscure possibility. I do not deny that it is a possibility—I am not trying to exclude it—or that it would be difficult. Certainly, the government's position—and, I understand, the opposition's position—is that proposed subsection 170DF(1)(e) is a proposition which we all support.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the operation of subsection (2) in conjunction with that and the word `inherent' which causes the difficulty.

—Yes. But, as I understand it, the opposition supports it at the moment, notwithstanding that there are circumstances in which it could cause difficulty on the grounds of racial discrimination. No-one says that racial discrimination should cause someone to be dismissed, but we acknowledge that there are problems that could arise.

PARA.TAB: I do not believe we should say that discrimination on these three grounds that Senator Spindler raises should be treated in any way differently from racial discrimination. It is all discrimination on a basis without reasonable reference to the behaviour of the individual as an employee. So we are not raising a new problem.

If the opposition is saying that its view is that proposed subsection 170DF(1)(e) should be deleted, then we will change the nature of the debate. The debate would then be very serious, difficult and different. But if that is not the opposition's view, then I do not think Senator O'Chee's point has the power that it appears on its face to have, because all we would be doing is moving a millimetre on an issue that is already substantially within this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the issue raised by Senator O'Chee as to whether a person of a particular sexual preference should be employed in a business if it is causing damage to that business, the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) raised the issue of race. He said that they are equivalent circumstances—that if a black person was employed by that business the same argument could well apply. I put it to the minister that a distinction can be drawn between those two circumstances.

PARA.TAB: In the example the minister has outlined regarding a black person, he is talking about the physical characteristic of an individual, which I—and I am sure Senator O'Chee and everyone else agrees—believe should not be a ground for discrimination. The case of concern that Senator O'Chee has raised refers to behavioural characteristics. A distinction can be drawn there and that ought to be acknowledged.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't find it an acceptable distinction, but I understand your argument.

—There are others who believe that there are clear distinctions that can be drawn. The particular issue I want to raise with the minister and with Senator Spindler is: where is the protection in this amendment for individual conscience? I put to the minister that there are people in our community who, through religious conviction, believe that it is their responsibility to restrain what they regard as evil and, to the extent that they are able, to keep evil out of their homes, out of their businesses and generally out of their lifestyle. Those people also believe that certain types of behaviour are evil.

PARA.TAB: The debate this morning has centred around sexual preference and that may be one area that certain people believe is evil. People may believe that drinking alcohol is evil. They may not want to employ people who drink alcohol. The minister has acknowledged that behaviour in the workplace that is regarded as unacceptable certainly should not be allowed there. That is one area that can be considered. But there are people who believe that the very presence in their workplace of people who practice particular things that they regard as evil involves the presence in the workplace of that evil. That is a position they hold in good conscience, a position they hold by conviction.

Is that good conscience held through religious conviction to be completely ignored, simply because others do not have that particular view? Are they not entitled to hold to that conscientious view and apply that conscientious view within their own businesses? Or is it simply to be ignored and overridden by the views of others? Where is the protection for that sort of conscientious view in this amendment?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to provide some information that Senator Harradine requested in relation to ILO convention 111 on discrimination in employment and occupation. Australia has, in fact, added sexual preference and age as grounds for anti-discrimination under the convention by declaring regulations made under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986. These regulations were made in 1989 and took effect in 1990.
—So that's the law now, is it?

—No, it is not. It is the constitutional power under which this legislation can be enacted and I am sure Senator Kemp will appreciate that with his detailed knowledge of the constitutional law of Australia. To advert to the situation described by Senator Chapman, it seems to me that people who hold very strong beliefs either way can simply avoid that situation by not seeking employment in such a situation. Senator Chapman used the word `behavioural'. I put it to him that that is a misconception of the three grounds on which I believe discrimination should not be exercised in employment. Age is clearly not behavioural, disability is clearly not behavioural and sexuality is clearly not behavioural.
—Ha, ha!

—I am afraid the laughter shows that people are not up with the definitions that scientifically have shown that it is not a choice but that it is an innate physical characteristic. I think that needs to be taken into account.

—In respect of what Senator Margetts said, my statement was not at all to allege that lesbians are necessarily acting in that way. The example that I gave was quite disconcerting. The individual concerned was offended by the treatment that she got in the shelter and was very much offended by the suggestions that were made, which were anti-men. There would be other people, in a very vulnerable state, who would respond—or possibly would respond—to suggestions which were lesbian in character. I do not know whether the minister is suggesting that that would be inappropriate action and, therefore, grounds for dismissal of the worker concerned.

PARA.TAB: I come back to the question of schools. I listened carefully to what the minister said. I am raising a question about the rights of children in respect of the persons who teach them in school. Quite often children, particularly young and vulnerable children, are very well aware of the lifestyles of their teachers. If the teacher, by word and influence, is going to have an undue influence on these children, surely that is a matter that needs to be taken into account. It was, in fact, taken into account by the government, and exemptions were given in section 38 of the Sex Discrimination Act in respect of certain types of educational institutions.

This brings me back to this question: are those exemptions, limited though they are, protected by this amendment? I asked this question and I still have not got the answer. Apart from the issue of remedy, what does this amendment do? What elements are there in this amendment that are different from the elements currently contained in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act and its regulations and the Sex Discrimination Act and its regulations?

I did ask another question, and Senator Spindler gave the committee advice—of which, of course, the committee was fully aware—which did not go to the question that I asked. Of course I am aware of the fact that there were regulations made in respect of the definition. What I did ask concerned the fact that if we are talking about reaching into an ILO convention for the validity of this clause, then we have to consider what is the proper interpretation of that convention. If we do not consider it, the courts will consider it.

Relevant to that consideration is what precisely the articles of the convention say and what was in the minds of the persons who drafted and voted upon the articles. Some of that—not all—is able to be seen in the travaux preparatoires or other working papers. Frankly, I have not seen anything in those preparatory documents which enables the type of amendment currently before us in respect of sexual preference to be validly maintained.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —So many issues have been raised since I last stood up that I may miss some, but I will try to cover them all. The last point raised by Senator Harradine concerned the constitutional authority for those regulations which establish the basis for our right to legislate in this manner. I am advised—and I endorse what Senator Spindler said—it has been accepted that those regulations, getting their force as they do from the terms of the relevant international documents, therefore are considered as, and have been accepted as, a legitimate base of constitutional power to so act.

PARA.TAB: It may well be the case that someone will challenge that in the High Court. I do not want to say what the High Court would say about it. But my advice is that the Commonwealth is clearly of the view that the power unequivocally exists. It is for the Senate to decide whether we should exercise that power. My advice is that there is no doubt that the power so to act exists, and it essentially derives from that which Senator Spindler outlined.

Senator Harradine asked me a question on a previous occasion. However, because there have been so many questions, I missed it. The honourable senator wanted to know what additional matters this bill deals with over and above the human rights and equal opportunity legislation. As I said in a previous answer, the predominant difference is that this bill gives an enforceable remedy to an employee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes; but apart from that.

—I do not want to just put that aside. That is essentially the key to it; that is essentially the reason. The bill says, `You don't only have a right to seek conciliation under that legislation; you have rights as an employee, flowing from this legislation, to be reinstated. You have the capacity to have an enforceable remedy'. That is the primary thing. I think that arguably a secondary benefit will flow from the conciliation and arbitration power, but that might be limited. In my experience, many industrial disputes originate from terminations of employment. The capacity to be able to deal with that under the industrial legislation is a worthwhile additional element.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to seek to fudge the question. The predominant reason why the government is accepting this amendment and why all of the other elements, which are not affected by the amendment, are contained in paragraph (e), is that they give an effective remedy to people who otherwise would only have the initial right to conciliation and then to seek a recommendation.

Senator Harradine also asked whether the modifications to the definition of `discrimination', similar to those in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act, are incorporated in this bill. There are additional amendments to be moved on behalf of the government which will duplicate those exceptions that are already in the human rights act. I cannot say whether they do everything that Senator Harradine wants, because I do not know what it is he is seeking. But I have been advised that they duplicate the exceptions that are already set out in the definition of `discrimination' in the human rights act.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the sex discrimination act?

—As I understand it, they are the same. If there is a problem, we can talk about it later. But I think it covers the point that Senator Harradine is seeking to make. I will get some further advice to see whether there is a gap.

PARA.TAB: The only extra point to raise—it is really such a philosophical divide that we will just have to agree to disagree—is the one that Senator Chapman raised again. While I recognise and would defend the rights of individuals to hold views with which I disagree strongly, including some of those which he outlined, I do not defend the right of people to exercise those beliefs to the disadvantage of other Australians. We all have the right to hold our opinions, but we do not have the right to exercise them in a way that is adverse to the rights of other Australians. I understand that Senator Chapman and others hold a different view. I merely articulate that for the record. We just have to agree to disagree, and the Senate will have to decide.

TALK.START.PARA: —I return to the problem which the minister sort of answered but did not, which is: what does an employer do when his customers or clients refuse to come to a place because of the sexual preference of one of the people working there? A physiotherapist does not have to be groping the patients, customers, clients or whatever one wants to call them; they may just refuse to go there.

PARA.TAB: Should employers wait until they lose all their business before it becomes reasonable for them to make a decision, however regrettable, to terminate that person's employment? Or if the customers say, `We will not come if that person remains there', is that sufficient grounds for termination? Do they have to wait until they suffer damage to their business before they are allowed to act? They may not even agree with the viewpoint of their customers. Do they have to wait until they suffer damage to their business? Is that what the minister is saying?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I really have nothing much to add. I cannot give an opinion of how the court would determine that, but I can say—
—That is the problem.

—Of course. Senator O'Chee is supporting proposed subsection 1(e). An employer has exactly the same rights and obligations to deal with circumstances where clients are discriminating against an employee on the grounds of sexual preference as if they are discriminating against that person on the grounds of race. That is appropriate. Senator Chapman has articulated the reason why he does not think it is appropriate. I understand his view, but I do not share it.
—I also said you can draw a distinction.
—I understand that. I do not share his view, but he articulated it and that is a legitimate part of the debate in this place. I do not share his view.

PARA.TAB: We believe that the same rights and obligations exist. I do not deny that an individual—whether the employee or the employer—can be put in a difficult situation in those circumstances. One has to decide in the circumstances of each case exactly what is reasonable for the employer.

We are not literally debating the amendment to the clause, but we are debating the amendment, the principle of which will apply to that clause. The rights and obligations should be exactly the same irrespective of the grounds of discrimination—race, colour, sex and all those other items listed in paragraph (e) as well as the three grounds listed in the amendment. That is my point.

We are not imposing a new right or obligation; we are simply broadening the definition of the circumstances in which it should apply. Discrimination on the grounds of age, disability and sexual preference should be treated the same as discrimination on the grounds of race, colour, sex, et cetera.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to highlight two or three points with regard to these problems. I want to identify what I think is a serious deficiency in terms of the way that the government—or the Democrats-cum-government—is dealing with it. I do not intend to re-run this debate as each clause comes up because we have tried to deal with the issue in its totality. But there will be some further questions when we get to the exemption clause.

PARA.TAB: I believe that three particular situations have been identified here for which neither Senator Spindler nor the minister has given satisfactory answers. Discrimination against particular individuals has two sides. What has been put into the bill—it should not be in it; as I said before, it belongs in the other act that we have talked about—is something which places the rights of one group of people ahead of those of others.

I particularly refer to the problem that Senator O'Chee raised, which is very legitimate, and the point that Senator Harradine raised with regard to the rights of parents. I do not believe that the answers we have had in terms of the latter issue have been satisfactory, although I guess that will be raised when we deal with the exemption clause. The third problem concerns individuals' religious beliefs or the creed under which they operate, and this applies to many Australians.

I want to put on the public record my view of the points that the government and the Democrats, through Senator Spindler, have raised. In my view, they are contravening the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which Australia is a signatory to. I will not read the whole document. However, part of it states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . guarantee to all persons equal and effective protection against discrimination on any ground . . . religion, political or other opinion . . .

I do not believe that Senator Spindler has thought through the ramifications of this series of amendments which will go into the Industrial Relations Act in terms of the matters that have been raised, particularly those concerning people's firmly held and adhered to religious beliefs.

PARA.TAB: Until this issue is addressed in total, I believe that these amendments should not be proceeded with. They will cause more problems than they will solve. I wanted to put that point on the record. If the government is relying so much on heads of power based on international conventions, I suggest that it look at what it has done in terms of this convention. As I said, it is quite clear to me that it is contradicting this convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a very brief comment. The comments by my colleague are spot-on. The problem with very prescriptive views of human rights is that they tend to elevate certain rights at the expense of others. The debate to date has concentrated on one particular set of rights and the desire to avoid discrimination against a group of people. We are all in favour of trying to avoid discrimination and persecution. But sometimes, when this is pushed to the extreme, the rights of other people are trampled on. Sometimes it is the rights of employers, sometimes it is parents and sometimes it is other clients.

PARA.TAB: There is a real problem and dilemma. Senator Spindler has a very narrow, fixed view of human rights. I like to think that in a society where there is widespread diversity—a very tolerant society—we accept, as Senator Chapman said, that there are people of passionate religious beliefs. They are quite entitled to those beliefs and they are entitled not to have those beliefs capriciously trampled on.

People like Senator Spindler have a set of beliefs and views, and we do not want those trampled. We have to remember that when we pass laws we elevate certain rights at the expense of others. Although we may not mean to do that, that is precisely what occurs. This is what worries honourable senators on this side of the chamber.

I think we have a tolerant and diverse society. Part of the great aim of a liberal society is to ensure that we maintain these values and recognise and tolerate diversity. We are seeing these prescriptive views in quite a few areas. We saw them yesterday in the child-care guidelines and we are seeing them again today in Senator Spindler's amendments. Our desire to suddenly move with full force to protect one group of people may trample on another group of people. I say to Senator Spindler and Senator McMullan that I have listened very carefully to what they have said but I am not convinced that they have tackled those issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reply to Senator Crane first. This amendment was given thorough consideration for weeks. We have discussed this amendment and we sought advice from the Attorney-General's Department. We also sought independent legal advice. This amendment was not brought forward casually.

PARA.TAB: We consider this amendment necessary to advance the very tolerance that Senator Kemp suggested our society has. It seems to me that the argument is being turned on its head by Senator Kemp. He is asking for the right to discriminate and repress. This amendment seeks to widen the level of tolerance in our society.

Because we say this so often, I wonder whether people want to hear and want to understand that we are not talking about peoples' rights to hold views, we are not talking about peoples' rights to be of a particular persuasion and we are not talking about peoples' rights to have particular philosophical or practical views in particular situations. We are simply saying that because a person is what he or she is, which has no relationship to the employment situation, that person should not be discriminated against in employment.

To the extent that their behaviour affects adversely the objectives of the employer, the employee and the whole workplace, the exemption clause comes into force. If it is behaviour that counteracts the objective of the employment, the employer can discriminate. That is quite obvious.

We are talking about two different things. I do not think the opposition wants to accept the view that people who have a particular disposition or innate quality should not be readily discriminated against in the workplace. That is the situation that the opposition suggests should be maintained. We are saying that it should be discontinued.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise with the minister some matters relating to the objects of the act. I ask for an explanation as to why the wording of the objects of the 1988 act has changed from `to promote industrial harmony and cooperation among the parties involved in industrial relations' to `to provide a framework for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes'. The changes are very significant. Is section (e) in the objects of the act a direct recognition of the very significant changes that are being made as far as boycott provisions, restrictions on common law tort actions and removal of the responsibilities of union organisers on a work site are concerned? In fact, under the current 1988 act it is illegal for union officials or union organisers to incite people in the workplace—
—They don't have to.

—It is in clauses 311 and 312 of the 1988 Industrial Relations Act. This amendment will remove that so that it will no longer be an offence under the Industrial Relations Act to go into the workplace and incite employees. Is this a direct recognition and admission right at the start of the act that the government is expecting to have more industrial disputation? If the government is not expecting that, why have the objects been changed?

PARA.TAB: I have heard people on the other side of the chamber mention many times—and I have not disagreed with it—that in many of the unions today there is a much more objective attitude towards behaviour. Is not the fact that the government is changing those objectives a direct recognition that it is anticipating more disruption, more civil disobedience and a number of other things? If not, why is it necessary to change the objects of the act from `to promote industrial harmony and cooperation'? I believe that those words are much more appropriate than the proposed objective which I have outlined.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to confess that I have not engaged in a great deal of philosophical discussion about why the wording of the objects has been changed. It is certainly far-fetched to say that it is in some way because we think there will be more disputes under the legislation. On the contrary, we are fairly confident that the remarkable success the government has had in reducing the level of time lost through industrial disputes in Australia will continue.
—Because of the recession.

—That would be a better argument if it did not also go down while growth was under way, and Senator Parer knows that it did. He should stop rewriting history. What we have here is a much more functional description. The wording `prevention and settlement of industrial disputes', as Senator Crane would know, comes straight out of the constitutional power. We now have a functional description of what it is intended to do. It takes out some of the rhetorical flourish and describes in a much more pragmatic way what it is intending to do. I do not think one should try to read great philosophical principles into it. We have moved to a detailed outline of that which the bill is intended to achieve.

—I ask the minister to address the specific point of why the government would want to take out the words `to promote industrial harmony and cooperation'. I find it remarkable, from what I have heard from the other side of the chamber in recent times, that the government is taking those words out of what should be a major objective of an industrial relations system—no matter whose model it is.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not much point in getting into a debate about what I call the rhetorical flourishes.
—Just answer the question.
—With respect, Senator Crane might not like the answer, but it does not make it not an answer.
—It doesn't matter whether I like it or not; just answer it.

—We will have a very long day if we proceed at this rate. The circumstance is simply that this is what we think is an accurate description. The fact that we do not have a particular form of words in no way implies that we regard the successful conduct of industrial relations and the minimisation of time lost through industrial disputes as anything other than a very important objective of government. It is one in which we have been uniquely successful and we expect this legislation to facilitate our continuing to be very successful. It gets a bit esoteric for me to then pursue whether we need to say something is about sweetness and light or, rather, describe the processes by which we will achieve it. This is a functional description of the bill and its practical objects. If Senator Crane would like it to be more rhetorical, all I can say is I am sorry.

—Senator McMullan has totally missed the point I was making. These words were in the objects of the act and the government has obviously made a considered—I would hope—and positive decision to remove them.
—What did they mean?

—If Senator Murphy does not know what they mean, he has a problem. The government has made a deliberate decision to take those words out. That is the point that I wanted to raise and put on the record. From my point of view, it is disappointing that the government has made that decision. It shows that the government has changed its position as to what it sees as being the objects of the act.

PARA.TAB: Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 5 and 6—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 7.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: (1)Clause 7, page 3, lines 20 to 26, omit proposed paragraph 88A(a), substitute the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(a)employees are protected by awards that set fair and enforceable minimum wages and conditions of employment that are maintained at a relevant level; and".

SPEECH.PARA: This is a consequential provision merely omitting a reference to paid rates in this proposed paragraph. A substantial debate about this paid rates issue will come at a later stage, I assume.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 8 and 9—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 10.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Clause 10, page 4, line 16, after "Part" insert "and Part VIC".
(3)Clause 10, page 4, proposed subsection 90AA(1), line 17, after "Part" insert "and Part VIC".
(4)Clause 10, page 4, proposed subsection 90AA(1), line 19, after "Part" insert "and Part VIC".

These additional amendments also relate to paid rates. Amendments 2 to 4 insert references to the new paid rates part in proposed section 90AA reflecting the proposed establishment of a new paid rates part, debate on which, as I said, we will come to.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
Clauses as amended, agreed to.
Clause 11 agreed to.
Clause 12.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of amendments to this clause. I think ours is probably the least controversial, although they may turn out to be famous last words. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 12, page 5, proposed subsection 111(1AA), line 10, before "(iii)" insert "(i), (ii) or".

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—I call Senator Bell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: Mr Temporary Chairman—
Order! Senator Crane?
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a procedural question. We have identical amendments to this clause. Who moves it?
—I have called Senator Bell, so I guess that Senator Bell moves it. I apologise.
—That is wrong procedure, is it not?
—It is those who get the call.
—We put this amendment in first.
—The matter is on the floor of the chamber. Senator Bell caught my eye first and I called Senator Bell. There was no malice aforethought, I assure you, Senator Crane, in the call.

—I accept your explanation that there was no malice, but due to where I sit I quite often miss out because I am outside your view. My name was first on the running sheet. I believed that I was to move this amendment.

—I assure you, Senator Crane, that there was no malice aforethought. It was accidental that I called Senator Bell on the way through. I will be alert to what names appear on the running sheet for the future passage of amendments in this section of the committee stage. I call Senator Bell.

—I acknowledge that Senator Crane submitted this amendment first. It was received and printed first. I also wish to point out that it is identical to the amendment which we proposed to achieve the same purpose. Little is to be scored by attempting to claim who thought of it first. The effect will be an effect with which we agree, and that is to achieve the opportunity for interim awards to be extended to enterprise flexibility agreements. That is an effect which is both desirable and which expedites the additional flexibility in this industrial relations scene, which we are about to see after the passage of this bill.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Kemp would be well advised to pay attention to the amendments which his own party is moving and to see that there is some degree of concurrence with what the Democrats are proposing. Rather than offer gratuitous insults, he would be better directed to the amendments which we agreed on with the coalition and to understand the purpose of those agreements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I take a point of order. I can appreciate that Senator Bell has had a long and late night and probably came into the chamber a bit tetchy—
—What is your point of order, Senator Kemp?
—I made no reflection at all on Senator Bell, and for Senator Bell to get up and make those utterly gratuitous comments is quite unacceptable.
—There is no point of order.

—Thank you for that observation, Mr Temporary Chairman. It just serves to demonstrate my concern that attention is not being directed towards the legislation but rather to some mischief. I acknowledge Senator Crane's amendment and I endorse it. If he chooses to move it, I will support it.
—With all due respect, you cannot do that now because I have called you.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 6.Clause 12, page 5, paragraph (b) after proposed paragraph 111(1D)(b), add the following paragraph:
"or (c) making such an award will facilitate the approval under Division 3 of Part VIB of an agreement covering employees who are not already covered by an award.".

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by the opposition and the Democrats. I would like to point out, in supporting the remarks made by Senator Bell on this issue, that the aim is to expedite the making of an interim award. Certified agreements can only be made if all the employees that would be bound by the agreement are covered by an award. The rapid establishment of an interim award is a convenient way of dealing with non-award employees who would eventually come under an agreement.

PARA.TAB: Like certified agreements, enterprise flexibility agreements can be made only if all the employees who would be bound by the agreement are covered by awards. The bill itself does not require the commission to expedite the creation of interim awards to speed the approval of an enterprise flexibility agreement. The amendment, whether it be the coalition amendment or the Democrat amendment, resolves the inconsistency by adding a new paragraph to proposed section 1D that requires the commission to speed interim awards that would facilitate enterprise flexibility agreements. The Metway Bank pointed out its inconsistency in its submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. It also pointed out that there was no guarantee that the commission would speedily make an interim award to cover its senior staff if at some stage the company wished to negotiate a single enterprise flexibility agreement, that is, if it was unable to negotiate a certified agreement. That is the reason for the moving of this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman.
—We are glad to see you smiling.

—I always smile; it is just the degree of the smile. I support what my colleague Senator Parer said about this amendment. I am not going to revisit this during the whole debate, but it is important that, if we are going to have a running sheet, we do work off the running sheet. Although I do not want to get into a tit for tat debate, our amendments were circulated at least 24 hours before the Democrats' amendments were circulated. I believe the running sheet reflects the precedence as to how these things are done—it is in the order in which the amendments are put forward. I would hope that for the rest of this debate we can operate off the running sheet. This amendment will speed up the process of enterprise flexibility agreements. I do not have to go over what Senator Parer said. I endorse his comments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I sympathise with Senator Crane. I understand the difficulties of fielding at deep square leg, but all I can say is that we are not responsible for placing the field. That is a matter he should raise with others.
—Hold on! We had a running sheet.
—I am sorry, I am not trying to score off Senator Crane. I was trying to be sympathetic.
—How do you cope at silly point?

—I was about to say that I would much rather be at point than square leg. I thank Senator Chapman for the interjection. I can count. I understand that if the Australian Democrats and the opposition move the same amendment, provided they do not get into too much disagreement about who moved it first, it will obviously get carried. I will not take up the time of the Senate unduly, but there are some things that we need to say. While we will not divide on it, I make clear that the government opposes this amendment.

PARA.TAB: I understand the purpose of the amendment. I think it is a welcome purpose because it is designed to assist in the making of enterprise flexibility agreements which the government supports. That is why we are proposing to put them into the legislation in the first place. In this instance it is not a disagreement of purpose but of process. Therefore, we cannot support the amendment.

I think we will find a very puzzling situation because, as practitioners will know, awards by their nature are made between employers and unions who are parties to interstate disputes. That is what the Industrial Relations Commission power allows.But enterprise flexibility agreements by their nature are not. They apply to employers and employees who are not parties to the relevant award covering those employees. There seems to me to be a very tenuous connection between the interim award and the agreement. The best that I can say for this amendment is that I do not think it will do much harm, but I cannot see how it will do any good.

I am amused to see that the government is in the position of expressing concerns that the states are concerned about this proposal. The states have shown considerable sensitivity about the potential for enterprise flexibility agreements made under the corporations power to intrude into their jurisdiction. I think they would therefore be concerned that the use of interim awards for this purpose might be a problem for them.

We are more than a little concerned in this instance that a further difficulty arises in that not all state awards are kept up to date. We could wind up with differing standards applying for the purpose of the no disadvantage test. I have serious apprehension about this proposal, but I suspect that it will have such extremely limited application that it probably will not do much harm. I indicate that the government is opposed to it. I think wiser counsel would suggest that one should not do this, but I would rather lose before 12.45—unless some honourable senators leap up and tells me that they are about to change their minds—than continue the debate after lunch.

TALK.START.PARA: —We should not let the matter rest at that. For the edification of the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) in determining what good it will do, I point out that the opportunity to make an interim award allows the determination of an enterprise flexibility agreement to proceed with an award underpinning it. Without that, it would be much more difficult to determine no disadvantage.

PARA.TAB: As well as that, the concern of the states is fairly transparent. The concern of the state governments is that once such interim awards are made with a state award as the basis of it—be it outdated or not—then the agreement subsequently moves away from those state awards. Of course the states are trying to protect their own territory. They should be recognised as doing so. I still think that the benefits by far outweigh the minister's small concerns.
Amendment agreed to.
Progress reported.
