TALK.START.PARA: —When debate on the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill was interrupted last week, I was speaking about superannuation, which was one of the matters covered in this bill. Before returning to the point that I was making, I would like to recap very briefly. I had outlined that this bill amends five acts and that the amendments concern such subjects as superannuation, limiting of appeals from the Conscientious Objection Tribunal, streamlining of overseas command procedures, mechanics of appointment for Welfare Trust Fund trustees, changes to eligibility for defence home loans and a minor amendment affecting salvage claims.

PARA.TAB: I had made the point that while the bill has no real theme, its focus was on rights and conditions of service for Defence Force members. In particular, I spent some time on the fact that this bill was amending the eligibility rules for gaining a Defence Force home loan. Yet some while ago in these sittings of parliament, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 was passed which ensured that such loans are now to be considered as a fringe benefit for family payment and additional family payment purposes. The amount of the loan is to be assessed by a formula which is contained in the legislation; a formula which I suspect carries its own potential difficulties when income is being reviewed by Social Security for the purpose of ascertaining how much family payment or additional family payment a person is to receive.

Many defence families are about to start to feel the effect of this social security change. It comes into effect on 1 January which is the same time as the annual posting period is undertaken in the defence forces. Exacerbating this concern is the fact that Social Security is unable to provide detailed evidence for recipients of family payment and additional family payment on precisely how they will be affected. Defence families are now facing postings. Ahead of them is Christmas with all its related costs; then into January, when it is time to look at the costs associated with schooling; and all these expenses need to be budgeted for. Yet these families are unable to obtain from Social Security the full details of how they will be placed in the New Year under that amended legislation.

During estimates, the minister made it clear that he did not know what effect the changes to the legislation would have; he did not even know the details of its implementation. I advise the minister to spend some time in his office taking some of the phone calls and receiving the letters that have been flooding into my office in recent months in relation to what is happening there, and he will learn a few of the facts of life of the legislation that he so enthusiastically put through earlier this year.

For another group of defence people, Christmas in new locations with new schools will mean quite a different set of expenses because these are people who have been made redundant through either the CSP or the force structure review. As I was outlining last week, according to the reports I am receiving, in the case of some of these people, superannuation is being used as a tool to ensure that people who have effectively been made redundant but who have not been offered a redundancy package, are nevertheless forced out of the services. In such circumstances, it is a voluntary separation and, therefore, they are not entitled to a redundancy package.

Personnel who have been replaced by civilians as a consequence of the CSP are, in some cases, being offered continued employment in the defence forces but at a lower pay and skill scale with a consequential detrimental effect on their DFRDB, and if they do not like that, they can leave. Most ADF personnel cannot afford to see their superannuation slip back, so they opt to leave. This is good for the government because it ensures that the projected level of separations and the reduction of numbers in the Defence Force that it is driving for and targeting under the review program are met. But at the end of the day it is yet another indirect attack on the defence forces.

It is of grave concern to the opposition that the Defence Force personnel in this country, under this government, are all too frequently under attack—not in a military sense, but with respect to their conditions of service. The great thing about the defence forces that makes them different from all other sections of the community is that they do not have any way to protect their interests. They are terribly dependent on having an effective minister or ministers of defence to look after their interests. That is simply not happening at the present time. Neither of the ministers—the Minister for Defence (Senator Rober Ray) or the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Senator Faulkner)—is doing a thing to look after the welfare of the members of the Australian Defence Force.

We are spending a huge amount of money—a huge fraction—a record amount of the defence vote, on new capital equipment. All the equipment in the world is worth nothing unless we have capable, experienced people of high morale to operate that equipment. That is not happening at the present time because the emphasis is on the hardware, not on the human resources. Morale in the forces now is very low. People know that there is no real defence policy for this country so, therefore, there is no real purpose—no raison d'etre—for their existence and training. They know that the training they are receiving is far less than they should get, because year after year the defence budget is going down and the capital equipment vote is going up. So the percentage gain to capital equipment gets higher as a part of the Defence vote.

The only way the squeeze can be made is by driving people out, which has a deleterious effect on morale, as we have seen in the force structure review, with progressive falling numbers in the defence forces; and by cuts in the operating and training budgets—all the things that are part and parcel of defence professional life. This induces a great state of anxiety within the defence forces. Anxiety now is a constant feature of service life: people are anxious about where the ADF is going; they are anxious about their personal affairs, and what their remuneration packages are.

The government set up the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal—a very flawed instrument; an instrument that at the end of the day makes the CDF, the Chief of the Defence Force, the advocate for improvements in pay and conditions for service personnel, but then makes it mandatory on him to pay that out of his Defence vote. In other words, if the CDF says we need an increase in the service allowance—which is now very much overdue—the only resort the CDF has under this system is to cut back even more in other areas of his budget outlays within the Department of Defence to pay for that increase in pay and conditions. That is transparently wrong. Yet that is the system that this government has put in place, and it is the system that it obstinately refuses to review. It is having a very serious effect on the morale of the defence forces.

I just go back to the instance I used of the service allowance. That allowance is paid to defence personnel for the disabilities they suffer in being posted to all parts of Australia or overseas; and to make up for the fact that they have no overtime, and in certain conditions can be working very long hours a week in very uncongenial circumstances. That allowance has been a constant part of service life for many years. It now has very little meaning because it has not been reviewed for something like six years and it has taken no account at all of the great changes in inflation that have occurred within the Australian community.

For all these reasons, morale is very low in the Defence Force, and the men and women in that Defence Force deserve far better treatment than they are getting from this government. The government and the ministers responsible for this have shown no interest at all in defending, let alone advancing, the interests of the men and women of the Australian Defence Force. But the opposition is prepared to speak out and see that they get a better go.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator MacGibbon raised, essentially, three issues. I do not intend to respond to the allegations of low morale in the defence forces. I am certainly not in a position to address that matter, and I am sure that Senator Robert Ray as the Minister for Defence, and Senator Faulkner as the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, can deal with it on another occasion. I do not believe that the criticism of the two ministers is appropriate; I strongly support their handling of their portfolios.

PARA.TAB: Senator MacGibbon raised a number of issues that I do not think are central to this debate. However, firstly, he asked why the requirement to restrict the right of appeal from conscientious objection tribunals was not foreseen. In response, I can say that provision for conscientious objection tribunals was made by the Defence Legislation Amendment Act 1992, and the requirement for the amendment now proposed was noted after the bill for the act had been introduced into the House. As there were no practical implications, it was decided to make a subsequent amendment rather than delay the passage of the act.

It is noted that this amendment was requested by the Administrative Review Council. The amendment brings the conscientious objection provisions into line with current administrative law policy; namely, that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal provides final review on the merits, and subsequent review by the courts is on questions of law only.

The second matter that Senator MacGibbon referred to was the application of social security fringe benefit provisions to home loans assistance. The extent of the applicability of the recent amendments to the Social Security Act to housing loans made under the defence homes loans assistance scheme, is still under investigation. Clearly, there is a separate issue from the provision in this bill which, as Senator MacGibbon has acknowledged, extends home loans assistance benefits in recognition of overseas service by Defence Force members.

The third matter raised by Senator MacGibbon was his suggestion that superannuation penalties on voluntary retirement were being used to force separations from the defence forces. The government strongly rejects that as the basis of the policy. The Defence Force scheme provides for pensions after 20 years of service, but, to encourage officers to serve beyond the 20 years, there is a penalty for those who retire before a specified notional retiring age. Management has no discretion in the matter, so there could be no question of misuse of this provision. The penalty does not, of course, apply to officers who are involuntarily retired. It is noted that there is no provision for notional retiring ages in the military superannuation and benefits scheme which has replaced the defence forces scheme. With that I conclude my remarks.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 28 October, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Departure Tax Amendment Bill 1993 amends the Departure Tax Act 1978 to increase the departure tax from $20 to $25. The bill is due to have effect from 1 January next year. The idea of a departure tax originated from one of the 40 recommendations of the House of Representatives Select Committee on Tourism in 1978 and was first introduced for persons departing Australia by the 1978 act. The decision to increase the departure tax from $20 to $25 was announced in the 1993-94 budget and is expected to boost revenue by $11 million in this financial year and $28 million to $30 million in a full year. The stated purpose of the increase is to offset the additional costs of tourism promotion expenditure which was announced in the budget.

PARA.TAB: It has been mentioned to me by airport operators that the more the government takes in the way of airport charges, such as departure taxes and the like, the less ability those operators have to raise their own funds from incoming and outgoing users of their airports. Because of the current government's insatiable appetite for money, some of the authorities which operate these airports are lacking in funds to improve and maintain their airports. A further concern is that an inequitable proportion of the tourism revenue and consolidated revenue collected from airports is returned to airports.

My colleague in the other place Mr David Jull, the shadow minister for tourism—an excellent one at that—has very skilfully and capably discussed the effects of this bill on the tourism industry and has outlined the major concerns which arise from its implementation. I note also that my Queensland colleagues, Mr Slipper and Mr Braithwaite, have spoken on the bill.

Today I want to talk about the bill but also specifically about the effect of the increased departure tax on the tourism industry in North Queensland. I note in passing that the honourable member for Herbert, Mr Lindsay, has once again shown his complete lack of interest in the many tourism-dependent people in his North Queensland electorate of Herbert by failing to represent them on this bill.

North Queensland is undoubtedly one of the fastest, if not the fastest, growing and most prominent international tourism destinations in Australia. We have hundreds of idyllic and diverse destinations, such as the Great Barrier Reef, the Whitsunday Islands, the lava caves at Undarra, the Chillagoe mines, the volcanic lakes on the Atherton Tableland, the Daintree tropical rainforest, Lawn Hill and Riverslea, not to mention the endless miles of beaches and islands at Mission Beach and Dunk Island south of Innisfail—all in the electorate of Kennedy. We also have many attractions, such as Townsville's Great Barrier Reef Marine Park World, the scenic railways at Kuranda and Forsyth and the Stockman's Hall of Fame at Longreach. The list of North Queensland's tourism assets goes on and on.

I again mention in passing, Mr Acting Deputy President, a matter I know you personally are concerned about. All those beautiful beaches up my way, and even Ninety Mile Beach and Bells Beach down your way would, if the recommendations in the Resource Assessment Commission's report came into operation, perhaps be fenced off or in some way taxed before people would be allowed to use them.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—There is also a McGauran's Beach in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure it is an idyllic beach. Perhaps that is already fenced off.
—No, it is open to the public.
—Hopefully, the government will not act on that report because it is un-Australian to suggest that Australians' access to the beaches should in any way be restricted.

PARA.TAB: I want to mention some facts which indicate the growth of tourism in the Cairns region. Total international visitor numbers to Cairns have climbed from 394,000 in 1991 to 508,000 in 1992. That is almost a 30 per cent increase in one year. In 1982 the number of international passengers using the Cairns airport was a mere 15,000; the number is now 1.2 million. The average annual growth over the last decade of international visitors to Cairns has been 23 per cent and Cairns airport now sees 178 international flight movements per week. Some 21 per cent of all international visitors to Australia now visit the Cairns region and Cairns now sees more holiday purpose visitors than the whole of Victoria. Cairns has a large share of the Asian market, with one in four Japanese who come to Australia actually visiting Cairns. Only a couple of weeks ago the prominent Asian airline Cathay Pacific commenced two flights per week between Cairns and Hong Kong.

Because of the growth in the Cairns tourism industry, it has been necessary to treat it with extreme delicacy when implementing any policy such as this policy on departure tax. It is well known that the Labor government is anything but delicate, regularly implementing policies which show no foresight and which often have no economic foundation. One only has to look at Labor's recent proposal for a fringe benefits tax on business accommodation and travel, which would have ruined the tourism industry, to see that this government has no ability when it comes to policy making. Fortunately, the FBT on business accommodation and travel, which would have had such disastrous effects on the tourism, travel and convention industry, has been shelved for the moment and I hope it stays shelved. The tourism industry well remembers that proposal. It was brought in without any thought by this government and could have cost anywhere between 10,000 and 18,000 jobs.

We can understand why it is necessary to be very careful in accepting any bill which this government proposes. I find some relief, however, in the fact that the Departure Tax Amendment Bill extends a policy which was carefully thought through and researched by a responsible Liberal government in 1978.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thanks for pointing it out to us!

—It was well thought through and carefully done in those days. We support this bill, as the parliamentary secretary knows. We want him to know that we are very carefully watching what the government does with the money and watching that it does not increase it to an outrageous figure. We also want the government to consider other things that could be done with the money—perhaps assisting some of the non-government airport operators.

PARA.TAB: The North Queensland tourism industry will be making a significant contribution to the revenue collected from this departure tax. Tourists who pass through Cairns already have to budget for added costs imposed by operators because of the remoteness of their operations. They also have to budget for innumerable taxes which are facing the tourism industry across Australia already. These include: sales tax, which has just been increased by this government; fuel tax, which impacts very heavily on the tourism industry—that has just been increased by this government; the wine excise, again a tax that falls more heavily on the tourism industry than most, and which has just been put up again; and so on. My colleague Mr Jull stated in the House of Representatives that the tourism industry contributed some $7 billion to the public purse last year.

But, most importantly, tourists who visit Cairns have to budget for paying taxes which are specific to North Queensland. Most notably, they have to budget for up to $7 extra per reef visit as a result of the recently imposed reef tax. There are suggestions that private boat owners might have to be taxed if they go anywhere near the reef. Visitors to Cairns have to pay specific taxes if they want to go into the Daintree area or travel on the Kuranda scenic railway.

It is evident that this government treats the tourism industry simply as a milch cow that it can milk whenever it runs short of money. Of course, it is always running short of money because it simply cannot manage the economy. It has little idea of how to balance budgets and it shows no enthusiasm for trying to expand the economy. It does not seem to matter to this government that every tax it imposes on the tourism industry lessens our ability to compete with the Pacific and Asian regions for European and American tourists.

The tourism industry is affected by every tax that is imposed. The budgets of local authorities are also affected by taxes that are imposed by governments. Councils in regional Australia recently had to pay the fuel tax hikes. The federal government seems to forget councils in North Queensland when it comes to the need for infrastructure in the growing tourist regions. The Cook shire, which takes in most of the Cape York area, desperately needs some money to put into basic infrastructure, such as the track to Cape York. But this government seems to ignore reasonable requests for that.

The shire itself is too small to have a financial base to provide all the infrastructure that is needed. Because this facility is used mainly by people who are not ratepayers, the Cook shire is in a difficult predicament; it should provide basic infrastructure in the form of toilets and garbage tips but it does not have the money to do so. I ask that the Cook shire receive sympathetic consideration when it seeks assistance from the federal government for that purpose.

As I said, the departure tax is just one of a number of taxes. One wonders how many more taxes will be imposed on the tourism industry before the tourists start avoiding Australian tourism destinations. Unfortunately, the current government cannot understand that the Australian tourism industry is in competition with the regions that I have mentioned. If the government continues to forget this, we will lose our competitive edge.

I would like to reinforce some of Mr Jull's statements about the methods used to collect the departure tax. The methods being used are both inefficient and old-fashioned. At present, people leaving the country have to line up at cages at international airports to pay their money. One would think that the government could organise a more subtle approach to collecting the tax. It should not be quite so obvious to visitors that they are being taxed.

We could learn from the American system under which international tourists are charged some $30 in departure tax without even being aware of it. The government in America puts the tax onto the airline tickets. In that way, the departure tax is hidden—not that there is any deception—in the cost of the airline ticket. The Americans do not do what we do in Australia—that is, simply flash with neon lights that the government is taxing tourists leaving Australia.

Visitors to the Cairns airport pay a local Cairns airport charge, which is really part of the airport's charge against the aviation companies. The aviation companies pass that on by way of adding to the price of their tickets. That is a much more subtle and better way of doing it. I would have thought that the government might have, at some stage, given some consideration to a more appropriate way of collecting the departure tax. It needs a much more subtle approach. I am sure that if we were to have a closer look at the US system and other overseas systems, we would find better ways of collecting that tax.

I do not want to keep the Senate any longer in relation to this matter. I simply repeat that the Liberal and National parties will not be opposing the increase in the departure tax. We are wary about the extra weight that it is putting onto the tourism industry. We will be watching closely to monitor how the government spends the money. We want to make sure that it does go back into tourism promotion, as the government indicated it would, and not into the general coffers. We will be keeping an eye on those matters, but at this stage we will not be opposing the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an opportune time to enter this debate on the Departure Tax Amendment Bill 1993. An article in today's West Australian carries the headline `Compass blamed for tourism slump'. The article states that the Western Australian Tourist Commission's figures show that there were 252,000 arrivals at Perth domestic airport last financial year compared with 408,000 in 1991-92. The collapse of Compass—I am talking about the first Compass; the second Compass did not come to Western Australia—is blamed for that. However, I put the blame for the collapse of Compass onto the other airlines, which for many years operated under a two-airline agreement. I believe that those airlines caused the collapse of Compass.

PARA.TAB: The Western Australian Tourist Commission found that Western Australia is affected more than any other state because 82 per cent of visitors to Western Australia come by air and only 11 per cent come by road. That big drop in road travel is very understandable in view of the increases in fuel levies that this government makes all the time. The distances and the cost involved mean that fewer people are travelling by road.

The Western Australian Tourist Commission also said that there is a big boom in tourism to Western Australia from South-East Asia. Any new taxes—a departure tax will be paid when visitors leave—that are imposed on tourism will affect this market. Increased tourism from South-East Asia is helping the industry. A lot of tourists come from Malaysia and I hope that the Malaysian incident, caused by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), does not affect this.
I again want to put on the record that I certainly do not blame Compass for the slump; I blame the other two airlines that caused Compass to go into liquidation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that my initial thought on being informed that the opposition was supporting an increase in the departure tax from $20 to $25 was that one could have knocked me over with an airline ticket. It is the first tax that the opposition—certainly in my recent memory—has supported.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased that Senator Ian Macdonald drew to the attention of the Senate that the departure tax originated with the coalition back in 1978 or 1979. We should draw to the attention of the public that this is one of the few far-sighted tax proposals that we have had from the opposition over the last decade or so. I compliment the opposition on its foresight in proposing this tax. In fact, we picked it up, ran with it and further refined it.

A considerable array of issues were raised by Senator Ian Macdonald. He criticised my colleague in the other place Mr Lindsay for not speaking on this matter. We all know the constraints on time that we have, both here and in the House of Representatives. It is simply not possible for every member or every senator to speak on everything that comes before the chambers.

We had an interesting discourse on tourism in North Queensland from Senator Macdonald. There are some very fine places up there, as indeed there are in my home state of Tasmania, but I will not waste the time of the Senate by going through the excellent tourism attractions we have in Tasmania.

I reject the contention of Senator Macdonald that we are proposing to put fences around beaches and charge taxes and access fees to beaches. I was reading the report Senator Macdonald was referring to this morning. The Coastal Zone Inquiry report, which was handed down yesterday, is a series of policy recommendations to government. It is not binding on the government in any way. It is not proposed that we erect gates and fences around beaches of Australia and put toll gates on them.

At times I had to wonder whether Senator Macdonald was supporting the legislation, in view of some of his criticisms, but in fact he made one very pertinent point which in fact contradicts his position on this matter. He highlighted the enormous growth in international visits into and out of Cairns. He is certainly right. There has been enormous growth. The departure tax of $20 has not affected the growth in tourism into and out of Australia in any way. He highlighted one area, Cairns, where in fact the industry is booming.

Senator Macdonald criticised an alleged array of taxes which adversely affect the tourism industry—the fuel tax, the sales tax, the wine excise—and he brought up the matter of a reef tax. I simply point out to him that in the last election the coalition proposed to replace many of these taxes with one great big tax called the GST. There is no doubt that the GST would have been a net additional tax burden on the tourism industry. That is one reason those opposite were not elected at the last election.
Senator Macdonald then went into the realms of local government. How on earth local government is affected by this particular tax I do not know, unless we have a continuous procession—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—It might sound a bit ridiculous to Senator Panizza, but why are these matters raised in a debate on this matter? To return to the departure tax, I agree with Senator Macdonald. It would be a lot more efficient if we did not have gates collecting the tax. I note with interest that Senator Macdonald said that we should be ensuring that tourists are not aware of this tax—in other words, that we should be hiding the tax. That seems to be contrary to the sorts of principles on taxation that the opposition has been advancing for the last decade or so.

PARA.TAB: We have attempted on one occasion to seek the cooperation of the airlines in collecting this tax. Unfortunately, the airlines have refused to collect the tax. It would be preferable, obviously administratively easier and obviously much cheaper than having people at gates in airports collecting the tax. I understand there are alternative methods being examined by a working group of the National Passenger Processing Committee. It is looking at options for collecting the tax in some other, more efficient administrative way.

With that, I conclude my comments and thank the opposition for its support. I say that with a smile, thinking of Senator Macdonald's speech, but I thank him for the opposition's support and thank Senator Panizza also for his contribution to the debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I use this opportunity to say to anyone who might be interested, anyone who might have taken any notice of Senator Sherry's speech—not many people do—that he was obviously doing some other work while I was speaking because he did not listen to anything I said. His responses show that he had no idea about, or interest, I might say, in what I was saying.
—No wonder he is only a parliamentary secretary.

—I do not want to bring those things up, but it is a pity that he does not listen. In relation to the collection method, I point out again to the parliamentary secretary—he might listen this time—that Cairns airport does in fact impose a charge which is collected by the airlines. If the Cairns Port Authority can find a way of doing it, I fail to see why the government cannot, although the government is so inept in most things that I suppose it could get a few lessons from the Cairns Port Authority on how to run an airport. Perhaps it could even get a few lessons on how to run a government. It might be able to tell the government a few things.

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Sherry) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: FINANCIAL CORPORATIONS (TRANSFER OF ASSETS AND LIABILITIES) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 October, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the Financial Corporations (Transfer of Assets and Liabilities) Bill 1993. This bill will facilitate the establishment of branch operations in Australia by ensuring that foreign banks currently operating as authorised bank subsidiaries or money market corporations are not disadvantaged compared with new foreign bank entrants when establishing branch banking operations in Australia. So the purpose really is to facilitate the transfer of assets and liabilities from foreign bank subsidiaries in Australia to the new branch-type operations.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Senate that this is but the first part of perhaps a greater package of bills, some of which may find expression in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), which we hope may be introduced next week into the House of Representatives. I put to the Senate that this is perhaps the sweetener of a larger package. It is the second part, I understand, that is not so attractive to the foreign operators as the first—and very much the pity.

It is also a shame that we did not have the complete package introduced into the parliament at the same time rather than having to look at two or maybe three pieces of legislation to understand the government's full intent in allowing branches of foreign subsidiaries to be established in Australia.

The government has decided to permit the issue of banking authorities to foreign-owned banks where the Reserve Bank of Australia is satisfied that the bank and its home supervisor are of sufficient standing, and where the bank agrees to comply with the Reserve Bank of Australia prudential, superannuation and other arrangements. This measure is in line with the government's commitment to open up the economy. Indeed, it will bring benefits of competition in the domestic banking system and help its international competitiveness. It is a significant liberalisation in the context of trade and financial services negotiation of the Uruguay Round of GATT. A lot of those statements find expression in the One Nation statement.

I will now take the Senate back in history to illustrate the turnaround in the government's approach to foreign banking. In a nutshell, initially, foreign banks were required to set up in Australia as subsidiaries. Now the government will allow foreign branches. We welcome that decision.

In September 1984, as part of the deregulation process, the policy on foreign bank entry was changed. The then Treasurer called for applications from domestic and foreign interests wishing to operate as banks in Australia. In announcing the decision, the then Treasurer indicated that the establishment of new banks would bring substantial benefits to the Australian community through the development of a more innovative, efficient and competitive financial sector.

I remind the Senate that, in 1985-86, 15 foreign banks were authorised under the Banking Act as incorporated subsidiaries. In fact, there were no further authorisations until after the One Nation statement was delivered. The new foreign banks that commenced in Australia had high expectations of their future impact on the Australian market and also of what services they could provide. Unfortunately, by and large, those expectations were not met. The new foreign banks focused their activities primarily on the wholesale or corporate sectors, providing competition in those areas, but few actually established a wide retail banking presence.

I remind the Senate that the Martin report of 1991—the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration—recommended that foreign banks from countries offering Australian banks reciprocal access be permitted to operate in Australia as branches, subject to a series of conditions. This bill, I remind the Senate, largely seeks to implement that recommendation.

The Treasurer's One Nation statement and his 18 June 1993 banking policy statement continue to reflect high hopes for increased competition in the banking industry. Submissions to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration reflect that to date the government has been totally unsuccessful in achieving this goal. Foreign banks have had a limited impact on the Australian market. Few have established a retail banking presence.

One side effect of these new foreign banks establishing subsidiaries in Australia has been the creation of a fear amongst some of the established banks in Australia. They went out to secure their market share at almost any cost. Unfortunately, a few became rather reckless in their lending. At present, shareholders and depositors are paying the price, in terms of reduced returns and, perhaps, higher interest rate charges, as a number of the banks seek to recover their losses through increased charges. I believe that one of the consequences, and certainly a downside, was the Australian banks seeking to maintain their market share and not watching the prudential standards, which resulted in some reckless lending. Of course, that coincided with the downturn in the economy. The two taken together had a deleterious effect on a number of Australian banks.

I turn to the impact of the foreign banking operations, which largely have focused their activity on the wholesale or corporate sectors. There are several reasons for this phenomenon. Firstly, operating as subsidiaries has actually increased the cost of raising funds so that they have been unable to compete on an equal footing with domestic banks. That was one of the downsides to having a subsidiary operation in Australia. The second reason was the high barriers to competition. The third was the cost of satisfying accounting and reporting requirements of the parent bank and such things as reports for Australian regulatory authorities.

According to the Martin report, the committee considered the benefits of allowing foreign banks to operate as branches to be increasing competition in the Australian banking industry and bringing Australia into line with the practice of the major world and regional financial centres to indicate that Australia is willing to participate openly and freely in the worldwide financial system. However, despite the government's optimism, I believe it is extremely unlikely that the foreign banks will rush to set up branches in Australia. That has been indicated by the phone calls I have received today.

Despite the go-ahead 15 months ago, foreign branches—with the exception of three: the United Overseas Bank and the Overseas Union Bank, both based in Singapore, and the recent move by the State Street Bank and Trust of the United States—have refused to convert subsidiaries to more powerful branches. The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) has said that the business of the State Street Bank and Trust of the United States will be limited to the wholesale banking business. Banking specialists have said that the changes offered by the government offer no incentive to establish branches and that it will take time for the foreign banks to work through the arithmetic before they can take a more positive view.

One of the major explanations for this phenomenon is the withholding tax on interest payable on funds borrowed from head offices. Mr Brett Crowley, a partner of Ernst and Young, has publicly stated that while withholding tax continues no lending will occur as the foreign branches will be paying out more than they could recover. State and Commonwealth government fees, taxes and charges are a problem. Also, there is an inability to transfer certain past losses to branches for tax purposes, depending on the type of arrangements. I will go into that later.

While this bill moves some way in the right direction, it is clearly not giving enough incentive. Changes the bill is making include that the withholding tax payable on interest on intrabank borrowings will be halved but kept at 10 per cent for any borrowings by foreign branches. While interest withholding tax is a wonderful revenue earner, bringing up to $600 million a year in tax revenue, its detrimental impact on a number of foreign branches taking up the offer to establish branches in Australia is patently obvious.

A subsidiary that has widely distributed debentures can obtain an exemption from interest withholding tax. The government is concerned that there would be a leakage of tax revenue if a general exemption were to be granted. While the government is prepared to allow an existing exemption held by a subsidiary to be transferred to the new branch as part of the reconstruction from the subsidiary to the branch, it will only allow a limited concession of 50 per cent of interest withholding tax liability for future transactions. So it can be rolled over but the refinancing does not attract the same exemption. That is the problem.

The transfer of the existing exemption is covered by clause 23 of the bill. The concessional rate of duty of 50 per cent of interest withholding tax for foreign branches will be covered in subsequent legislation, which I believe could be the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.4). It is a pity that we could not have the other part of the legislation when debating the merits of this bill. I understand that foreign branches have lobbied to have the policy changed so that the subsidiaries can take advantage of section 128F of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which allows the raising of funds offshore without the payment of interest withholding tax. The foreign branches argue that the relaxation of the rule will actually boost competition.

Another change is the waiving of the payment of Commonwealth and state fees and charges on the transfer of assets and liabilities from the Australian subsidiary of a foreign bank in existence prior to 18 June 1993 to a new Australian bank or to a new authorised bank subsidiary. Under the government's policy, a foreign bank that gained an authority from the Reserve Bank of Australia to operate as a branch would be obliged to conduct the bulk of its international intermediation through a bank. I put it to the Senate that there are some problems in terms of the sorts of subsidiaries that actually can transfer from subsidiary status to branch status. The bill talks about subsidiaries and also money market corporations, but this bill does not provide any definitions.

We have the difficulty that some existing structures in this area may well not qualify. Could the minister tell me whether property finance group subsidiaries, for example, would qualify in terms of being able to convert to a branch under the arrangements of this bill? There is also the question—the alarm bells have been rung—of the allocation of certain head office expenses to the branches. We have already seen difficulties in the life assurance area where the Taxation Office imposes arbitrary allocation formulae. Even more contentious is the fact that the government is considering what is termed a `notional capital concept' whereby an arbitrary amount will be allocated in terms of the head office expenses for the Australian operations.

So the losses, the nature of the subsidiaries, section 128F of the act, the interest withholding tax, the problems that are likely to be raised in tax bill No. 4—or subsequent bills—will certainly take off some of the initial gloss or the attraction of this bill. Nevertheless, we welcome it as it is one step forward to opening up the Australian economy, to making the system more competitive and perhaps to providing lower cost financial products to Australian consumers.
