TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table a correction to the explanatory memorandum to the Financial Corporations (Transfer of Assets and Liabilities) Bill 1993.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Income Tax Returns: Tax File Numbers

TALK.START.PARA: —In today's matters of public interest debate, I raise the matter of the lodging of income tax returns without a tax file number. I refer to a response from the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) to a question on notice and to the minister's response on 27 September 1993.

PARA.TAB: A number of constituents believe that the answer does not truly reflect a correct interpretation of the tax law. There is no law which requires taxpayers to quote their tax file number upon request. There may be penalties in some circumstances; for example, if a taxpayer fails to quote a TFN, there is a deduction of 48.4 per cent tax at source on salaries, wages, investment incomes and unfranked dividends. When the return is lodged, however, those taxpayers can claim the total tax deducted and, in most cases, the amount withheld would be greater than their liability so they would receive a refund. The real penalty for those taxpayers is that they are denied the use of their funds because of the additional tax that they had paid until their assessment and refund was issued.

The tax office maintains that under regulations 15 and 34 it has the power to require taxpayers to complete the official return form, and that return form does not have to be accepted until it is signed and completed. The real position is that the tax office has no authority to require taxpayers to quote their tax file numbers or to require them to apply for a tax file number. The problem is that the tax office system needs a tax file number to identify taxpayers and to say that, from a practical point of view, it is in the interests of all taxpayers to have and to quote a tax file number.

I draw the Senate's attention to the support that comes, for example, from the Australian Taxpayers Association which supports good law—but only if the methods are within the law. It believes that under the current laws it is not compulsory to apply for or to have a tax file number. Until this happens, I remind the Senate, all taxpayers—which includes the tax office—must abide by the law. The Privacy Act was intended to protect taxpayers' rights, and no law requires a taxpayer at the moment to have a tax file number. The only sanction provided is to deduct tax at the high rate, which is normally the case when a tax file number is not quoted.

At the end of the day, however, no taxpayers pay a higher amount of tax on their assessment whether or not they have supplied their tax file number. They may initially, but not after assessment. In other words, the penalty imposed on taxpayers for not having or quoting a tax file number is the loss of purchasing power for a limited period of time until their income tax assessment is issued by the tax office. At that point, all taxpayers are treated, and should be treated, the same.

I remind the Senate that a similar issue arose with tax agents who were required by the Tax Agents Board to supply their tax file numbers. On that occasion, the tax office also had to back down. I presume that, in relation to the requests and the tax office's refusal to process returns when people do not have a tax file number, that is not the law at the present time. I take this opportunity in the Senate to remind the tax office of that fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly about a report that was made to the human rights subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. In the first part of a submission made by Justice Evatt, some comments were made on a speech that I gave to the Senate on 26 October which looked at, among other things, the activities of UN human rights committees. I welcome the contribution that Justice Evatt has made to this debate. I think it is an important debate. In that context, I wish to make a few remarks on the observations that Justice Evatt made.

PARA.TAB: My complaints about the government's activities in relation to UN conventions and UN human rights committees are these: in the first place, the government has clearly overturned the philosophy of the Australia Act in allowing complaints to go to UN committees. Among other things, the Australia Act severed appeals to the Privy Council. At that stage, it was decided, with the agreement of the opposition parties, that the Australian legal system should be self-contained.

Just five years later, the government has opened up appeals to three UN human rights committees. As a consequence, I believe that it has overturned the philosophy of the Australia Act. As a person who treasures the sovereignty of our nation, I believe that the government has compromised that sovereignty by this action. Nonetheless, those who believe that UN committees should have the right to involve themselves in Australia's domestic activities have a responsibility to make sure that these UN human rights committees are appropriately structured and meet the test of judicial independence and process that we would want for bodies like these.

Justice Evatt made three points about my remarks to the Senate on 26 October. Rather surprisingly, her first point was that she felt my comment about Australia's independence being undermined by allowing UN committees dealing with human rights to involve themselves in Australia's domestic activities was not correct. I am surprised that Justice Evatt runs this line. Even Senator Schacht, who is a great advocate of UN conventions and a strong supporter of allowing UN committees to involve themselves in Australia's domestic activities, concedes that this will undoubtedly undermine the independence and sovereignty of the nation.
I will quote from a report which Senator Schacht presented to this chamber. Among other things, it said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there has been a tendency for the United Nations to limit national sovereignty. This evolution, therefore, increasingly demands a reconsideration of the principle of national sovereignty. United Nations conventions, now covering a wide range of activities, inevitably change the character of domestic institutions, affect domestic legislation and extend accountability beyond the usual domestic constituency.

I do not often agree with Senator Schacht, but I believe that that report, which was presented to the Senate by the human rights subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade summed up the situation quite correctly. I am surprised that Justice Evatt has decided to run the line that in some way Australia's independence is not compromised by our allowing UN committees to involve themselves in our activities.

PARA.TAB: There are some real dilemmas for those who support the internationalism of Senator Gareth Evans and the Labor Party. On the one hand, they are running a campaign against the constitutional monarchy based on the need for Australia to be an independent country. On the other hand, they are opening up Australia's legal system to UN committees. So there is a complete contradiction between those two positions which the Labor Party is running. It is a real problem for it. The republican movement has to make it very clear whether it supports my position and, I hope, your position, Mr Acting Deputy President, that Australia is an independent country and that UN committees have no role in involving themselves in our domestic activities.

There is another problem. Justice Evatt has made the point that many of these treaties can only be put into law through an act of this parliament. That is correct, but it raises another issue which people like Justice Evatt and those who support Australia's enmeshing itself in the UN human rights treaties have to face up to. On the one hand, they say it is very important for us to ratify all these conventions and particular articles and protocols which allow these UN committees to become involved in our domestic activities. On the other hand, they try to argue that this does not have any great effect on the independence and sovereignty of the nation. They really cannot have it both ways. If it is so important, it must surely have an effect. The effect naturally is to bring in both a new plane of law to which Australians can appeal and the activities of UN human rights committees.

Those on the other side who support the enmeshing of Australia in UN human rights treaties say on the one hand that these treaties only become law when they are enacted by the parliament. Then, when the bill comes before the parliament, they say that we have to enact this law or we are in breach of the UN human rights treaty that the law is apparently giving some particular effect to. They complete the circle by saying that we have to sign these treaties and enact them into law because Australia will be seen to be not fulfilling its international obligation it we do not actively support them.

There are real contradictions in the arguments of those who so actively support UN human rights treaties. As an aside, it is interesting that in the Age of today, Alan Atkinson makes the point—I think he is right; it is quite an insight and backs up what I have been saying—that the main task of the republican movement:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . has been to persuade the electorate that the monarchy is a foreign imposition, and that republicanism is an assertion of independence. The opposite is true. The republican movement is one aspect of a broad and deeply laid abdication of independence.
While the author of this article has not touched on certain matters, I believe that he has insight, which I fully endorse.

PARA.TAB: Time is fairly short, so I will have to be brief. Justice Evatt concedes that the UN human rights committees' rulings have an impact on other countries. That is correct; it is a comment that I have made. If they did not have an impact, why on earth would we bother to ratify the appropriate conventions and protocols to allow them to involve themselves in our country? I agree with Justice Evatt on that score.

Her second point concerned the impact of these committees on Australia. She rightly makes the point that this is a relatively new procedure. But I put it to her that the committees' impact not only comes through any legislation which the government may choose to put through. By ratifying the treaties, they give a constitutional head of power. In other words, it has major constitutional impacts.

Our courts, particularly the High Court through its Mabo judgment, are paying attention to the possibility that appeals may go to these human rights committees and therefore judgments are being framed in this manner. A finding by a committee can, in effect, provide a head of power for the government of the day to override state government law. So it is an important and significant act. Justice Evatt, who is a member of the UN human rights committee, should not run away from that.

Justice Evatt's third point generally confirms my views about whether these committees have proper standards of judicial independence. The walking wounded—Senator Collins, Senator Bolkus and Senator Faulkner—have just entered the chamber. Justice Evatt certainly confirms my views about the need for the government to look closely at how these committees operate. She confirms that the appointments are short-term and that in the past members of the UN human rights committees have been under instructions from their own governments; in other words, they have not acted in a fully independent manner. Justice Evatt has confirmed that the hearings of these committees are largely held in private. Of course, an essential feature of our law is that court hearings be public hearings. I believe that is a very important aspect of our legal system.

Essentially, I believe that Justice Evatt has largely confirmed my concerns about many of the tests which I have raised about the functioning of these committees. I very much hope that the government will now look seriously at the whole issue of whether these UN human rights committees are appropriately structured to play any role in Australia's domestic activities. I put it to you, Mr President, that I am opposed to this move. The government has a responsibility to make sure that these committees function properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Last night the minister boasted that he had the numbers in cabinet and caucus to push through his proposed `divide and rule' health package. He also labelled opponents of the package as `recalcitrant'.
—Go on; go on.

—The minister said that last night. Why should this be interpreted as anything other than a very unsubtle, but very public, rebuke of the Prime Minister for his failure to toe the minister's line? If the minister has the support of cabinet and the caucus, why is he so intent on humiliating the Prime Minister in advance of the meeting? If the minister does not carry the day in cabinet, will he resign?

—This is a really good question and I am delighted that Senator Herron has asked it. Having been asked only 12 opposition questions since the election, it is always good to get an extra one. I am delighted.
—We thought you got into enough trouble over the Marshall Islands.

—Senator Campbell should take three deep breaths; we will get to him. I am sure that Senator Herron, being the diligent senator that he is, took the time and the effort to look at the whole speech. I am disappointed that he would choose to quote selectively out of context.

PARA.TAB: I made it abundantly clear—and in fact stated it directly—that I would not go to cabinet with a package which was opposed by the Prime Minister. I used those words last night. I said, `If I can't convince him, I will not go to cabinet with a package to which he is opposed'. The fact that Senator Herron would suggest that this is in some way a slur or a slight on the Prime Minister is, to say the least, extraordinary.

I went out of my way to say that I would not do that. I pointed out that the one part of my package with which he is not happy has been referred to a working party. If I cannot convince the Prime Minister, some people in my own caucus—who are sitting not too far away from me now—and the ACTU, then I will not proceed with that part of the package. That is one of three parts. I will certainly proceed with the other parts.
I did work in the word `recalcitrant' last night. I thought it had to come in; it seemed like the thing to do at the time. I got `recalcitrant' in and I do not apologise for using the word.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you regret it?

—As a matter of fact, I do not regret the choice of the word `recalcitrant'. Of course, I would not have been referring to Senator Bolkus, because he would not be recalcitrant. I am a bit worried about some of his mates, but not him. I did use the word `recalcitrant'. I stand by it, as I stand by my speech last night.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I distinctly remember Senator Richardson boasting in Launceston that he was a world expert in power—they are his words—when he tried to threaten the insurance organisations. What is wrong with Senator Richardson? Senator Richardson's boast of being a world expert in power is incompatible with his backdown before the Prime Minister.

—Au contraire, Senator Herron. As a matter of fact, if one knows a bit about power, one works out one thing. Senator Herron is not an expert on it so I probably should tell him. One works out that, if one cannot win, one backs off.
—Gutless.

—Yes, that is me all the way; that is my reputation. I would have thought it pretty silly of me to take on the Prime Minister in cabinet and I will not, because people such as Senator Herron might misinterpret my actions.

PARA.TAB: I suspect they might even suggest I have another agenda. I would never want them to have the opportunity of saying that, so they will not get it. Unlike Senator Bishop and all those opposite who are trying to undermine their leader, we are not and we will not.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Bolkus. I refer the minister to previous announcements he has made that visitors from the former Yugoslavia and from Sri Lanka have had their stay extended until January 1994 and ask why arrangements have been made for people from these countries after that date.

—As Senator Devereux mentioned in his question, visitors and other temporary entrants from both Sri Lanka and the former Yugoslavia are nearing the expiry of their temporary entry permits. In June this year, I announced that visitors from both those countries would be able to extend their stay until 31 January 1994. This measure of course recognised, in the case of visitors from Sri Lanka, that while the situation and the standard of human rights in Sri Lanka were continuing to improve the situation was still sufficiently uncertain to warrant the offer of a further extension of stay. Similarly, it was clearly difficult, if not impossible, for visitors from the former Yugoslavia to return to their home countries while fighting there continued.

PARA.TAB: In the interim, Australia has monitored the situation in both countries, and I have decided that visitors from both Sri Lanka and the former Yugoslavia should be offered a further extension of stay until 30 June 1994. Conditions are still improving in Sri Lanka. However, I hold some concern that there is continuing conflict there and that its effects are felt by the civilian population. The provision for an extended stay for people from former Yugoslavia has been available since the conflict there became entrenched. It would be unreasonable to expect people to return to their home countries while the fighting continues.

The further extension applies to citizens from both countries who held a temporary entry permit at any time on or after 31 December 1991. The extension I am announcing today will ensure that those who are involved are not required to return while conflict persists.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Evans, the Minister representing the Prime Minister, and it follows that from Senator Herron. I refer to the very public campaign being waged over recent weeks by Senator Richardson in his attempt to drag the Prime Minister screaming and yelling to his health agenda. I ask: is it normal practice for cabinet ministers not only to foreshadow their proposals but also to boast that they have the numbers and then make a very veiled threat to the Prime Minister that he ought to see sweet reason? Could the minister please explain why this blatant campaign by the Prime Minister's former ally should not be regarded as a gross breach of cabinet practice which more correctly could be described as sweet treason?

—What is normal practice in this country under this government is for cabinet ministers as competent as Senator Richardson to engage constantly in lively contributions to public debate on significant policy issues that need significant public discussion, party discussion and community and parliamentary discussion in the hope thereby of getting policy improvements that may be necessary to deal with particular emerging social problems.

PARA.TAB: We have a tradition in our party—in our government—of robust public debate, of exchange, of a willingness to engage in discussion of new ideas. In all of this there is a spectacular contrast with the turgid, dinosaur-like, leaden footed, thick headed, ideologically obtuse fashion in which those opposite go about this same process. They have one new policy idea a decade. When they get it wrong, they are devoid of any new ideas for another decade—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. I wonder if Senator Boutros Boutros-Biggles could finally return to the question and answer the question or be sat down.
—Order! Resume your seat. There is no point of order. The next time you raise a point of order, use the proper names.
—Senator Kemp has succeeded in throwing me off my stroke.
—I suggest that the minister come back to the original question.

—The original question, I think, was pretty well answered by me when I said that what Senator Richardson was up to was nothing more than a significant, useful, intelligent, lively contribution to the public debate in this country, something that those opposite are simply manifestly incapable of, and they are jealous.

—Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of media statements by the South Australian Leader of the Opposition, Mr Dean Brown, in Adelaide yesterday that Australian National had secured a very large financial institution as a $300 million shareholder in the proposed Alice Springs to Darwin railway line and that this was a major step forward for the project?
—Is this to save the South Australian Government?

—Is the minister also aware of statements by Mr Brown that the proposed Alice Springs to Darwin railway line is economically viable? Can the minister advise the Senate if these statements are correct?

—I can assure the opposition that this question has got nothing to do with saving anybody. Over the last 16 years I have become closely acquainted with extraordinary statements made by politicians, which are trotted out with every election campaign, regarding the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link. As a long-time supporter of this project, I have to say that I made the point last time that one of the great problems which this proposal lacks is credibility. One of the reasons that it lacks credibility is the over-the-top statements made by politicians. But nothing will match the whopper that was delivered by the Leader of the Opposition in South Australia yesterday. It was an over-the-top falsehood. It was a totally untrue statement with no foundation at all.

PARA.TAB: Coming from a politician—with the South Australian State Bank matter a topical issue in the election—who promises the people of South Australia some responsibility in terms of the allocation of their finances, to publicly commit $100 million of South Australian taxpayers' money to a project on the basis that someone has secured a company which will become a major shareholder in this project, a company which does not exist, is the height of irresponsibility, even though it is only three days before polling day.

I read the transcript of the interview yesterday with total disbelief. Mr Dean Brown made the statement that Australian National had secured a major financial institution as the major private shareholder in a proposed joint government-private industry consortium. The position that the coalition, through Dr Hewson, and the government have adopted on this project is precisely the same—that is, that attention will be given to this project and assistance will be considered when genuine private institutional support for the project can be found. So I was intensely interested in this claim by Mr Brown that he would advance $100 million of his state's money to the project on the basis of this company.

I then found out to my astonishment that what he was referring to was a proposal that has been put up by Australian National. No such company exists. There is no large financial institution that wants to become a shareholder in this consortium. I am very familiar with the proposal that has been put up by AN.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are familiar with everything!

—Well, I am the minister responsible for Australian National and I have a copy of the proposal. The company referred to is the Westpac bank. What Westpac is interested in doing—and fair enough for it—is becoming a financial adviser to any interested consortium that wants to put money into the project. Of course, as I have consistently said over the years in respect of this project, it is about time the project got someone who was interested in putting something into it rather than companies that are simply interested in taking something out. I reiterate that the claim made by the South Australian Leader of the Opposition yesterday is totally false: no such company exists.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the shadow Treasurer, Mr Downer, made the same claim five days before the last federal election. He said that he had found a consortium of bankers who were interested in the project. They were never identified by Mr Downer, and, of course, they have never appeared to this day. Five days before the last election, a newspaper headline read, `Bankers found for rail link by Mr Downer'. I have to say that Mr Brown has been two days later in making this claim than Mr Downer was last time, but the claim is equally fallacious.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the release of documents by US energy secretary Hazel O'Leary, which reveal that the US conducted more than 250 secret nuclear tests over the past 50 years, including 48 in the Pacific region. I ask: was the Australian government made aware of any of these secret tests by the United States, or did it detect any of them using its own monitoring systems? Where were the secret Pacific tests conducted and what was the size range of the tests? Will the government acquire all the documents released by secretary O'Leary and table them in the Senate along with any Australian documents on these tests?

—Until the announcement about the undisclosed tests was made, as Senator Bourne said, by US energy secretary O'Leary yesterday, the Australian government was not aware that such a significant undisclosed testing program had been conducted. It now appears that almost one in five tests was not publicly disclosed. Our understanding was that it was general practice for the US to announce its tests. We regarded that, at the time, as a welcome practice which was not followed by other nuclear weapon states with independent testing programs. While, to say the least, we are more than a little disappointed and disconcerted that such a large number of tests apparently were conducted, and conducted unnoticed, we now welcome the US disclosure of this information. This at least now heralds a new era of openness about nuclear testing and about nuclear weapons programs in the US generally, which is, in our view, obviously a very positive development.

PARA.TAB: Analysis of details of the earlier tests could contribute to refining verification techniques for a comprehensive test ban treaty. That is a high priority currently for the government. We have long supported measures to promote transparency in nuclear testing programs. Such transparency facilitates monitoring and lays the foundation for effective verification of a comprehensive test ban treaty. At the UN General Assembly in 1986, we took the lead in establishing a UN register for the notification of nuclear tests.

As to further details about the location of tests in the Pacific, the Australian seismic array, which monitors such underground tests, has detected no tests other than those conducted by France in French Polynesia. It is highly unlikely that any tests would have been conducted recently in the South Pacific. The Treaty of Rarotonga, which entered into force in 1986, banned such testing and successive US administrations have said on many occasions that none of their activities in the region are inconsistent with the provisions of that treaty. I think it is reasonable to take them on face value—at least to that extent.

As to the question of documentation, I have now instructed the embassy in Washington to raise these various questions with relevant officials and to provide the Australian government with further details. I understand that the official report by the US department of energy is going to be released in Washington tomorrow, Friday 10 December. I will table this and other relevant US documents when they become available. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade will also provide for the tabling of other relevant documentation that we prove able to obtain on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the minister seen recent statements issued by the Australian section of the International Commission of Jurists calling upon the minister to take positive action to facilitate peace talks in relation to the conflict on Bougainville? If the minister is aware of such statements, what action has the government taken to bring about such talks and to resolve the situation on Bougainville?

—I am aware of the comments made by the Australian section of the ICJ. As senators will perhaps recall, the government has had on the table a longstanding offer now to facilitate peace talks among Bougainvillian leaders, provided all parties to the conflict agreed that that offer is acceptable and want to take advantage of it. At last week's ministerial forum meeting at Mt Hagen, I reiterated that position. I made clear our willingness to make available our good offices and our resources to facilitate such talks if it were thought to be helpful by all relevant parties. At the same time, I re-emphasised Australia's quite strongly held view that Bougainville's problems cannot be solved by purely military means and that there is a need for the Papua New Guinea government to take positive steps to bring the various groups involved in the conflict together for talks.

PARA.TAB: I should perhaps say in this context that human rights matters were also an important topic for discussion at that ministerial forum. I again reminded PNG ministers of Australia's concern about the human rights aspects of the Bougainville conflict. I encouraged the PNG government to provide full responses to particular allegations of human rights abuses, in particular those relating to the cases of Ken Savia and Brother Leak.

Papua New Guinea ministers provided assurances of the importance that PNG attaches to the protection of human rights and to the proper investigation of claims of human rights abuses. They undertook to provide further information on the specific cases which had previously been raised with the PNG government. That response was sincerely expressed and I am hopeful that it will produce a little more detail than we have been able to obtain so far. One of the basic problems is that the situation on Bougainville is still not such as to make possible the easy gathering of evidence about a number of these matters.

The significant outcome of the ministerial forum, which should be of particular interest, I hope, to honourable senators, even if those opposite are not in the slightest bit interested, was the suggestion raised at the forum that an Australian parliamentary delegation visit Bougainville at a mutually agreed time. Papua New Guinea ministers agreed that that idea had considerable merit. I now propose to take this matter up with the Presiding Officers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the current industrial campaign being pursued by the Communications Workers Union in an attempt to overturn the recent cabinet decision in relation to Australia Post. Will the government give a firm undertaking that it will not move from its publicly announced position? Is it not a fact that the ban on parliamentarians' mail will not affect the ability of parliamentarians to communicate with others, as they have long since discovered the virtues of telephones and fax machines, and that the real victims of the campaign will be those ordinary Australians who rely on members of parliament for help, particularly against the constant outrages of the federal government? Why is this not a contempt of the parliament? Does it not constitute a graphic illustration of the urgent need for competition? If the campaign continues, will the government give consideration to bringing forward the starting date for the commencement of alternative mail services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is both unfortunate and regrettable that the Communications Workers Union is taking this action. I can in fact confirm what Senator Alston has said from a contact that was made to me this morning from my office in Darwin. Members of parliament are well resourced and, in terms of getting on with their own internal business, have adequate facilities—in fact more than adequate facilities—to act as an alternative to the normal post service: telephones obviously, but, more particularly, as Senator Alston has correctly said, fax machines and the computer generated electronic mail.

PARA.TAB: Politicians have, as Senator Alston has correctly said—I cannot believe this nonsense I am getting from his colleagues because I am agreeing with him—ample opportunity to conduct their own urgent business with their offices in both Canberra and Darwin or their electorates. Of course, the problem is that the constituents are affected, as Senator Alston has correctly said.

This morning, for example, I was told by the manager of my Darwin office that they have had two days completely mail free. The person on my staff who preoccupies herself almost entirely with immigration issues has had very little to do for the last two days. She said to me this morning, `All we are waiting for now is for someone to pull the plug on the telephones and then we can slip right into the Christmas holidays'.

Senator Alston is correct. The action is misguided and the people who are being directly affected by it are those constituents of members of parliament who do not have access to fax machines or electronic mail. The matter is being pursued in the proper forum. Australia Post is pursuing action through the Industrial Relations Commission to get an early resolution. The dispute has been notified to the Industrial Relations Commission and a hearing has been set for today.

But I think it is a bit cheeky for Senator Alston to ask this question because, on the question of Australia Post and the concerns that the communication workers have, he rightly was given the accolade last week for the quote of the week—and it is a beauty—when he was talking, in his usual cavalier fashion, about the rights of workers. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: It never ceases to amaze me how talk of 10,000 job losses and a $600 million loss of revenue can frighten the pants off normally rational decision-makers.

They are the words of the alternative minister for communications sitting opposite. That quote was rightly given the accolade of quote of the week. I hope that the loss of 10,000 job and $600 million in revenue will continue to frighten the pants off rational decision makers. The facts are that, as has been said publicly by the Minister for Communications, the sensible proposals that have been advanced by the government will not result in this level of job losses. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am grateful to the minister for confirming the obvious. I am sorry his concentration span did not extend to the bottom two-thirds of the question. I refer to the resolution of the Senate which states:

PARA.TAB: A person shall not improperly interfere with the free . . . performance by a Senator of the Senator's duties as a Senator.

QUESTION.PARA: I ask, therefore: why is the current action not a contempt of the parliament? Will the minister look at bringing forward the start-up date? In other words, why will the minister not do something instead of leaving it to the industrial relations club to work out a deal against the public interest?

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable senator well knows, the question is entirely out of order. I answered that part of the question which is relevant to my responsibilities to this chamber. I indicate again to Senator Alston that the matter has been notified to the industrial commission and a hearing has been sought today. As to whether the union action constitutes a contempt of the parliament, I suggest that Senator Alston direct his question to the responsible person in this chamber. The responsible person in this chamber is the President.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health. What evidence is available to confirm that the hoarding of prescription medicines is continuing to be a problem? Will the new pharmaceutical benefits scheme safety net arrangements prevent people from getting more prescription medications than they need?

—I thank Senator Murphy for his continuing interest in the problem. There is in fact plenty of evidence to suggest that hoarding of medicines is continuing. One does not have to look too far to find it. In 1992, as an example, approximately six million prescriptions were dispensed in February compared with 17.5 million in December. Dispensing data indicates that the average number of prescription drugs dispensed for each person who has reached the safety net threshold increases from 12 a month in the middle of the year to 20 at the end.

PARA.TAB: Pharmacists, doctors and consumer groups alike are all concerned about the problem and its dimensions. It is a question of how it should be dealt with. The area of the scheme most rapidly increasing is that for non-cardholders because the general patients safety net increased by over 100 per cent in 1992-93. Obviously, we cannot allow that to continue. Consequently, a couple of measures are planned to address it.

Firstly, the Health Insurance Commission will be running an education campaign to make people aware of the dangers of the practice. That education campaign has the support of the peak professional bodies and the consumer bodies, including the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association. More importantly, from 1 January 1994, as I am sure Senator Herron is aware, there will be a single safety net threshold of $400 for general patients. Once that threshold has been reached, there will be a charge of $2.60 for further approved prescriptions for the rest of the year. Concession cardholders still remain eligible for free pharmaceuticals when they reach their safety net, so we are talking about those people who do not have that concession. The Health Insurance Commission will introduce compliance activities and will administer them, I hope, in such a way as to protect those people who have privacy concerns about this issue.

The compliance activity function will rely on drug utilisation data obtained by the Health Insurance Commission when it is processing payment claims from pharmacists. It will be used to identify aberrant behaviour and to investigate where appropriate. It will not involve investigation of medical records, except for the use of highly specialised drugs which come under the section 100 arrangements in public hospitals. Once the new safety net takes effect, the education campaign gets under way and the compliance measures are introduced by the Health Insurance Commission, we can start to make a real dent in what Senator Murphy has correctly identified as a serious problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. I presume the minister has read the front page of today's Australian Financial Review which relates to the $360 million credit card chaos which is to be revealed in next week's Auditor-General's report. I do not need to remind the minister of the dismissal of two housekeepers from the Lodge recently for their alleged failure to follow financial directions for the use of a single credit card with a $200 limit. Is it not a fact that holders of government credit cards are not allowed to withdraw cash using their cards and that almost $550,000 has been withdrawn, at a time when hundreds of thousands of Australians are struggling just to pay off their own credit cards at Christmas time? When is someone in the government going to take responsibility for the continuing financial mismanagement in light of this matter, Mrs Kelly's sports rorts affair and Mr Keating's lavish Lodge decorating spree?

—I have not read the front page of the Australian Financial Review but I know what Senator Campbell is referring to. I will not pursue him down the road of the irrelevant side issues he raised subsequently, but I accept that the introduction, use and control of Australian government credit cards is important. As Senator Campbell said, the scheme is under the responsibility of the Department of Finance. It was introduced as part of the 1987 reforms to public administration.

PARA.TAB: The government takes very seriously any proven misuse or inefficient use of public money. The report, at this stage, is a draft report from the Auditor-General. I know that some departments are strongly contesting some of the elements of the draft report. Nevertheless, when the audit report comes down in response to those audit findings, departments will be required to examine those matters and take appropriate action, particularly where there has been any breach of the proper guidelines.

The Audit Act does include stiff penalties for people convicted of misuse of credit cards—a fine not exceeding $20,000 or imprisonment for a period not exceeding five years, or both. It is not something we take lightly. There is wider concern about issues of purchasing which are tied up with this and which are the subject of investigations by House of Representatives committees and internal task forces. Every transaction on the list provided by the audit office is being examined to ensure it was undertaken within Public Service and departmental guidelines, and for official purposes. Any which do not conform to these requirements will be thoroughly investigated and, if necessary, action will be taken against any user.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer and ask: can he direct his attention to the part of my question that claimed that those people are not allowed to use the cards to withdraw cash? I understand that that is one of the financial guidelines. I ask him to inform the Senate about that. I am glad that the department is looking into these cash advances. Would it be possible for the minister to table before the Senate details of the 906 cash advances for the year 1992-93—on average, $600 each—hopefully before the adjournment tonight and include the names of the agencies and the amounts of these advances, agency by agency?

—There is a problem in so far as this is a draft report and some of the facts are in contest. With these reports, the Auditor-General normally provides a draft and people can query the facts in the draft. That then goes back and the Auditor-General releases the final report. When the Auditor-General brings down the final report, if any of these allegations are sustained, the action to be taken will be that which I have outlined. If there is an indication that people are undertaking improper transactions of any sort, I will be happy to look into what further information can be provided to the Senate.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Does the minister accept as fact the claim made by many eminent biologists, such as emeritus Professor Charles Birch and eminent economists with the World Bank such as Professor Herman Daly, that 40 per cent of all photosynthetic activity—that is, the energy on which all life depends—is now being used either directly or indirectly by human beings? If not, what figure does the minister accept and what is the basis of his figure? How does he reconcile this large fraction being used by one species with the continual push by government for more growth, growth, growth, both of population and in per capita consumption? Does not the fundamental incompatibility between the inevitable constraints of biology and the basis of most government policy mean that it is time for government to re-emphasise its commitment to sustainability and to make this the basis on which it derives its economic and all other policies?

—Senator Coulter had the courtesy to let Mrs Kelly and me know that he was going to ask this question. However, while we respect the eminence of the gentlemen Senator Coulter refers to and we certainly recognise the fundamental role of photosynthesis in supporting life on this planet, we are certainly in no position to accept or refute the figures that Senator Coulter quotes about human and photosynthetic activity. In fact, Senator Coulter may well have asked that question asked by all the readers of The Hitch-hikers Guide to the Galaxy, to which the answer, as many honourable senators will know, is 42.

PARA.TAB: After hearing the question and giving it some further reflection this afternoon, it seems to me the answer could be that we might ask Senator Coulter and honourable senators opposite to help out with this problem by not breathing for the next week. I suspect it would certainly help the government with the numbers in the Senate on a few issues.

Of course, the government's sustainable ecological policies have been announced already. This government has a long history of supporting and promoting ecologically sustainable development, and that will continue. However, in view of Senator Coulter's interest in this particular question and his quoting of scientific percentages and overseas experts, Mrs Kelly and I indicate that we will seek further information and report back to the chamber. While we wait for that information we will see whether anybody on the other side stops breathing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. In light of the Auditor-General's report, given such prominence by my colleague Mr Peter Costello, that grants made through the community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program—

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

One could imagine the leaflets are being prepared tonight in her office to be letter boxed all around the electorate, that this carpetbagger from outside the electorate is actually showing interest in the electorate.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Surely this minister should not be allowed to live up to his name of `Cheap Schacht' by talking about something that is utterly irrelevant. Would you please direct him to return to the question?
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Schacht, answer the question.

—The question asked was about the Mackellar electorate. I think Senator Bishop should declare her interest in the Mackellar electorate. Everyone else knows about it. It is quite interesting that, in asking this question about the Cremorne rugby club, she clearly indicates—

—Cromer rugby club. I did not hear the word; there were so many interjections when she asked the question. It is with some incredulity that we heard the question. Opposition senators cannot blame us for laughing because we are laughing about Senator Bishop's prospects of becoming leader of the Liberal Party via Mackellar. TALK.START.PARA: —Give Peter Reith a go, too. He is undermining Dr Hewson, too.

—My colleagues have drawn attention to the fact—
