—I am answering the question. I notice that Mr Reith has now joined the leadership struggle here in the Senate with Senator Bishop. But I will treat that last small part of Senator Bishop's question seriously. I will refer the particular case to Mrs Kelly and come back with the information. I understand that we are not sitting tomorrow. I would like to be able to give the information to the Senate next Monday or Tuesday when we know the result of Mackellar, and I can further comment.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Even for Senator Schacht that is pathetic. If I might say, when the minister is trying to find an answer, would he kindly justify—in the light of having denied the Cromer Rugby League Football Club its grant—why the marginal Labor seat of Richmond received 11 grants totalling in excess of $160,000 while not one cent was found for the electorate of Mackellar for an amenities block to be used by children and others instead of having to cross a busy and dangerous road to use an adjoining petrol station's toilet facilities?
—Tell us about the subdivision.
—The question—
—Tell us the cost of a home in the subdivision.
—Order!
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. It is just impossible for someone on our side to get a question out.
—She just got one out. I heard every word.

—And it is impossible for anyone in the place to hear it also. Could I ask you, respectfully, Mr President, to tell this frontbench over here to shut up during questions so that everyone can hear them.

—Order! In reply to the point of order, there have been too many interjections from people on my right today. I would also like to point out that Senator Alston and Senator Macdonald constantly interject during question time. I am asking all honourable senators to cease interjections.

—The crux of the supplementary question is this: will Senator Schacht kindly supply the Senate with answers as to why the marginal Labor seat of Richmond got 11 grants totalling in excess of $160,000, and yet the claim by the Cromer Junior Football Club was denied any funding at all, despite the fact that Mrs Kelly said that it met the funding criteria?

—Mr President, before you made a ruling, I noticed that, at the end of her question, Senator Bishop was talking about toilet blocks in the electorate of Mackellar. It must, I think, subconsciously reflect the level of the Liberal preselection campaign in Mackellar.

—On a point of order, Mr President: this is a serious question. Senator Schacht's earlier attempt was pathetic. He did not bother to listen to what the grant was for for the Cromer Junior Football Club. He is not interested; he thinks it is a joke. I want to know, and the rest of Australia wants to know, why it is acceptable for Mrs Kelly to hand out taxpayers' money to buy votes and yet not meet a legitimate and approved grant that was asked for for junior footballers?
—In reply to the point of order, I think you have made your point.

—As I said, I will refer the matter to Mrs Kelly. All I can say is that we will come back with this information. I look forward to giving it to Senator Bishop next Monday, Tuesday or Wednesday whether she is a winner, a loser or has drawn the preselection ballot in Mackellar. It will give us another chance to make some comments.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I preface my question by indicating that some honourable senators are aware of my longstanding interest in the transfer of Australians who are imprisoned overseas. I ask the minister: can he advise what progress, if any, was made at the latest meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in relation to Australian participation in the international transfer of prisoners?

—Let me, at the outset, acknowledge the long interest that Senator Colston has had in this particular issue. He is right; there was a recent meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. That meeting was held last month. At that meeting the Attorneys-General all agreed to lend their support for this scheme which Senator Colston has shown an interest in over a number of years.

PARA.TAB: We now have all jurisdictions in support for an international transfer of prisoners scheme. But all is not perfect, of course. The Northern Territory has reserved the right to opt out of the scheme. But to the extent that agreement is necessary, we have achieved that, and the scheme can now be developed. There are good humanitarian reasons for such a scheme and good prison administration grounds for such arrangements. These schemes do operate overseas, and they operate well. A number of countries have already been pressing Australia to participate.

The scheme will allow Australians serving sentences overseas to serve their sentences in Australia. It will also allow foreign citizens imprisoned in Australia to be repatriated to their home prison system when there are demonstrated community ties. The next step in developing the scheme will be a report by the group of officials working on the details of the legislative and administrative framework delivered at the next SCAG meeting in February.

At this stage it is envisaged that, in order to be transferred to Australia, amongst other things the prisoner would be required to be an Australian national who has a minimum of six months of his or her sentence remaining to be served. In addition, both countries, the prisoner and the Australian state receiving the prisoner, would all have to agree to such transfer.

In order for this scheme to operate successfully we do have to link with international mechanisms. It is proposed that, once the necessary legislation is in place, Australia as a first step will become a party to the Council of Europe Convention on the Transfer of Sentenced Persons, which currently has 23 parties to it. We will also be able to participate in the Commonwealth countries scheme—a scheme which now has four participants.

Multilateral arrangements are one way to go but there will also be a need to focus on bilateral arrangements. On the basis of patterns of imprisonment as between Australia and other countries, we will also look at the need to enter into bilateral arrangements with particular countries. The foremost amongst these would be Thailand, a country where the largest number of Australians—27 as at 6 June 1993—are serving terms of imprisonment. I understand that Thailand has already indicated a willingness to discuss a transfer scheme as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. While my interest in prisoner transfer is not confined to any particular country, my personal involvement has been through a constituent's daughter who is serving a long term of imprisonment in Thailand. Therefore, in view of the minister's comments on that country, could he keep the Senate informed on any progress in reaching an agreement with Thailand on this matter.
—I shall do so, Mr President. As well as that, of course, I will keep Senator Colston directly informed as to the progress, given his particular interest in Thailand.

—I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on Monday, 29 November. The article states that nine workers from Australian Stevedores were fined $40 each for agreeing to a request by the company's management to increase their productivity, in a one-off circumstance. The workers incurred the union's wrath after they `got in and got things done' to help retain a client that the company was in jeopardy of losing. In other words, they worked too hard. I ask: when will the government realise that waterfront reform needs to be nourished to avoid ridiculous situations like this happening? What is wrong with workers uniting with their employer, in this case to help keep a client and, ultimately, their jobs?

—It takes an extraordinary length of time for the penny to drop for the opposition. Senator Sandy Macdonald is referring to an incident that happened four weeks ago and it has taken this length of time to get a question on it—I actually thought I would get one on the first day the week before last week.

PARA.TAB: The incident referred to by Senator Sandy Macdonald related to a longstanding issue on the waterfront of the additional personnel required to protect people working below deck on a ship. On this particular occasion those additional personnel were not provided, so the union put out a statement saying that this was a safety issue.

However, in my experience over the last few years, the union's disciplinary procedures are normally and more appropriately applied to serious issues—for example, a worker being intoxicated on the job while operating very heavy and dangerous equipment. In my view, the application of those disciplinary procedures on this particular occasion was inappropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I ask: what guidelines are used to assess the hours needed for home nursing care for veterans? Have they been revised lately to reduce the nursing home care which veterans receive?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1992 there was a review of the community nursing program. It identified a degree of overservicing by some private providers. As a result of that review, changes have been implemented aimed at ensuring that our beneficiaries receive the level and type of care that are most appropriate to their needs. The Repatriation Commission requires that beneficiaries have a full nursing assessment undertaken by the nurse providing the care. The nursing needs delivered are assessed according to clinical need. In addition, DVA nurse advisers in each state branch office will be monitoring the quality of nursing care provided and conducting nursing assessments on some clients to determine if the nursing care provided is appropriate and meets our agreed standards.

PARA.TAB: It is fair to say to Senator Reid and other honourable senators that these steps will ensure that the level of nursing care delivered to veterans and war widows meets clinically assessed need. As a result of these new assessments, the amount of community nursing care a beneficiary has been receiving will be reduced or replaced with a more appropriate service—for example, home help.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. Recognising the minister's strong commitment to improving access to the arts and other cultural activities for all Australians, has he considered the potential for increasing the contribution of broadcasting to meet this need?

—I thank Senator Zakharov for her question, firstly, because it raises a very important question of principle and, secondly, because it enables me to refer to what I think is a very important opportunity for Australian viewers that is being missed by particularly the commercial networks. As is inherent in Senator Zakharov's question, it is important to note that the reach and pervasiveness of television and radio give them a fundamental role in the communication of cultural activities to Australians and the opportunity for Australians to properly have access to that which is being produced, often with the assistance of their taxes.

PARA.TAB: We have been talking a lot about access: people's capacity to enjoy the best available being inhibited by geographic location, which we discussed most recently with regard to visual arts, and people who have significant problems of access because of disability and because of socioeconomic circumstances. For some of them, television provides the only opportunity to see what is best and available, and it certainly brings government subsidised cultural activities to hundreds and thousands of taxpayers who otherwise would not get the benefit.

I am sure everybody watched last Sunday evening's broadcast of La Boheme, which I saw—and it was fantastic. This Sunday, for those people who would like to get their cultural fill, there is an Australian Opera performance of Orpheus and Eurydice—and it is free. A lot of people cannot afford it and that is why it is important. It is assessed that the television performance of La Boheme drew an audience of 800,000 people. It would take seven years of almost continuing audience for the Australian Opera to reach an audience of that size. Firstly, it increases the numbers and, secondly, it dramatically changes the composition of people who get access in terms of geography and socioeconomic distribution. The people who could never otherwise get to see what is being offered and what their taxes are subsidising get the opportunity through this activity. It was a fantastic performance and I am delighted that the ABC does this and I wish that commercial television would do it more. Of course, it does provide important access to Australian drama, and I also welcome that. That is the first point, and I thank Senator Zakharov for raising that point because that is important and I hope that more will be done in that regard.

The concern I want to draw attention to is what seems to be lacking in the commercial sector. When we think of the breadth of interest amongst Australians in cultural activity—particularly in view of the recent statistics about more Australians going to art galleries and museums than to the major football codes—it is interesting to note that what is lacking is information about Australia's cultural life.

There is an explosion of information in the print media. I am delighted to say that our major newspapers are producing more and better coverage of arts and cultural activities, but it is still significantly lacking in commercial television. I hope that commercial television will look at the potential audience and the commercial opportunities available to it, as well as the social responsibilities it can discharge by doing it. It is denying its audience access to this important information and missing an important opportunity. I hope that it will reconsider its attitude and give more coverage to this sort of material on commercial television.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Yesterday in question time, Senator Vanstone asked me a question about the Australian Protective Service. The Minister for Justice has provided the following advice: the suggestion by Senator Vanstone that morale within the Australian Protective Service at the joint defence facility base at Nurrungar is low and that relations with defence personnel are difficult is unfounded.

PARA.TAB: It is true that earlier this year there were some internal personnel problems within the APS which led to an investigation in May by Chief Superintendent Lacon, whose report was mentioned by Senator Vanstone yesterday. At Easter time this year the APS played a major role in dealing with demonstrations by the peace movement at Nurrungar. This involved some 700 demonstrators, 150 of whom were arrested by the APS during the demonstration.

I understand that the Department of Defence does have confidence in the capacity of the APS to fulfil its role of protection of the joint defence facility at Nurrungar. The internal organisational difficulties of the APS contingent at Nurrungar earlier this year did not affect its ability to protect the facility, as evidenced by its performance during the Easter demonstrations at Nurrungar and Woomera. Senior officers at the joint defence facility are currently satisfied with the performance of the APS.

The minister says that he is further advised that the Director of APS is satisfied that both morale and operations at Nurrungar have now improved substantially with the actions which he has initiated, combined with further close management attention which together will ensure that further improvement occurs.

When answering one part of the question, I said that I had been to Nurrungar myself. At that particular time I thought Senator Vanstone was referring to Pine Gap. It was to Pine Gap I had been, not Nurrungar.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Faulkner) to a question without notice asked by Senator Reid this day relating to home nursing care for veterans.

The minister confirmed that the department has in fact rewritten its guidelines, the effect of which is to reduce the amount of nursing care at home that a veteran can receive. I wish to make some remarks about the way this is done and what it in fact means, and refer in particular to one case.

I would in passing remind people listening to the broadcast and those honourable senators here that a carer gets a pension of $8.10 per fortnight for full-time care of a veteran at home. The sum is such that one would almost think that it would cost more than that to administer and send that amount out every fortnight. Its inadequacy for the job that is being done is very apparent indeed. I would also remind honourable senators of the amount it would cost to keep a veteran in a hospital or even a nursing home if the care were not able to be provided at home.

In the case to which I particularly wish to refer, it is fortunate that the veteran's wife is a former trained geriatric nurse. So she is able to do a great deal more for her husband than might otherwise have been the case. However, she is now 83 years of age and she has been the full-time carer for her husband for nine years. He, having had both legs amputated, is not able to care for himself. What I find absolutely remarkable is that after nine years, when the carer is now 83 years of age and the veteran himself is nine years older than when this started, the amount of nursing care received at home has been reduced by 13 per cent. One would have thought that after that length of time it might even have been appropriate to increase it. I also mention that the nurses who attend often stay for longer than the time that they have now been told they will be paid for because of their recognition of the needs of the family that I am speaking about.

I ask the minister to have his department look a little more compassionately at the needs of the people it is supposed to be helping. It might be said that perhaps some of this could be made up with respite care. There is provision for respite care. In the case I am referring to, the whole of the year's allocation for respite care for this family was used up in one go when the 83-year-old carer whom I mentioned had a triple bypass. So there is no more respite care available for the rest of the year. It might be said that it is a one-off case, but they are real people attempting to survive by having the veteran remain in his home, cared for principally by his 83-year-old wife. They are now having the nursing care component reduced, which makes it extremely difficult for this to continue.

I come back to the point I made earlier: the cost of having this veteran in a hospital or nursing home would be a great deal more than is being provided at present. I have no objection to the department being careful with the money being allocated for the purpose to make sure that it is not being used unwisely, but the department should at least look at a family, when it is examining the needs of a veteran, as a whole unit and take some account of the capacity of the carer to continue to do what she has been doing for nine years.

The total picture should be looked at to make sure that where there is a situation such as this, where the whole of the respite care allocation was used up while the carer underwent major surgery and then, astonishingly, returned to her job as full-time carer, the respite care component is continued during the year on a fortnightly basis, which is what should occur. The one-off allocation for the surgery that she underwent should have been an ex-gratia grant of respite care to enable the situation to continue. They want it to continue like this, but the pressure being placed on them at present means that it may not be able to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the specific case that Senator Reid has raised, I am happy to progress that with her privately. I think that is an appropriate way for us to proceed in that instance. I believe that the services that the Department of Veterans' Affairs is providing to our ageing veterans and war widows are appropriate services. I believe that we are particularly sensitive to the changing needs of veterans and war widows in our community.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Reid knows, in many forums that we both attend where veterans, war widows and representatives of ex-service organisations are present, I do stress the nature of the challenges that governments and ex-service organisations will face in the future. Currently, 30 per cent of our veterans and war widows are aged 75 years and over. By the turn of the century more than 60 per cent of our veterans and war widows, our entitled beneficiaries, will be over the age of 75 years.

That means that the sorts of services that Senator Reid has referred to will, I think, become more important to veterans' affairs beneficiaries. Senator Reid is also right to point out the fact that the profile of carers receiving carers pensions will also change. Not only are the beneficiaries getting older, but the carers in many instances, as Senator Reid knows, are getting older also. I think Senator Reid ought to acknowledge that our programs are very much focused on the importance of the health and the independence of Australian veterans and war widows. We are committed to seeing veterans and war widows, wherever possible, remain in their homes and remain independent for as long as possible. Their health and their independence is of vital importance.

I am happy to deal with Senator Reid privately on the specific instance that she mentions. I do not believe it is appropriate that we talk about individual cases in this procedure of taking note of answers to questions without notice. I give Senator Reid a commitment that I will have a discussion with her and look closely at the individual case that she refers to. But, from the surveys that we have conducted within the Department of Veterans' Affairs about our client needs and attitudes, many of these trends that have been identified in Senator Reid's questions are obviously occurring more broadly across our ex-service community, as has apparently occurred in the one case that Senator Reid mentioned. They are important challenges for the future. There is a need for our services to reflect the changing nature of the veteran community—the fact that we have an ageing community. This government has been committed, and will remain committed, to ensuring that the repatriation health care services that we provide are most appropriate to Australian veterans and war widows into the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) to a question without notice asked by Senator Bishop this day relating to the allocation of sports funding.

SPEECH.PARA: The question I asked today was a serious question which highlighted the matters that had been dealt with, in part, by Senator Campbell's question which drew attention to the double standards of the government in dealing with public administration and highlighted the work that my colleague Peter Costello has done concerning the Auditor-General's report and the maladministration of grants into Labor marginal seats for political advantage. I quote from the Auditor-General's report:
Although the Department plays a significant role in the administration of the program the assessment and selection of projects to be funded is made by the Minister.
The report further says:

The fact that in the latest round of approvals the Minister's office asked for details of the electorates in which the applications were located but was not prepared to put its request in writing when asked to do so by the Department, willy nilly can only lead to speculation about the basis for the selection process.

It also says that the documentation did not show the justification for approving one application in preference to another, and that is the basis of my question. The request was made by the Cromer Junior Rugby League Football Club to build an amenities block, which is to be used by members of the community to prevent the need to cross a busy road to use the only amenities facilities available—the facilities at the local service station. The application was for $55,000—not a cent was forthcoming. In Mrs Kelly's letter to Mr Carlton she said:

Unfortunately due to the large number of eligible applications received, many worthy projects were not able to be supported. The club's project was deemed eligible for funding. At this time, there are no plans for further applications for grants through this program to be sought. However, should additional funding become available through this or similar programs, all local government authorities and federal members of parliament will be advised. I regret that I am unable to be of further assistance at this time.

The fact of the matter is that the Auditor-General's report finds that there was no documentation to show the justification for approving one application as against another. I asked in a supplementary question that details be made available to justify why in the Labor marginal seat of Richmond, which was held by the government—and just—there were no fewer than 11 grants made, totalling at least $166,730. They were made to the Brunswick Byron Netball Association Inc., which received $12,000; to the Brunswick Heads Bowling Club, $6,000; to the Brunswick Heads Surf Life Saving Club Inc., $10,000; three grants in Ballina; and more grants in different parts of the electorate.

PARA.TAB: To put these in context, I draw attention also to other grants that were made in preference to the one being made to Cromer. There was one made to the Mount Gravatt Workers Club, which has had some notoriety. A $200,000 grant had been made to the club, which is in the marginal ALP seat of Moreton in Brisbane, before the club had even been formally established by a public meeting. No approval for the club's proposed sporting complex had ever been issued by the city council. The club committee included the ALP member for Moreton, Garrie Gibson; the former ALP Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Clem Jones; and the local state ALP member, Laurel Power.

The point is that the Auditor-General stresses that there is no legitimate documentation to say why one grant is made and another is not. The point is that in the seat of Mackellar not one cent by way of a grant was made available, yet in those areas where there was a political advantage to the Labor party the grants were made. I am simply saying that the Senate is entitled to know why one electorate is totally disadvantaged at the cost of not having a facility which is much needed and how political advantage determines public administration and how public money is spent.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the motion moved by Senator Bishop to take note of my answer. I think the most salient point about all of this is that Senator Bishop would not be asking a question about a grant in the Mackellar electorate unless there was another event this coming weekend of considerable significance for her political future. Until two or three weeks ago she would probably have needed a compass, a map and three days to find the details of the Mackellar electorate. I am surprised that someone who has a reputation for political perspicacity, as Senator Bishop apparently has in some sections of the Liberal Party, would stand up here after being away for three days—
—No, I wasn't.

—If not away from here, then in her room ringing for votes in Mackellar. I am surprised that she would stand up and ask such a transparent question that is related to her preselection prospects. It was crass.

—Order! Senator Schacht, it is not appropriate to reflect on the motives of senators. Having said that, I also draw your attention to the fact that you are not really addressing the motion before the chair.

—I am reflecting on competence, and I think that is a reasonable political point to make, but I certainly accept your direction. Senator Bishop has asked why one electorate got 11 grants and Mackellar got none. I think she ought to read the document that gives the guidelines for eligible grants. It is quite clear that those electorates that have expanding populations and low socioeconomic conditions get considered ahead of other electorates.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop would be aware that the electorate of Richmond, which I think she was referring to, has one of the fastest growing populations in Australia. What honourable senators opposite cannot get used to is that the person whom they accused of being an accidental oncer, Neville Newell, proved to be an outstanding local member and beat the Anthony dynasty. Before the last election everybody in the National Party was saying, `This is a lay down misere for a win because we have another one of the Anthony family running in this area. A third generation Anthony is running. We are going to bolt the seat in'.

Mr Neville Newell increased his majority against this extraordinarily expensive campaign run by the National Party and the Anthony family. As I said before, the opposition cannot get over the fact that it lost and it is now looking for another excuse and a conspiracy. It thought that it was going to win Richmond. It lost. Instead of looking at the quality of its candidates and the quality of its policies, the opposition is trying to find a conspiracy or some other reason why it lost the unlosable election and lost the unlosable seat of Richmond. That is why Senator Bishop is jumping up here as a cover for her own obviously diminishing preselection chances in Mackellar next weekend. Senator Bishop certainly has my full support for winning the preselection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. This is totally extraneous and irrelevant to the debate. You have already ruled on relevance and he is now ignoring your ruling.
—The point is well taken by Senator Schacht also, I am sure.

—I notice on many occasions that honourable senators opposite wander all over the place in these debates on motions to take note of answers. I stick to the facts about the future of Bronwyn Bishop, which is a matter of great interest to all honourable senators opposite. We are backing her all the way in Mackellar to get into the lower house to create mayhem there. I have given an indication to the Senate and to Senator Bishop that I will refer the technical details of her question to Mrs Kelly for a response and will return to the Senate next week to give the answer. I look forward to having a further discussion, irrespective of the outcome of the Mackellar preselection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief.
—Make it relevant.

—It will be totally relevant. Senator Bishop has not been a frequent visitor to the Northern Territory, but she has been there on a regular basis, I acknowledge, at the invitation of some of her conservative colleagues in the Northern Territory. I have sat here and listened for weeks now to knee-deep, po-faced hypocrisy from the opposition on this issue.
—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Would you mind asking Senator Collins how this is relevant to Richmond and Mackellar?
—Order! I am allowing Senator Collins to develop the argument. I am sure he will come to the point.

—I will get right down to the bottom line. The argument is about accusations of political preferment by politicians using their positions in parliament to enrich particular electorates. That is the issue. I have listened to the po-faced nonsense that has been run. As I have noted before, Senator Bishop has been to the Northern Territory on a number of occasions. I suggest that she have a word with her conservative colleague the Treasurer of the Northern Territory, Mr Coulter. He has recently issued a newsletter to his constituents in the electorate of Palmerston in the Northern Territory. The opening paragraph of the newsletter says:

SPEECH.PARA: As usual, Palmerston did well out of this year's Territory budget. As long as I remain Treasurer and Member for Palmerston, it always will.
Mr Coulter then goes on—

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is a tad up front.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. When I moved that the Senate take note of the answer given to me, I was dealing with the question of grants made by Mrs Kelly pursuant to her program. I did not ask any questions about the Northern Territory or about matters in the territory. Would you ask Senator Collins to confine his remarks to the question that I raised?
—I am satisfied that Senator Collins is seeking to address the principle of the question.

—Because of my desire to limit the length of my contribution to this debate, I will extract one or two items from the full list of gifts to the electorate of Palmerston which the Treasurer has listed on the front page of his newsletter. They are as follows: local government funding for the community hall or playgroup in Palmerston, $200,000; upgrading of the Archer sporting complex, $95,000; airconditioning of a hall and gymnasium, $350,000; Temple Terrace traffic improvements, $500,000; and floodlighting of the Moulden Oval, $120,000. I suggest that before there is any more criticism of the government, Senator Bishop might like to take up this issue with her conservative colleague, the Treasurer of the Northern Territory. I table the Treasurer's newsletter.

—I want to put on the record some facts about the allocation of these sports grants in the northern seat of Richmond. Senator Schacht completely misled the Senate. He was claiming that the difference between Mackellar and the northern seats was one of poverty and levels of income. Perhaps he could explain why the seats of Richmond and Page on the north coast, both seats with a margin of half to one percent, each received $180,000 in these grants while the seat of Cowper, which is not a marginal seat and which is held by the National Party, got $60,000, one-third of the amount received by the two equally poor seats to its north. The minister cannot explain that because the money was given out, not on the basis of need or poverty, but simply on the basis of their being marginal seats. It was a rort—one of the many that we have seen. The government should be condemned for this action.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), to a question without notice asked by Senator Campbell this day, relating to the use of government credit cards.

SPEECH.PARA: I will be very brief because Senator Patterson also wants to make a contribution to this matter. Senator McMullan, in a long answer—reading directly from a very carefully prepared brief—failed to answer crucial elements of the question I put to him regarding the credit card chaos which has beset the Australian government. It has 30,000-odd credit cards spread around the country. They are being used to purchase a range of items for the Commonwealth government with very little accountability, little audit trail and enormous susceptibility to fraud. It is ineffective expenditure and purchasing policy. We know from what Mr Tanzer, the Head of the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services, said in a Business Review Weekly article this week that purchasing policy needs to be reviewed and that more stringent safeguards need to be put in place. Purchasing policy was described in the Bevis committee's report as `mayhem'. We will know about it in greater detail next week when the Auditor-General reveals the state of the credit card scheme.

PARA.TAB: The point that needs to be made is that the minister refused to answer whether or not public servants were allowed to extract cash from these Commonwealth-provided credit cards. The ruling given in April 1991 by extract from the finance regulations of the Department of the Auditor-General says quite explicitly that although Westpac does provide access to cash by Australian government credit card, the secretary has determined that cardholders will not have access to cash advances.

Clearly there has been an enormous breach. Some $550,000 has been withdrawn through this scheme in the last 12 months. We have asked the minister to provide details of those 906 cash advances so the Senate can determine whether there has been a breach. It is incumbent on the government and the minister to table details of these cash advances—not next week or over Christmas when the Senate has adjourned but today, if possible, or by early next week at the very latest.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addition to the cash advances that my colleague was speaking about, evidence has also come to light of public servants using their taxpayer-funded Australian government credit cards for such things as weight reduction clinics, chocolates—it seems strange that someone is spending on weight reduction while someone else in spending on chocolates—surf wear, sunglasses, footwear, five-star hotels, furs, musical instruments, records, CDs, grog, country club membership, flowers and plants, horse riding lessons, speedboats, jewellery and clocks, museums and art galleries, takeaway food, hairdressing, lingerie, home brewing kits and duty-free purchases. The list of things that have been purchased with these cards is unbelievable. I will be interested to see whether the government can explain why it has let this practice continue—obviously for some time.

PARA.TAB: The other matter of great concern is that $3 million worth of taxpayers' money has gone in interest foregone. When I look around at the sorts of programs that are needed—especially in my portfolio area of senior citizens and aged care—I see, for instance, the number of carers looking after people with dementia. That $3 million could well have been spent in that area. Many Australians in the community—the more than 11 per cent who are unemployed and those who are struggling to buy things on their credit cards this Christmas—will, I am sure, be asking questions about how public servants were able to purchase the items on these lists. I hope the minister can come up with some answers. This government could not organise a chook raffle. It cannot look after Australian taxpayers' money, and I think this exemplifies that fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak on this matter. This is not the first time that public officials with plastic cards have been caught with their hands in the cookie jar. I questioned the tax office in estimates committee hearings last May, or whenever it happened to be, about the abuse of plastic cards in that department. It was admitted at that time that credit cards had been used to purchase such things as chocolates, horse riding and dancing lessons.

PARA.TAB: The tax office is the department that imposes the highest degree of honesty on all Australian taxpayers, yet it was not able to impose that standard on its own officers. Having been caught out, what did the government do with these officers? It counselled them: it hit them on the hand with a feather and told them not to do it again. There was not a great amount of money involved that time, but here we go again.

I simply refer to Kerry-Anne Walsh's article in the Bulletin which says that some 30,000 to 40,000 officers are now involved in purchasing with credit cards—of course, not every officer misuses the card. Many of those cards do not have limits. For instance, for three officers of the Department of Industrial Relations and Worksafe Australia the sky is the limit. Others in the Department of Defence and the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services have plastic cards with a buying power of $800,000—although mostly they are between $2,000 and $50,000. This system is way out of control.

Mr Taylor, in his letter to the plastic cardholders, said that he wanted some explanation, especially about some of the interesting purchases. These purchases have been outlined by Senator Patterson. This time it is alcohol, flowers, chocolates and lingerie. I presume the lingerie was bought by women—

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds like an elevator list in a department store.

—Yes. I presume the lingerie was bought by women in the department who were going to official functions. But I would like to know what the answer is because this has really blown out. The article says that goods to the value of between $30 million and $40 million have been purchased on these cards.
—Why can't we have these cards?
—Yes, why can we not have them? As the government had that previous experience with the tax office, why did it not clean up this matter before the Auditor-General was forced to bring it up again?

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), to a question without notice asked by Senator Herron this day, relating to health insurance.

The first point I make is that the Minister for Health, in his answer to my question, said that his office had supplied a copy of his speech last night. His office has still not put out a copy of his speech. We have been trying to get it. It has been unable to provide a copy, as it was unable to do when he spoke in Launceston. It took us a week, and we still did not get a copy of that speech.

PARA.TAB: The second point I want to make is in relation to the Australian Health Insurance Association. It is in the minister's pocket at the moment, going along with his proposals. I want to refer to Senator Richardson's record and I ask the association to look at his record. In 1977 he supported Mr Hayden against Mr Whitlam. In 1982 he supported Mr Hawke against Mr Hayden. TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Certain Aspects of Foreign Ownership Decisions in relation to the Print Media, be appointed to inquire into and report, on or before 28 February 1994, on the following matters:
(a)the origin and basis of decisions in 1991 and 1993 to increase the permissible percentage of foreign ownership of newspapers, and, in particular:

PARA.TAB: (i)whether those decisions were influenced by considerations relating to the content of newspapers including any requirement for "balanced" coverage; and

TAB.TAB: (ii)whether the contents of newspapers were influenced by those decisions or the prospect of those decisions; and
(iii)the procedures followed by the Foreign Investment Review Board and the extent to which any of its deliberations or recommendations were taken into account in the making of those decisions; and
(iv)whether the Prime Minister influenced or sought to influence those decisions, and, if so, the basis on which and the extent to which he did so; and

PARA.TAB: (b)the significance and effectiveness of the guidelines of the Foreign Investment Review Board; and
(c)the views expressed to Mr Conrad Black by the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson MP, on foreign ownership in the print media in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: (2)That the Committee consist of nine senators, as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a)four nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate; and
(b)four nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and
(c)one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: (3)That the Committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4)That:

PARA.TAB: (a)the chair of the committee be elected by the members of the committee from the members nominated by the Leader of the Opposition;
(b)in the absence of agreement on the selection of a chair, duly notified to the President, the allocation of the chair shall be determined by the Senate;
(c)the deputy-chair of the committee be appointed by the chair from the members of the committee immediately after the election of the chair;
(d)the deputy-chair act as chair when there is no chair or the chair is not present at a meeting; and
(e)in the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chair, or the deputy-chair when acting as chair, have a casting vote.

SPEECH.PARA: (5)That the quorum of the committee be five members.

(6)That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place and to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(7)That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the subcommittee.

(8)That, without limiting its power to pass procedural or other resolutions that are not inconsistent with this paragraph or these terms of reference, the Committee observe the following procedures, namely, that:

PARA.TAB: Submissions and calling of witnesses

(a)as a general principle, evidence be invited in the first instance in the form of written submissions and following examination of submissions, the Committee decide which witnesses are to be called for examination; and

(b)subject to any contrary order in relation to a particular submission, the submission to the Committee by a person of a statement relating to the inquiry be deemed to be the giving of evidence before the Committee by that person in accordance with that statement; and
Evidence
(c)evidence be heard in public session except in instances where the committee or a sub-committee resolves to hear evidence in camera; and
Statements to the media

SPEECH.PARA: (d)the chair be authorised to make statements to the media on behalf of the Committee concerning its activities; and
Broadcasts and re-broadcasts of public proceedings

PARA.TAB: (e)the recording, broadcasting and re-broadcasting of public proceedings is authorised in accordance with the rules contained in the order of the Senate of 23 August 1990 concerning the broadcasting of committee proceedings; and

SPEECH.PARA: Release of evidence and documents

PARA.TAB: (f)the secretary is authorised to supply for correction, copies of proof reports of both public and in camera proceedings to the witnesses whose evidence appears in those reports; and
(g)subject to any contrary order in relation to a particular submission, each document submitted to the Committee be published; and

SPEECH.PARA: Adverse Evidence

PARA.TAB: (h)subject to any contrary order, evidence which adversely reflects on a person, be forwarded to that person inviting their response.

SPEECH.PARA: (9)That:

PARA.TAB: (a)the terms of reference of the inquiry be appropriately advertised in the media; and
(b)written submissions be sought and examined by the committee and oral evidence be heard, including oral evidence from the authors of the most important submissions.

SPEECH.PARA: (10)That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee, with the approval of the President.
(11)That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(12)That the committee may report from time to time its proceedings and evidence taken or any interim conclusions or recommendations arising from its inquiry, and may make regular reports on the progress of its proceedings.

The need for the committee arises directly out of the recent Lateline interview with Mr Conrad Black and the extraordinary subsequent revelation of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in Seattle on 18 November that any increase in foreign ownership for Mr Black would be contingent upon the Fairfax group delivering balanced coverage, especially in the lead-up to the last federal election. This unprecedented confirmation that foreign ownership decisions in the media were to be made on the basis of the ALP's political interest rather than being made on national interest considerations makes it absolutely imperative that the parliament urgently examine this affair and get to the bottom of the government's decision making processes.

PARA.TAB: As is already, I think, widely known, both Mr Black and the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, have already indicated their willingness to attend. By contrast, the Prime Minister's continuing to plead the fifth amendment, I think, is a decision that I hope he will reflect on and, indeed, overturn during the recess. It is to be hoped that he will appreciate the implications of his threatened non-attendance, particularly the possibility that adverse inferences may well be drawn even by impartial observers who are anxious to ascertain what it was that really led to the two most recent decisions on foreign ownership in relation to print media.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has made clear, on many occasions, its very strong view that there is simply no justification whatever for embarking on this particular inquiry. The circumstances justifying the increase in the Black stake from 14.9 per cent to 25 per cent have been amply and rationally explained in terms of financial economic management considerations.

PARA.TAB: The notion that there was anything improper or inappropriate in anything said by Prime Minister Keating to Mr Black at any stage is utterly without foundation, despite all the pompous forensic nonsense talked on this occasion, as on many others previously, by Senator Alston. That is very clear from statements that have been made publicly by Mr Black, who is the only witness on this matter the opposition has or is likely to have.

What is going to be very interesting is to have Dr Hewson's views exposed on these same issues, given the evidence, of which we are aware, that Dr Hewson was not in fact prepared to place any limit on the quantum of the foreign ownership taken up by Mr Black or anyone else. We do not believe that this inquiry is necessary or justified. But now it is going ahead and manifestly the numbers in this place will determine that outcome; therefore, there is no point in speaking much longer on all this at this stage.

Now that the inquiry is going ahead we are indebted, I may say, to the Australian Democrats for forcing upon a very reluctant and a very embarrassed opposition terms of reference which will in fact guarantee an even-handed evaluation of this particular exercise, ensuring that there is an evaluation not only of the government's position on the question of foreign ownership here but that of the opposition as well. It is entirely appropriate that that should be so. Under those circumstances, we do not believe the reference is justified. We will divide on it, but we have a healthy appreciation of what the net result of our endeavours in this respect today will be.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the establishment of the Select Committee on Media Foreign Ownership Decisions. We do not believe that media ownership and the level of foreign ownership generally in Australia is a matter consigned to the dust in the cracks of history; we think it is a matter of immense importance.

PARA.TAB: It is not just a matter of the circumstances of the conversation the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) may have had with Conrad Black being amply explained; it is a matter of the process of decision making. That is why we are really pleased with the focus of this committee on the role of the Foreign Investment Review Board and the extent to which any of its deliberations or recommendations were taken into account in the making of decisions pertaining to media ownership and the level of foreign ownership in the media.

If we add that to the obvious consideration of the notion of balanced coverage—who said what to whom—I am pleased to reassure Senator Evans that we will be doing our best to ensure that even-handedness prevails. I do not think that will be an easy task because obviously there is a lot about this committee that will be political in nature, but at the bottom of all that there are important policy issues that we have an opportunity to explore. I am pleased to be supporting the establishment of this select committee, and I am pleased to be on it.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: (1)That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on the Native Title Bill, be appointed to inquire into and report, on or before 1 February 1994, on the following matters;

TAB.TAB: (a)the extent to which the Native Title Bill 1993 reflects the High Court's judgment in Mabo v Queensland [No. 2];
(b)the effects of the Native Title Bill 1993 on the rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people;
(c)the effect or likely effect of the Native Title Bill 1993 on the economic interests of Australia;
(d)the likelihood of the Native Title Bill 1993 being found to be, in whole or in part, unconstitutional, and the consequences of such a finding; and
(e)the impact of the Native Title Bill 1993 on the practical management responsibilities of the States in relation to the administration of land titles and property rights.

PARA.TAB: (2)That, in conducting its inquiry, the committee should examine in particular:

TAB.TAB: (a)the extent to which the Native Title Bill 1993 allows for the co-existence of native title with any other land title, leasehold, license interest or other right over land, and the potential legal implications of co-existence on such lands;

(b)the effect of the Native Title Bill 1993 on the security of land leases, licences or any other right over land issued by the Crown currently under issue, particularly pastoral leases, tourism leases and licences and mining or exploration leases and licences;

(c)the effect of the Native Title Bill 1993 on the mining industry and whether the Native Title Bill 1993 will create unnecessary delays in the granting of exploration and mining leases and licences to the detriment of the mining industry and the economy;
(d)the effect of the Native Title Bill 1993 on the rights of renewal available to leaseholders and licence holders issued by the Crown over areas of land;

(e)whether `forum shopping' between state and federal tribunals in the determination of native title breaches the traditional relationship between state and federal jurisdictions and, if so, whether such a breach is warranted;
(f)whether the revival of native title is consistent with the High Court's Mabo v Queensland [No. 2] judgment and, if not, whether revival rights are necessary;
(g)whether the Native Title Bill 1993 should include provision for a time limit for the lodgement of all native title claims; and
(h)the effect of the Native Title Bill 1993 in relation to existing Commonwealth, State or Territory legislation providing for title to be reserved for Aborigines.

PARA.TAB: (3)That the composition and powers of the committee be determined by a subsequent resolution.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very difficult matter; possibly one of the most difficult pieces of legislation to come before the Senate in years. Nobody disputes that. Furthermore, it is a piece of legislation which very few Australians understand anything about. I do not think that that is disputed. There is wide community uncertainty about Mabo—the case itself—and the government's proposed legislative response to the case.

PARA.TAB: Arising out of that uncertainty there is also considerable community disquiet. There is a feeling of uncertainty and worry in the community in relation to this matter, particularly out in rural Australia, Western Australia, the Northern Territory, Queensland and even in my state of South Australia. Of course, there is also political uncertainty in the state of New South Wales, whose government is now opposed to the federal government's legislation. Likewise, the state of Victoria and the Northern Territory are opposed to it and, of course, the Western Australian state government is strongly opposed to it and has legislated an alternative approach.

Therefore, it seems to us that this government should be only pursuing its legislative option in this place with great care and after considerable community consultation. In relation to a matter which in effect has so much potential for destroying social cohesiveness, one would have thought that the government would have gone out of its way to build a community and political consensus to the most desired legislative response.

Everyone accepts that there needs to be a legislative response to Mabo because of the uncertainty that has been caused as a result of the case and the fact that there are still so many issues that were not clarified by the High Court in its judgement in that case. There is a whole range of legislative responses that could be made. The government has chosen one particular course. We argue that it has chosen wrongly, and we see the Western Australian government, for example, taking a very different response.

Therefore, back on 23 November we gave notice that a select committee should be set up to go out into the communities in rural and regional Australia—not just the capital cities—and contribute not only to building greater public understanding of the Mabo issue, but also hopefully building greater confidence in a particular legislative approach. We would suggest that that is a very sound and sensible approach to be taken by the federal parliament. In addition, it would result in a much more informed debate even within this place when the select committee reports.

The government rejected that option. It rejected the possibility of such widespread community consultation. It has argued that its very limited consultation with select industry groups, state governments and select Aboriginal representatives is adequate. We strongly dispute that position and strongly argue that, if ever there were a piece of legislation that requires much greater public support to be carried than it has at the moment, it is this one. The government says that if we delay it for that public consultation, the fragile consensus that exists at the moment might evaporate. We would say that, if all the government has is a fragile consensus, then it should not be pursuing the legislation at this time.

If ever there were a need for a piece of legislation to be built on a sound foundation rather than a fragile consensus, the need exists with this piece of legislation. We are disappointed that the government is not prepared to allow the committee process of this parliament to take place to try to build that sound foundation towards a legislative response.

Of course, through that process we would have argued that there is a better legislative response. Our position is well known. Basically it is not to usurp the traditional and constitutional functions of the states in relation to land titles and to permit the states to operate in that traditional area of responsibility, subject to the High Court's decision and relevant Commonwealth legislation such as the Racial Discrimination Act. This is a very sound, logical and constitutionally valid alternative.

We would have had the opportunity through the committee—there is no secret about this—to have sought to build greater community support for that option. That debate and that educative process would have been helpful. We might have lost. The chances are we would have lost, when we look around this chamber, but at least we would have given the Australian people the opportunity to be part of this legislative process and we would have ensured a more constructive and positive debate in this place.

The alternative given by the government was to allow the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs just three days of hearings. What we will hear from the members of that committee this afternoon is that that was simply an inadequate amount of time in which to do the job properly. I am confident that they, or certainly those who have put down a dissenting report, will tell us that the individual people of Australia and the groups that they spoke to in the three cities that they were able to visit—Darwin, Perth and Brisbane—wanted more time for debate and wanted the select committee to be set up for that purpose.

The dissenting report tells us that there is serious constitutional doubt about the government's bill. It tells us that there are many Aboriginal groups who are unhappy with the government's chosen response, and are particularly unhappy that they have not been given the opportunity to be properly informed as to that response or to put their position.It will tell us that the mining industry in this country is worried about the loss of investment. It will tell us that pastoral interests are concerned about the security of their title and their livelihood. In other words, it reinforces that grave uncertainty within the community, an uncertainty that could be overcome by this select committee.

I am disappointed that we now find that the Greens are not prepared to support this process. I am amazed that the Greens in their press release say that it is a travesty that the government wants to push this bill through in the last week before Christmas to become law without the community better understanding it. Yet they are not prepared to allow the process of the parliament to take place whereby there could be another two months of detailed consideration in the community. I just cannot understand the logic of that.

The Australian Democrats, of course, announced that they would support the government's response even before the government had announced the detail of its response. So they were locked in from the past. This is just another example of how closely aligned they are with the Labor Party—sometimes we think even driving the Labor Party. But that is their chosen lot and we are therefore not surprised to see that they do not want the Australian people to have a greater participation within this legislative process.

We moved the motion because we on this side of the chamber think that it is important that this select committee go ahead for the reasons I have just given, and so that a greater community understanding can be built up on a very difficult and controversial piece of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition's motion simply is not designed to improve the government's native title legislation. Rather, it does nothing more or less than play into the hands of those who have yet to come to grips with the reality that the High Court has recognised a new form of title in the common law of this nation and that what we are about, as expeditiously and as sensibly as is possible, is implementing that in law in the way that creates the maximum degree of certainty for the maximum number of people within the shortest possible time, which is manifestly very much in the national interest.

PARA.TAB: For those who remain troubled about the consultative process that lies behind this legislation let me describe just what has gone into it. So far as the consultation process which has preceded the parliamentary consideration or the Senate consideration of it is concerned, it needs to be said as follows: over the past 18 months there has been an absolutely unprecedented degree of public discussion and debate on the issues raised by the Mabo High Court decision.

In the first place, the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation distributed a booklet called Making things right—reconciliation after the High Court's decision on native title, some 200,000 copies of which have in fact been sold through the Australian Government Publishing Service outlets.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many would have been read by Aborigines?

—ATSIC undertook a major public publicity campaign among both Aboriginal communities, which is, of course, its particular responsibility—responding to those interjections—and the wider community. Some 27,000 copies of an information kit prepared by ATSIC in terms that should be readily understandable by ATSIC's particular constituency were distributed. More recently 5,000 copies of a plain English guide to the bill, as it is described, have also been distributed by ATSIC.

PARA.TAB: The government itself very early on established an open and transparent process for responding to the Mabo decision. We established an interdepartmental committee which undertook wide ranging discussions, not just with itself but with those in the community who had a major interest in the outcome of this legislative process. It set up a ministerial committee to work through the issues. A discussion paper was released under the authority of that committee for public comment in June of this year of which 6,000 copies were enormously widely distributed. A comprehensive outline of the legislation, as it then stood in our minds, was released in September 1993, as a focus for public comment and discussion. I think nearly 3,000 copies of that particular outline were distributed. Some 3,000 copies of the bill itself and explanatory material associated with that have been distributed since the bill was first introduced into the House of Representatives some time ago.

The introduction of the bill was preceded by a very detailed process of negotiation and consultation with Aboriginal interests, the states and other relevant interests, including, of course, the pastoralists and the miners. That is something which none of the state or territory governments which have introduced native title bills have been prepared to do. So do not let us hear any yelps and squawks from Northern Territorians or Western Australians in this particular consultative exercise because nobody has been through the kind of process that we, the government, have been through on this matter.

Now there is the Senate committee report itself before us. Members of the committee will no doubt speak about that, and it sounds as though there may be some competing views—that is not unusual in the history of Senate committees when a certain partisan stance is to be taken. But what needs to be acknowledged is that in the time available, limited as it was, an extremely thorough and comprehensive inquiry into all aspects of the proposed operation of the Commonwealth bill has in fact been undertaken.

I congratulate the committee on the thoroughness and the quality of its work in the time involved. I think it is a really remarkable effort. It travelled to Queensland, Northern Territory and Western Australia and it received, read and considered 109 written submissions, as has been made clear in appendix 1. It heard evidence from a wide range of sources, both within the Aboriginal community itself—although it sat only in capital cities, under the auspices of this particular process it did hear people visiting those cities from a number of outlying communities—and it heard people from a whole range of other interest groups. My quick count of the total number of witnesses appearing before the committee in its four days of hearings in Brisbane, Darwin, Perth and Canberra was a total of 149 witnesses—all of them with something to say, all of them with relevant interests to represent and advance. Their voices were heard. That is not a flimsy, superficial or quick and dirty exercise. That itself represents—quite apart from all the rest of the consultative processes that I have already mentioned—a major effort at listening to people's responses to the terms of the legislation and involved far more consideration than most legislation gets in this place, as all of us who have been here for longer than five minutes would readily testify.

The majority report, after assessing all the evidence put before it, has recommended in favour of the early passage of the legislation. In particular, the majority report points to the highly detrimental and discriminatory impact of the Western Australian Mabo legislation on Aboriginal people in that state. It points to the potential breaches of Australia's international obligations arising from that legislation and it points to the urgent necessity of getting Commonwealth legislation into place to get a little bit of justice into the statute books to remedy—to redress—that situation that has now been created by the bull-headedness of the Western Australian government.

I will now say something about the debating time that will now be available to deal with this bill in this chamber. This is another relevant consideration if we are talking about references to select committees and the need for dispatch or the absence of dispatch in terms of parliamentary consideration of it. There will be ample opportunity for Senate debate on the Native Title Bill. We programmed more time for this bill—almost the whole of next week—than has been the case for any other bill, or indeed the total package, in the budget sittings program.

The only other bill for which any remotely comparable amount of time has been programmed is the Industrial Relations Reform Bill, which seems likely to take in total two full sitting days. Putting that in context, we have spent in the vicinity of 140 hours so far on legislation in these sittings and by the end of this week we will have dealt with a total of 112 bills which works out, on my quick calculation, at an average of just over one hour and 10 minutes per bill.

We have programmed for the Native Title Bill approximately 20 hours for debate in this chamber during the second reading and committee stages. If we achieve that, if we go that distance, that should represent about 12 per cent of the total time that has been spent on legislation in these sittings. We will have spent 12 per cent of our time on one bill and there is a total of 112 bills, or 70-odd different packages of legislation, that we have dealt with in this session. So it is being given the time and attention it deserves.

It has been given the consultative time and attention it deserved in the whole very complex and elaborate process leading up to the introduction of the legislation. It has been given a reasonable amount of time and attention by the Senate standing committee legislative scrutiny process—in fact, much more through that particular process than I can recall being given any other piece of legislation. It has been given, and it will be given, an ample amount of debating time in this place to enable us to deal with not only the general principles of the bill, but also, as I know many honourable senators want to do, particular, substantive, detailed proposed amendments to it.

It cannot be assumed that the reference to a select committee would result in a report back to this place some time around 21 February, as is proposed by the current form of the motion. We all know that there is not going to be any realistic opportunity to put substantial time and effort into a select committee exercise in what remains of December when we get up or in the month of January, because life is not like that in Australia; it never has been. Whatever the determination of the committee might be to work through the period of January, it is highly unlikely to be able to get access to the range of witnesses that would be necessary to add any significant new dimension to the Senate's understanding of this legislation that has not already been contributed by the excellent work that has been done by the Senate committee.

It has to be also said that while much of the public debate on this whole Mabo issue has been constructive, there has been a tendency for some elements in the community to be destructive and divisive in their contributions. While the nation has much to gain from successfully addressing and resolving the issues raised by Mabo, as I hope we would all acknowledge, it is the case that some groups will see gain for themselves in frustrating such a resolution.The truth is that further delay, however well intentioned it may be, will only play into their hands and place at risk the very substantial national gains which are now within our grasp.
The Greens, after a lot of agonising, seem to have understood and accepted this point. They say in their press release issued today:

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that the forces in our community would have used the delay to undermine further the legislation.
They describe the legislation as `already unacceptable'. They cannot expect me to accept that particular characterisation, but I do accept their description of `undermining'. They continue:
The time would have been used to engage in more racial vilification against indigenous people.
That is a point that I think has to be taken at absolutely face value. There are an awful lot of rednecks still out there in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —What makes you think that?

—There are an awful lot of rednecks in the particular constituency that Senator Panizza represents. I am not suggesting for a moment that Senator Panizza, even when he is at his vulgar and noisiest worst, is a redneck in that same capacity. But I am suggesting there are a lot of people out there who welcome every conceivable opportunity to belt the racist drum and to say exactly what they think about the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I do not believe they should be given the further opportunity.

PARA.TAB: I cannot believe that any such exercise would be concluded in February. I am sure, in the nature of these things, it would spill over much longer than that. We are talking about literally months and months of very divisive and very destructive debate. The kind of process of reconciliation, of building consensus, of building support for an understanding of the rights of Aboriginal people, of building an understanding for some principles of justice and principles of decency at last to be applied for these people who have been so sadly neglected, that consensus, that process of reconciliation, is fragile and that would, I am afraid, be very seriously prejudiced by any extended process of this kind.

Delay will place added strain on the reconciliation process between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. This is the very last point that needs to be made: I fear that further delay would also exacerbate tensions within the indigenous community, particularly between those indigenous people who stand to gain from the High Court decision because of their continued association with land in some shape or form, and those who will not, by the nature of their longstanding dissociation from land, so benefit. We want to avoid that kind of division. We want to promote harmony, reconciliation and consensus. This particular exercise will not only not contribute to that; it will operate very directly, very immediately and very hurtfully against it. For all of those reasons we will not support this motion for reference to a select committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike many or in fact most bills that we debate in this chamber, the Native Title Bill has had a very long birth process. For at least a year, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), after the High Court judgment, consulted with the states. I am one who criticised the exclusivity of that consultation.
—He didn't consult with WA very much, and that's on the record.

—He did. Senator Panizza, prior to the breakdown in communications, every state government was extensively consulted in the year after the High Court judgment. It is not the Prime Minister's fault that those negotiations broke down later on. I criticised the Prime Minister for thinking that only the Prime Minister and state premiers had the right to have an input into the form and content of the native title legislation. We saw eventually that that commitment to consultation was extended to include greater discussions with the mining industry, the pastoral industry and, ultimately, with what has become known as the Aboriginal negotiating team.
—Unelected ones.
—Well, ATSIC is not unelected. Senator Panizza has his own views about ATSIC, but ATSIC is the Aboriginal parliament of this nation.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Senator Panizza, when you seek the call, I will give you the call at that time. I ask you to refrain from interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will go back to that point because an objection which is raised from time to time concerns the question of the legitimacy of the Aboriginal negotiating group, the fact that they are not elected. The point is that the opposition has not had the opportunity to be involved in the detail of the negotiation. I suspect that it does not even know the Aboriginal people who have been involved. The point of saying that is to define for the opposition who represents the Aboriginal negotiating team, because it does not appear to know. First and foremost, there is ATSIC. We have seen Lois O'Donoghue and the other commissioners at the press conferences and in the negotiations with the Prime Minister. These people are elected from the grass roots of the regional councils right through to the commissioners themselves.

PARA.TAB: The second component of the negotiating group is those who represent the land councils and the third component at the beginning was some members from the Eva Valley working group. They were there; they are still there. They are now affectionately called the B team. The fact is they are still there and they are still part of the process.
