TALK.START.PARA: —I want to please my colleague Senator Panizza by quoting from Mr Chaney and also from Mr Campbell in a reference that was made to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in its inquiry into the Native Title Bill, which is not the subject of this debate here this afternoon but nonetheless is a very important subject.

PARA.TAB: Before I do that, I want to pick up the point made by Senator O'Chee in his contribution to the debate when he quoted from the Hansard evidence given by Mr King. The evidence given by Mr King was later answered by Mr Peter Yu, who is the Executive Director of the Kimberley Land Council. Mr Yu said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is highly unfair and insulting to the executive of the Kimberley Land Council who are represented by many of those 30 or so different language groups, traditional people—people who are very senior, and very strong in their law and culture. There may be political differences that the gentlemen at the other end of the table have, and we respect that. We have tried to accommodate the interest by approaching them to sit down in negotiations. If people are not prepared to sit in negotiations and consult, I am not sure how you resolve it.

I would hope that would put the quote used by Senator O'Chee earlier into some degree of context. We still live in a democratic country and people can choose not to be associated with decision making. However, when they choose not to be associated with decision making they then should not go to the extent of criticising decisions that are made. Unfortunately, we have seen a number of instances of that occurring a number of times through the course of what was a relatively short but in terms of hours and input a very exhausting, a very lengthy and a very detailed inquiry.

PARA.TAB: I will now satisfy my colleague Senator Panizza by quoting the two gentlemen I mentioned earlier. It is a direct quote from the Senate committee Hansard of Friday of last week, page 444. Mr Chaney said:

My reason for giving evidence was my concern that history would seek to be re-enacted, or they would seek to re-enact history by building up public feeling against any notion of Aboriginal rights in this state, to the point where political action would become impossible through the parliament. I am fortified in that view by the comments made by the member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Campbell, in the second reading speech in the House of Representatives, where he made this comment:

SPEECH.PARA: It may be possible that, for once in their lives, the Greens will do something useful. If they can lock this up in a committee for any length of time, I believe public opinion will steamroll this bill and it will be consigned to the garbage bin of history where it belongs.

I think Mr Chaney was making a lot of sense. I think all Western Australian members of parliament, be they federal or state members, know that there is a racist campaign being beaten up in Western Australia at the moment. It is a campaign which we were reminded of a number of times during our visit to Perth. We remember the campaign during the 1980s and we look back on it with regret. I am sorry if I am embarrassing anybody in the opposition, but I now show the Senate a poster that was placed outside polling booths right across Western Australia in 1986. The posters were put there by Liberal Party and National Party campaigners. Those opposite cannot wash their hands of it now. Their party was intimately involved in a dreadful, racist campaign in the 1980s. It cannot be allowed to be repeated in Western Australia or in any other part of this country.

PARA.TAB: We are at the cliff edge of it happening now. The advertisements and letters are appearing in our newspapers. I bet it is not only those on this side of the chamber who are receiving those disgraceful, disgusting letters that make one ashamed to be a political representative of Western Australia. We cannot try to hide from it: there is racism in our society and sometimes it raises its ugly head more often than at other times. I certainly hope it does not happen. If this bill were deferred for a month, two months, five months or, more realistically, 12 months, so that a select committee could do its job, our society would completely break up.

We have witnessed—much to the shame of the particular organisation concerned—a rewriting of history. We should perhaps be addressing the report of the parliamentary committee that looked into this matter rather than Senator Hill's motion, because that committee received a submission from the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia. It was submission No. 5 and it has been published. I quote from page 4 of the submission:

SPEECH.PARA: It would appear to be entirely fair for compensation to be paid where anyone is deprived of property rights or right to enjoy some title or facility as provided for in the current Western Australian Acts, however the right to compensation for loss of perceived rights where entitlement or title has not been established is quite another issue.

For past acts the question would have to be decided on whether the granting of pastoral leases deprived aborigines of the right to use the land. In Western Australia, South Australia, and the Northern Territory, aborigines were not removed from the land . . .
I reiterate that the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia said this to a Commonwealth parliamentary committee:

. . . aborigines were not removed from the land until Commonwealth laws were passed in the seventies making it mandatory to pay award wages and granting full social service benefits. This forced the stations to pay only those who qualified for full wages and others to remove to where full benefits were available.

In the early days aborigines congregated around the station homesteads because life in the bush was harsh and brutal; for prolonged periods sustenance was near to starvation level, and station owners provided rations—it was easier to come in out of the bush.

That is a disgraceful submission by any standards. In 1993, to put forward such a statement to a Commonwealth parliamentary committee, knowing that it would be made public, to rewrite history in that manner, is disgraceful. I could use stronger words about it, but I will refrain from doing so in order to observe the gentilities of this place. But it gives us an indication of views that are prevailing in our society.

That a senior officer and respected community citizen in the form of Mr Boultbee was prepared to put his name to such a scurrilous statement as this without any sense of fear says a lot about our society.

PARA.TAB: A lot of people forget—unfortunately, many of the Aboriginal people both in my home state of Western Australia and particularly those who gave evidence on the east coast of Australia—that last week Western Australia passed into its laws an act of parliament which removed native title for Aboriginals in Western Australia. It did that with such urgency that for the first time in over 100 years the guillotine was applied in the upper house, in the Legislative Council. It was the first time that the guillotine has ever been used in that house and it was used in order to remove native title, to overturn the High Court decision. The guillotine was not just applied once; it was applied twice. On the second occasion there was a multiplicity of amendments put forward that were not even subject to debate because no time was allowed for it.

That is how serious the issue is and that is how confident the Court government in Western Australia is that it can push through, and get away with, what will clearly be recognised by history as racist legislation. It can do it; it did do it. In one-third of the land mass of Australia, native title has now been wiped out. That is one of the reasons for the urgency of the legislation that the Senate will be debating next week. One of the reasons why that legislation must be brought in is to protect those Western Australian citizens who have been deprived of their rights through that action.

I conclude by giving a further reason why this motion before the Senate should be defeated and why the bill should be carried next week. I quote from evidence given to the committee by Father Brennan, a Catholic Jesuit priest and Australian citizen who said in his opening comments:

SPEECH.PARA: It is sometimes said that I am an Aboriginal advocate, but I am not. There are more than enough Aboriginal advocates here who would take the view that my views on these things are often on the side of conservatism.
That is what he said about himself. On page 532 of the Senate committee Hansard of 6 December he said:

Firstly, what is to be put in its place and, secondly, what is to be done for the benefit of native title holders, particularly in Western Australia, who stand to suffer most because of the Western Australian legislation? It would seem to me that there is no Aboriginal group that will lose out from this legislation and there are Aboriginal groups that stand to gain from legislation of this sort being passed.

I think it is a very convincing argument by a very respected individual who I do not believe is a conservative. I do not necessarily agree with everything that he says from time to time; nonetheless, I respect his right to have a view and to profess that view, as I respect the right of Mr Boultbee to have a view and to express that view.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, I do not think anybody has the right to distort history in the way that Mr Boultbee has done. I condemn him for that and I condemn his organisation for allowing him to do it officially on its letterhead. I further condemn the organisations which have joined with interests in the mining industry and other organisations in Western Australia to finance advertisements in our media that are whipping up anger, bitterness and hatred against the most deprived class of people in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to join this debate briefly this afternoon and refer to the motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, to refer the Native Title Bill to a select committee. This legislation before the parliament is fundamental. It is of great importance for all Australians, especially Aboriginal Australians. The motion put forward by Senator Hill is worthy of very serious consideration because of the import that it sets out in the proposed terms of reference and the matters that should be examined by the particular committee.

PARA.TAB: But there are only two aspects that I want to address this evening. I will leave the other comments very logically and correctly until next week's debate on the Native Title Bill when the Senate will be considering that in obviously a lot of detail. But, in pushing for Senator Hill's motion today, I want to stress two points and two points only. The first issue is the interests of Aboriginal people, with whom I am very familiar in my electorate. I am not wishing to be descriptive in any way when I describe them as traditional and ceremonial Aborigines. They have a very important stake in this particular legislation. The second issue that I want to address relates to the constitutional relationship between the Commonwealth and the states and territories. To me, Senator Hill's motion goes to the very fundamental core of the interests of those two particular groups.

I represent very proudly the Northern Territory electorate. Thirty-five thousand people living in my electorate are Aboriginal or of Aboriginal descent. A very significant proportion of those people are traditional Aborigines still living in remote, isolated communities and carrying on, what can probably be described as, a ceremonial lifestyle that has very great significance.

When the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs visited Darwin last week, an excellent presentation was given to the committee by the Rev. Dr Djiniyini Gondarra, the executive officer for the Northern Regional Council of the Uniting Aboriginal and Islander Christian Congress. Dr Gondarra went into a lot of detail with regard to the specifics of Aboriginal law and how it would impact. One of his advisers, Mr McMillan, in backing up the comments made to him, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are describing to you a system of law which is perhaps far greater than the draftsman of this bill or than the non-Aboriginal people of this country believe it to be.

The issue was raised very fundamentally that the Native Title Bill did not address that situation. That is a debating point. It is very significant and important for those traditional Aboriginal people of Arnhem Land, elsewhere in the Northern Territory, in Western Australia and in Queensland to have those issues properly addressed. The way in which the committee and this parliament, in its haste, are now dealing with this legislation, I find to be very patronising and to be very wrong.

PARA.TAB: We are all aware that when two cultures are trying to communicate, there are exceptional differences that have to be addressed. Often we do not make that proper appreciation, in a legal sense or in a political sense, in accommodating that very important issue in dealings between two cultures. I am fearful that of the 149 witnesses that appeared before last week's committee—whom Senator Chris Evans identified—less than a handful were full-blood Aboriginal people still living in and linked to their traditional and cultural ways. That is a great shame. I do not call into question the bona fides of any witness and I appreciate that many of the Aboriginal people who appeared had good intent. But many of them do not reflect the interests of full-blood Aboriginal people and there is often very fierce debate within the Aboriginal community about the issues and how they present them.

I became familiar recently with an excellent article by a school teacher in Arnhem Land who back in 1987 prepared a very good document that looked at the cultural differences that school teachers had to address when they went into traditional Aboriginal communities. Whilst this was prepared for a teacher, let me just quote a couple of points that need to be taken into account because I think they are vitally important and will be essential to both this debate and the debate next week. This document stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In yolngu—
that is Aboriginal society—
. . . it is bad manners to be too curious or inquisitive, and yolngu passively resist answering too many questions because it goes against their notions of independence and privacy.

Yolngu children generally do not experience in their own culture the use of questioning as a teaching technique or the question-and-answer technique of transferring knowledge. It follows that yolngu cannot understand why a teacher is asking questions when she knows the answers. (There is one setting in yolngu society where they do ask questions when they know the answer—that is when they are angry and make a loud speech in public. Here one of the techniques of verbal challenge is to `ask' rhetorical questions such as, `Do you think I don't know what you've been doing, eh?' These questions are never answered, and children expect not to have to answer similar questions from teachers.) This simple inability to understand the function of the question as a teaching technique is enough to reduce children to a confused silence.
I wonder, Mr Acting Deputy President, whether you have experienced that in meeting and talking with many Aboriginal people. The paper goes on to say:

Hypothetical questions are an even worse problem, because they are never found in yolngu speech. Even if yolngu are asked an hypothetical question in a very real setting and it has immediate relevance so that they seriously tried to understand it, they still often misunderstand because they transpose the hypothetical setting to a literal setting. For example, if you ask, `Would you rather have a banana or an orange?' and the answer is, `Orange', it will be assumed that you have an orange and a banana right there to give away.
Similarly, there are issues that deal with shyness. It covers the issue of how people deal with social norms. The paper goes on to say:

Yolngu will sometimes answer what they think you want them to say. For example, they will say, `Yes', when they know the right answer is `No', but they think you hope it will be `Yes', just to avoid the possibility of direct verbal confrontation or the likelihood of further questions.
If you are in the habit of phrasing a question in the form of alternatives in English, it might prove fruitful to slow down and work out one alternative at a time.

In a Senate committee system, we tend to engage in all of those activities. As I said, my concern is that at last week's hearing there were fewer than five traditional Aboriginals giving evidence. Whilst there were many other representatives, many of them had political and correct representative agendas that may not necessarily reflect that important bit of the traditional Aboriginal.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the issue that I think needs to be addressed by a select committee is this constitutional relationship between Commonwealth, state and territory governments. Mr Acting Deputy President, you referred to that matter of the Western Australian legislation and that is on one side of the political spectrum. On my own side from the Northern Territory point of view, there is an important act of this parliament—the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act—which bestows rights that go further than that of the Native Title Bill that will be debated next week. That will produce tensions and issues that ought to be, and should be, properly resolved to ensure a consistency in the benefit of all people. That relationship between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory is terribly important.

The next generation of Australians and Aboriginal Australians will feel for years and generations to come the repercussions of what we do in this parliament next week. I would have thought the Greens would have been much more attracted to an inquiry over the next month or two that pursued those issues and set that relationship right so that there was not the opportunity for conflict, tension or racism to rear its head. Unfortunately, I am of the view that the bill currently before us will exacerbate, rather than assist, that problem. I hope that the Greens will reconsider their position and support Senator Hill's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the chair is whether a select committee, which will report back here by 1 February next year, ought to consider a whole variety of matters arising out of the Mabo judgment. You, Mr Acting Deputy President, are very familiar with that judgment, having no doubt read it, and you have been a member of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs that has looked at and inquired into very many matters from very many people arising from the Native Title Bill.

PARA.TAB: Can more inquiries take place? Of course more inquiries can take place. No matter what legislation comes into this chamber, more inquiries can take place. I think you, Mr Acting Deputy President, made a very powerful contribution to a debate that has been going on in this chamber on industrial relations legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —He always does.

—He always does, as the august minister who sits in front of me says. On several occasions, we have heard those opposite say that one of the problems with the inquiry is that there has not been enough consultation. I remember when the corporations legislation came before this parliament the claim was made that there had not been enough consultation and that more should take place. The question is not whether more consultation could take place but whether enough has. I can only reiterate on that point the telling remark made by Senator Kernot, who said that in deciding whether enough consultation has taken place we should look at not only the discussion that has taken place in the committee but also the discussion that has taken place over years—which she plays such a central part in—between the Aboriginal citizens of this country and other members of this community.

PARA.TAB: There has been massive consultation over the years. It is said that somehow that position will be improved if, over the January holidays—that is the holiday season; it is a very Australian custom to have holidays in January—such consultation takes place as will, according to speakers on the opposite side, bring agreement with the various groups affected by the Mabo decision. That is clearly not so because the difficulty with the Mabo decision is that it brings into play a whole range of conflicting interests which can never be reconciled.

That is the problem with which we are faced. When we listen to the miners talking about how the proposed legislation will affect them, they put forward very valid points. When we listen to the pastoralists, so do they. When we listen to the commercial fishermen, as you did so intently, Mr Acting Deputy President, they have a good point. Of course, so do the Aboriginals. Everybody feels they are entitled to their rights and, in the ideal situation, everybody should be given their rights, but conflicting rights can never be reconciled. They will not be reconciled by a quick inquiry. It will have to be a quick inquiry. As I understand it, the committee will have to report back on or before 1 February 1994. It is impossible for that to happen.

I thought Senator Chamarette made a most moving speech in this chamber. Clearly, she has had to face some very hard issues, which she has resolved. The resolution of those, of course, is not easy. No doubt we all feel the tensions that arise in a situation such as this. But, in the end, our system of government is such that the parliament must make laws that are proposed by various people. The bills might be proposed by a private member, by government and so on, but in the end we have to make a decision. We cannot, and should not, resile from our responsibility to do that. Now is the time for us to consider the bill, and that will be done next week.

This process will not be the end of the fight of the Aboriginal community in this country for justice. This is a very historic occasion. Winston Churchill, whom perhaps you did not know, Mr Acting Deputy President, in the darkest days of the war said:

SPEECH.PARA: This is not the end. It is not even the beginning of the end. But it is, perhaps, the end of the beginning.
I think that, if this legislation is approached by the Aboriginal community and others on that basis, it will be put into proper perspective. It should be debated, and debated next week.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I glanced through this Australia Council annual report with considerable interest. My eye was drawn in particular to the community cultural development program, particularly to the amount of money which flows to the trade union movement via Australia Council grants. I find it difficult to accept without great concern—ironically in the year of the federal election, a year in which the trade union movement spent a considerable amount of time, money and effort re-electing the Labor government—that so much money is flowing to the trade union movement.

PARA.TAB: I find it utterly inappropriate. A major issue of propriety is in relation to the use of the Australia Council as a vehicle for expending a vast amount of money on the trade union movement which, patently and obviously to the people, has enormous and significant sums of money at its disposal, and which were used quite blatantly to re-elect the Labor government back in March.

Page 99 of the annual report has a section listing trade union programs which get a total of $166,000. Above that, trade union arts organisers get a number of grants totalling $62,000. Among the other extraordinary items under this program are other union grants, buried away almost as though they were deliberately hidden in other grants. There is something called national networking—I have no idea what that is—for which the Trades and Labour Council of Queensland got $15,000. There are performance projects. The trade union choir of South Australia got $6,000. The total was $40,000 or $50,000. There is promotion—field initiated, with more grants to trade unions. There is resource development—field initiated, with more grants. The Australian Railways Union of South Australia, the Food Preservers Union of South Australia, the trade union choir of South Australia and the Waterside Workers Federation are all getting thousands and thousands of dollars of grants under these extraordinarily obscure programs—under the Australia Council's auspices. It is quite inappropriate for taxpayers' money to be used to fund these various activities of trade unions, particularly in a year in which thousands and thousands of dollars of trade union money has been used to re-elect the Labor government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Clause 12, pages 5 and 6, omit proposed subsection 111(1G), substitute the following subsection:

"`(1G) In determining an application for the Commission to dismiss or refrain as mentioned in paragraph (1)(g) because of subparagraph (1)(g)(ii) or (iii), the Commission must give particular weight to the benefits of not disturbing a particular employment agreement (as defined in subsection (1A)) if the application is made on the ground, or on grounds including the ground, that:

TAB.TAB: (a)(i)the matter or part, or the industrial dispute or part, concerns terms and conditions of employment of a particular kind and application; and
(ii)terms and conditions of that kind and application are regulated by the employment agreement; and
(iii)a State industrial authority could have prevented the employment agreement from coming into force if the authority had considered that:

PARA.TAB: (A)the agreement would result in the reduction of any entitlements or protections of employees under:
(1)a State award; or

TAB.TAB: (2)any law of the State that the authority thought relevant; and
(B)in the context of those employees' terms and conditions considered as a whole, the reduction would be contrary to the public interest; or
(b)(i)the matter or part, or the industrial dispute or part, concerns terms and conditions of employment of a particular kind and application; and
(ii)terms and conditions of that kind and application are regulated by the employment agreement; and

(iii)the employment agreement complies with minimum conditions prescribed by a State Act, and a State industrial court or a court of competent jurisdiction has the power to declare the employment agreement wholly or partly void.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: The substance of the amendment is (b)(iii). The rest of the amendment is, in effect, the position as stated in the bill—although the wording has been rearranged to facilitate putting in the new subparagraph (b)(iii).

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crane, to guide us, are you moving amendment No. 2?

—We have two amendments to clause 12. We will move the second one only if the one I have moved is not accepted by the government and the other parties. This amendment compels the commission to give particular weight to the benefits of not disturbing an existing state originated agreement, provided it meets three criteria. Those three criteria are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (iii) a State industrial authority could have prevented the employment agreement from coming into force if the authority had considered that:
(A)the agreement would result in the reduction of any entitlements or protections of employees under:
(1) a State award; or
(2) any law of the State that the authority thought relevant; and
(B) in the context of those employees' terms and conditions considered as a whole, the reduction would be contrary to the public interest;

It is a small addition, but we believe it is an important one because it compels the commission, when looking at a contract under state legislation, to give particular consideration to the points I have raised.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one will be surprised to know that the government is not agreeing to this amendment. Our concern is that this would seek to discourage the Industrial Relations Commission from disturbing an employment agreement which merely had to meet minimum standards set by state legislation. Given the tenor of recent state legislation, it would quite clearly undermine the whole thrust of the government's policy about awards underpinning agreements.

PARA.TAB: We could have a long discussion about it, but I think everyone is familiar with the issues. It is quite clearly philosophically unacceptable to us. The outcome that may ensue in at least some states—and potentially at different times in the history of all states—is unacceptable also. The government will not be accepting the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are not convinced of the need for this amendment either. The bill impedes any roping-in claim where the relevant state has a no disadvantage test for employment agreements which is equivalent to the federal test. This amendment seeks to water down that benchmark so that the state merely has to have minimum conditions and a court which can quash the agreement in whole or in part. Its effect is to nullify the intention of the clause, because every state would comply.

PARA.TAB: In our view, the no disadvantage test is a major element of the industrial safety net. We do not object to the encouragement for the states to adopt it which is provided by the bill in its present form without amendment. So we will not be accepting the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that this legislation is designed to override the mandates that were given to a number of states in recent state elections. A clear mandate is about to be given at the South Australian state election. I am very familiar with the situation in Western Australia following the last election; I am not so familiar with the Victorian situation. But, certainly in Western Australia, the issues of industrial relations and its direction were very high on the list of issues that were debated at the last election. Some pretty scary campaigns of total deception were run during that election—from the north to the south and from the east to the west of that state. Even with those scare campaigns, the Western Australian people voted very clearly for a change in direction after 10 years of Labor.

PARA.TAB: This amendment compels the commission to take into consideration those industrial relations issues. The amendment is not saying that we want the commission to be unfair to people in the workplace, but it is asking the commission to take those various aspects into consideration. It is very frustrating for the people who voted in those elections—whether they were employees, employers, or in some other category—to now find that this government, backed by the Democrats, is moving to a position where it will override the states' mandates. The amendment makes only a small change, but I believe it is necessary in order to cater for the situation that exists in those states.

In a federation, as a federal parliament—particularly as a Senate—we have a responsibility to take those factors into account. The amendment is not trying, as was suggested by Senator Bell, to overturn the intent of this legislation. It is giving a little more flexibility and is taking away some of the rigidity. It will prevent moves towards centralising everything in Canberra which, in the long term, can only be detrimental to the various states—my state in particular.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens in Western Australia have experienced what has happened in that state where the adult award is $275 a week for unlimited hours work. We, therefore, will not be supporting this amendment.

—I want to pick up a couple of points Senator Crane said with respect to this proposed Commonwealth legislation. Firstly, with respect to the mandate, the Labor Party that is still in government went to the last federal election with a commitment to workers in this country that it would make changes to industrial relations legislation to bring us into line with international obligations pursuant to industrial employment matters.
—You're not talking about that very much. You spent most of your time telling lies about jobsback.

—We certainly did talk about it. In fact, it was a very major issue. Senator Chapman might not like to acknowledge that, but it certainly was a major issue. In addressing Senator Crane's amendment, I think what he is losing sight of is the fact that the Commonwealth legislation will not override state legislation where the state legislation meets the requirements of those international obligations. Where state legislation is seen to comply with the obligations as they relate to ILO or other conventions, the Commonwealth legislation will not override it.

PARA.TAB: We had a long and lengthy discussion about this in the committee. I thought Senator Crane understood that. He in fact raised a number of questions in the committee about this particular matter. So I think this amendment is not necessary because, if Western Australia, Victoria, New South Wales and other states have legislation—in particular, as it relates to minimum standards, wages and conditions whereby there are arbitrary means of adjusting those—the Commonwealth legislation will not override it. Quite frankly, I believe that this is one of the reasons that the government will not support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard Senator Bell refer to the no disadvantage rule. What I have to say will be of interest to Senator Margetts as well because I will give a couple of examples. This happened in New South Wales. A Sydney based company reached an agreement with its employees to work four 10-hour shifts each week, for a number of reasons. One reason was to make it more flexible for its employees. Another was to maximise capital utilisation. More importantly, according to the company, it was to reduce the company's energy bill. The company was prepared to pay wage increases to supplement the change. It was agreed that a shift allowance of 30 per cent under the award be reduced to 15 per cent. The union intervened and refused to be party to the agreement on the basis that the cut would be a reduction in national standards.

PARA.TAB: Another example involves another New South Wales company. An agreement was made at the enterprise level to introduce annualised salaries and to buy out annual leave. The agreement was actually signed and agreed to by a state official. But, when the agreement went for certification, it was repudiated by the national official because it did not fit in with union policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —But under the current act you can't reduce standards; you don't understand that.

—This is not a reduction in an award standard. Senator Murphy is so inflexible. That is the whole problem with this country. We are trying to do things which are for the benefit of the employee as well as the employer. We want to introduce some flexibility to make us more productive and give people the incentive to invest so that employment is increased. It is interesting that Senator Murphy interjected because the other day he made the point that—I am going off the subject a little, but the sort of nonsense we get from Senator Murphy gives me an opportunity to respond to him—if people were to become more productive, how on earth could it increase employment.

PARA.TAB: I will not go into that right now because we are short of time. But, if Senator Murphy wants to have a look at page 7 or 8 of the Industry Commission report, he will get all the answers. If Senator Murphy can read, he might come back here with a different response. This is the sort of nonsense we hear when we get this so-called no disadvantage rule and the overlap between state and federal jurisdictions. I could not agree more with my colleague Senator Crane that we are a Commonwealth. We are made up of states. To have everybody dressed up—as those opposite would like them to be—in Chairman Mao tunics, from an industrial relations point of view, is a nonsense and a recipe for continuing—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I rise on a point of order. All I sought to do was raise with Senator Parer the very fact that he was saying—

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McGauran)—This should not be a personal explanation. What is your point of order, Senator Murphy?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Parer stated something that was blatantly incorrect.

—There is no point of order. Senator Murphy, I cut you off because we may very well have a very long night ahead of us and the more points of order that are taken and the more interjections that are made, the longer we will be here.

—Senator Murphy has raised the issue of International Labour Organisation conventions with regard to the amendment moved by Senator Crane on behalf of the opposition. I simply want to make the point that the fact that ILO conventions are being used to impose uniform minimum standards in this country simply reinforces the need for the amendment moved tonight by Senator Crane. I believe it is highly dangerous for us to be using ILO conventions in terms of establishing domestic law—both as a nation and indeed, as Senator Parer mentioned, as a Commonwealth of states. As an independent nation, surely we can legislate for our own requirements without relying on International Labour Organisation conventions and recommendations, which in fact may or may not be constitutional.

PARA.TAB: Even more importantly, we need to recognise that the states are sovereign in their own right and that it ought not be the practice of this Commonwealth government to use the external affairs power in the way it is in this legislation to ride roughshod over the states in their jurisdiction. It is only through the use of these ILO conventions and recommendations that the federal government is able to do that. In this way we are of course sacrificing the sovereignty of Australia to an international organisation. If this situation were not so serious it would be laughable. As my colleague Senator Kemp has said on a number of occasions in this chamber, the number of United Nations and international conventions that this government is agreeing to and using as the basis for legislation in Australia is quite laughable. On the one hand the government is doing that but on the other it is arguing that we ought to become a republic because we need to express greater independence. The government is so inconsistent. If those opposite cannot see that, something is wrong with their logic. We are quite capable of determining our own legislative needs without relying on those conventions or sacrificing our independence in that way.

As I said, the more important issue is the way in which these conventions are being used to ride roughshod over state sovereignty within what ought to be state jurisdiction. That is particularly so where state governments have recently obtained a mandate for their policies with regard to industrial relations. Senator Crane has already pointed out the way in which that has happened in Western Australia. In South Australia, the Liberal Party has very clearly spelt out what its approach to industrial relations will be when it wins government on Saturday. There is absolutely no justification whatsoever for this government implementing the means of riding roughshod over that new government's approach to industrial relations by the use of the ILO conventions and recommendations. That is exactly what it will be doing by using—or, should I say, abusing—the external affairs power in this way.

In doing that the government is not only riding roughshod over the states but it is also the very antithesis of what it says this legislation is designed to encourage—which is greater flexibility and a more enterprise based approach to employer-employee relations. The very antithesis of that is setting down minimum national standards when the very essence of enterprise agreements is to have variations based on the individual needs of individual firms and also individual regions. Those opposite are denying the opportunity for variations between states that ought to be the essence of a freed-up approach to industrial relations. There are differences between regions; there are differences between states. The agreements that are reached between employers and employees ought to have the capacity to reflect those differences. But, again, that will not occur because of the way in which these international conventions are being used to ride roughshod over states rights and state jurisdictions.

The result is that we will not obtain the flexibility that this country desperately needs in industrial relations. Different regions will not have the capacity to improve their local productivity for the overall benefit of Australia's productivity and for the improvement of the living standards of all Australians. It is on that basis that this amendment ought to be supported and incorporated in this legislation, to at least water down to some extent the way in which this government is using or, as I said earlier, abusing the external affairs power to impose uniformity on the states.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have made my contribution and outlined our position here, but Senator Parer chose to comment on something that I said so I wish to address that. Before I do, I think we should put the role of the International Labour Organisation in perspective. It is a tripartite body consisting of representatives from government, the work force and employer groups. In fact, Australia's most senior representative at the International Labour Organisation is the representative of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. He is the longest serving Australian at that organisation and has a very important position.

PARA.TAB: At the latest meeting of the ILO in Geneva in the middle of this year the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry was represented, as was the coalition through Mr Howard and as was the Tasmanian state Liberal government through its Minister for Employment, Industrial Relations and Training. It is wrong to project an image of the ILO as being other than a tripartite organisation. In fact, the representatives of the employer groups were keen to implement some of the conventions and findings of the ILO, particularly with regard to the 10,000-member minimum union size. As well as that Mr Noakes, the ACCI representative—

TALK.START.PARA: —You supported that.
—In fact, I did not; the honourable senator should check up on that. Mr Noakes was able to influence and implement several ILO recommendations and conventions.
—I apologise; your colleagues supported it.

—I think the coalition should be eager to look up things such as the matter of access to assets during insolvency, for example. That matter was discussed and a decision was arrived at with which Australia now complies, much to the advantage of those who are clamouring over the assets of an insolvent group. I think it is irresponsible to project it as other than a tripartite body which serves the interests of all groups very well. It is because it does so that it has managed to survive for the incredibly long period that it has.

PARA.TAB: I want to address Senator Parer's remarks on the no disadvantage test. The examples Senator Parer gave occurred under the existing act. They were not satisfactory situations. I do not believe a situation such as the one Senator Parer described should be supported, and we should not allow it to occur in the future. That is why we have this Industrial Relations Reform Bill in front of us. We are changing it; that is what we are doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to refer to Senator Chapman's comments on the ILO. There has been a lot of comment during this debate about the ILO, as to whether we ought to be listening to such an organisation. Ironically, I have not heard members on either side of the chamber state that they are worried about the fact that if the Uruguay Round of the GATT is signed on 15 December we will be handing over a lot of powers to an international organisation which is not the least bit democratic: the multilateral trade organisation for the GATT. This will mean that our conditions covering the environment, workers' health and safety, trade rules and so on will be dictated by a non-democratic international organisation. I do not hear anybody on either side of the chamber complaining about that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on a few points. The first is the support given by the Australian Democrats to the use of overseas conventions to determine our law in Australia. I think that is an utter disgrace. I heard the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) say that we are making our own law. That is correct; we are preparing our own legislation. In the back of this document we have all these ILO conventions. Why on earth, when preparing our law, does the government need to rely on these other conventions?

PARA.TAB: There is one convention the minister might like to address. Maybe we have deteriorated as a country, but I still thought we would have been categorised as a developed country. But I am mistaken. Schedule 5 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Convention concerning minimum wage fixing, with special reference to developing countries.

That is embodied in this act—`with special reference to developing countries'. Obviously the government is relying on this. I think that is a disgrace. Senator Murphy said, quite incorrectly, that the government went to the last election spelling out exactly what was in this act, or the direction of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that. What I said was that we said we would change industrial relations to represent international conventions.

—I think the honourable senator is drawing a big straw. My recollection of the last election was that the organ grinders in the ACTU were going around to all the workshops, all the hospitals and all the schools and were saying, `If you vote Liberal you will lose your job and 50,000 public servants will be put out of work'.
—Blatant lies, they were.

—We had to counteract that. That was the game being played. We all know—and it is silly for those opposite to pretend otherwise because the Labor Party is the political arm of the ACTU—that the ACTU has come back to collect. I am concerned to know whether this is the final bill or whether it is only the first instalment.

PARA.TAB: Going back to what Senator Murphy said about going to the election and telling people what was going to be done, the Labor Party's own Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Minister Brereton in September of this year did not know what was going to be done. Every time Minister Brereton came out—I presume he did so in good faith, I do not know; maybe he was fooling the whole lot of us—he made statements—

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the things I did say, Senator Parer, was that we would protect the award system.

—He made statements to the effect that he would allow enterprise bargaining, and particularly within the non-union sector. That was in about June. In April the Prime Minister made the same remarks. In August we had a similar thing. Then, lo and behold, on 17 September there was a media report—we all have to rely on media reports to hear what the organ grinder is up to, as do those opposite, the monkeys—that the minister and the ACTU had finally reached a deal. It was nothing to do with the employers, small business people or employees—the workers. The report said that this further entrenched union power and did nothing to facilitate effective enterprise bargaining. I know that this is really not related to this particular amendment, but Senator Murphy raised it and it would be improper of me to let it go past the keeper without commenting on it.

—I would like to pick up two or three things that have been mentioned. I will do so in the order in which honourable senators have spoken. Senator Margetts jumped up and said that in Western Australia there is a $275 adult wage. She forgot to mention a number of things in that regard. That is the minimum to start with. There are also additional things such as four weeks holiday leave, sick leave, paternity leave, maternity leave and adoption leave, which are not in this federal bill. I do not know whether that is the full list, but I wanted to point out that there are a number of other things.

PARA.TAB: Senator Margetts and everybody else on that side of the chamber must realise that Western Australia did not give a mandate to the federal Labor government to make these changes—just look at what happened in Western Australia during the federal election. But I do not want to debate that. Senator Murphy and Senator Margetts must realise that just 12 months ago Western Australia had close to the highest unemployment rate. It now has the lowest, and it is falling. Western Australia is the state where investment is happening, and that investment is increasing.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not as a result of the new industrial relations bill.

—It is the result of a different philosophy and an expectation that people can get on with the job because they have a government that is prepared to take some of the hard decisions across the full spectrum of issues—including industrial relations—and that is why confidence is coming back. It is also another reason why export dollars are returning to Western Australia in growing volume to the benefit of all Australians.

PARA.TAB: It is beyond me why the Commonwealth wants to get involved in what is going on in Western Australia. The Western Australian government is quite capable of running its own affairs. It is totally misleading to stand up and pick unemployment in Western Australia as the be-all and end-all of the argument. In this country we have to address unemployment. The one state that is really doing something about it—I am not saying that no other states are doing the same—is Western Australia and, what is more, it is succeeding in tackling the problem.

Senator Bell referred to the no disadvantage test. Unfortunately, this matter was discussed at one of the hearings at which Senator Bell was not present. However, departmental officers at the committee hearing made it quite clear, as did a number of other witnesses, that the no disadvantage test in this bill was no different to that which existed in the previous act.

The point Senator Parer made about the impact of that no disadvantage test is as valid now as were some of the complaints we made about the restrictive nature of that test in previous debates on this legislation. Honourable senators can check the Hansard for the evidence given to us in that inquiry but, effectively, they will find that there has been no change to the flexibility of that no disadvantage test.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are right. That is what the Hansard says, but he was talking about union intervention.
—I am sorry, but Senator Bell related it to the no disadvantage test.
—No, he was talking about union intervention.

—Senator Bell can check the Hansard in the morning. This amendment attempts to allow those states to introduce flexibility to the no disadvantage test to address some of the broader economic problems we have in this country and to give the nearly one million unemployed some hope of getting a job.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a lot of discussion on this Industrial Relations Reform Bill but I will be referring to those aspects of it that relate to the clause under consideration. We hear a great deal of selective quotation of mandate theories in this country—people always have mandates for the bits they want and not for the bits they do not want, and oppositions always regard governments as having mandates only for the bits they choose to remember. I remind opposition senators that this government was elected subsequent to the election of the state Liberal government in Western Australia and, if a mandate is applicable there, ours is more current. I regard the mandate argument as a whole lot of nonsense.
—Well, you've got no mandate in Western Australia, Bob.
—Sadly, I must remind the honourable senator that we had already won the election before his results came in. That is why he is over there at deep backward square leg and we are here at point.
—You've been on about that a lot today.
—The way I saw things going a little earlier, it is probably the only cricket we will win today.
—You had better watch the square drive.

—I am not sure what the current score is; it was not looking too good when I last saw it. I do not want to take the mandate issue too seriously but let me get down to the matters of substance. One is the balance between fairness and flexibility. Senator Murphy was absolutely correct: there was a lot of debate about industrial relations in the course of the last election campaign—it was the second most important election issue.

PARA.TAB: What distinguished the government from the coalition was that, while the coalition was talking about flexibility, we were talking about striking a balance between fairness and flexibility. And that is what distinguishes the debate on this legislation—while everybody else is looking for more flexibility, we are looking for flexibility within a framework that guarantees fairness.

The opposition is trying to take out the fairness and leave the flexibility—in other words, downward flexibility. As the opposition sees it, the contest is about having more flexibility to take conditions down further. For the opposition, it is not a question of whether we have flexibility but whether that flexibility can be taken down further, and Senator Margetts and Senator Murphy made absolutely valid points on that issue.

People become fussed about whether we heed our international obligations under the ILO. As a matter of general principle we should but the application of any international convention is a matter for this parliament. No convention has the force of law in this country unless this parliament votes to make it so. That is the correct situation for a sovereign nation in an international environment.

While we recognise that there are things which, because of our international obligations, we are obliged to consider, if the parliament does not vote for them, they do not become the law of Australia. Although this issue is a man of straw that the opposition wants to beat to death between now and the next election, it will not stand up; it is just too weak to run, even as a debating point.

Now and again the states rights position is trotted out. Australians live in states. If ever there is a contest between states rights and the rights of people, I will always support the rights of people. People have rights, states do not have rights; governments do not have rights, people do.

TALK.START.PARA: —The people of Western Australia have rights which you are not listening to.

—Western Australians have rights but the state does not have any and nor should it any more than the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth does not have rights; it has responsibilities and powers which it is entitled to exercise when the parliament votes accordingly.

PARA.TAB: The contest in this amendment does not arise from the furphy about mandates, sovereignty or states rights; it is about how low the conditions and standards of workers can be driven in the name of so-called flexibility or whether we will have a balance between flexibility and fairness. The amendment goes to the core of the bill, which is why the government does not support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister spoke about the ILO conventions. I am pleased to see that those conventions are written in English. The conventions included in the bill refer to the fact that `the English and French versions are equally authoritative'. I thought the major language was English, yet we have a document which refers to English and French versions.

PARA.TAB: The minister also said that, from an industrial relations point of view, whether one lives in Cape York, Perth, Port Augusta, Tasmania or Canberra, somehow the wages, terms and conditions of employment should be absolutely identical across the board.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't make it up, Warwick.

—That is what he was saying. If that argument is followed to its logical conclusion, the government will put through legislation which says that the price of a house in Sydney will be the same as in Brisbane.
—No.

—It will. This is the sort of thing it is saying. Everyone knows, for instance, that the cost of living in a place like Sydney is higher. When we get into the post-industrial phase—there are a lot of people in computer work and things like that—the people who live and work in a place like Sydney generally get paid more than someone who works in a similar job and lives in a place like Tamworth.This is what this legislation is trying to overcome. It wants everyone dressed up the same. The net result of it will be that jobs will not be provided. I made this point in my speech in the second reading debate. I did not hear any response then and I still have not heard anyone say how this particular piece of legislation is going to create jobs.

PARA.TAB: The view across the board of the people who provide those jobs—the people who make the investments, whether they be big companies, medium companies or small businesses—is that this particular piece of legislation will be a disincentive to investment, which means a disincentive to employment. I would have thought that this is the last thing in the world this country needs. I make that point only because the government talks about no disadvantage—and I gave some examples. Once this becomes entrenched, with people able to jump from one to the other, which is what this particular clause provides, as we all know, that will be the eventual result.

I will finish with one little example. A couple of years ago I went to Korea and one of the people who went with me was Senator Burns. He had made up his mind before he went there that if a country was successful the workers were oppressed—a very old left wing socialist idea. He looked around desperately for these oppressed workers. Senator Burns is an honest man and I think if he were asked him he would say that he could not find any.

We did meet up with the trade union people in Korea and they mentioned that a particular company had given a 23 per cent wage increase—I think it was Hyundai, the motor car company. Senator Burns, in the typical Australian union officials' thinking—no reflection on Senator Burns—said, `I presume this flowed on across the economy'. The Korean union official said, `Senator Burns, we are trying to build industry in Korea, not destroy it'. That is the point I am making—that once we try to standardise and centralise, which is what those opposite are talking about, we will further destroy the job prospects of people, particularly young people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address the points raised by Senator Parer he gave examples of union interference. If I understood his example correctly, he said that there was an agreement reached that sought to reduce the shift penalty from 30 per cent to 15 per cent. That was agreed to by the workers but the union came along and said, `No. That is a reduction of national standards so you can't do it'. Is that correct?
—State officials agreed.

—Let me get right the basic point Senator Parer was making. If he was referring to federal legislation, there is no capacity under the current act for national standards to be reduced—varied, yes, even as it stands now before we finally get to the new bill—but we cannot reduce award standards either in certified agreements or under any other aspect of the current Industrial Relations Act. The commission could not do it. What the union was actually saying was quite correct. Whether the union said it or not, if the agreement was sought to be registered in the federal Industrial Relations Commission, the commission would not have been able to do so because the act, as it currently stands, would not have allowed that to happen.

PARA.TAB: The other point I want to make quickly is that, with respect to Senator Parer's condemnation of our seeking to implement ILO conventions, we, along with I do not how many countries, are, in fact, members of the International Labour Organisation and it is a representative body, as pointed out by Senator Bell, made up of employer, government and opposition representatives, state and federal representatives, et cetera. Article 1, which Senator Parer chose not to mention, states:

Each Member of the International Labour Organisation which ratifies this Convention undertakes to establish a system of minimum wages which covers all groups of wage earners whose terms of employment are such that the coverage would be appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: That is exactly what we are seeking to do. That is what we said at the last election we would do. That is why, as Senator McMullan has pointed out, we sought to maintain flexibility and fairness. Those opposite, in neither their policy nor anything that they have said in this debate here tonight or in the committee in terms of the question they raised about employment, have not given any examples of how their policy or anything that they have said would increase employment. It would not. The fact is that we had that obligation and what we said at the last election is that we would uphold it. As the minister has pointed out, what those opposite seek to do is nothing short of reducing the conditions of work and the wages that people in this country earn. That is why we must oppose this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of comments in response to Senator Parer's remarks about my conversation with trade unionists in South Korea. It is true that I did give them advice about how they should go about trying to increase their wages and improve their working conditions. I also put some propositions to those in management at the Hyundai shipyard about the need to have good relations with the unions and I asked questions about how they managed to do that. They said that they consulted with the unions all the time and that they had really good relations with them. A few months after we left South Korea there was a strike by the workers in that shipyard who were seeking nothing but justice and a reasonable set of wages—and the government sent in the troops and the police, and people were bashed up. That is how good the South Korean cooperation is in certain areas where there are real and active trade unionists in that country.
—I just perhaps—

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McGauran)—Senator Parer, we should not drag this particular point out too long. We do not want to be discussing overseas trips.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the fact that that amendment was lost, we have an alternative amendment. Maybe I could take the opportunity of talking about another one of Senator Burns's trips somewhere else, but I shall not.
—Don't give the ball to Senator Parer.
—Senator Murphy is going to inspire me to take off if he keeps going. We did get out to somewhere in the west of Queensland and got some information from the AWU, if I remember correctly. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3)Clause 12, page 6, paragraph (b), proposed paragraph 111 (1G)(c), lines 1 to 11, omit the proposed paragraph.

I have already given the explanation for the previous amendment. This is an alternative position. We believe that the previous amendment was the preferred position. The government has decided otherwise, so I have so moved.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Clause 12, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 12, page 6, insert the following clause:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Repeal of limitation on Commission's power to remove sex discrimination

PARA.TAB: "12A.Subsection 113(2B) of the Principal Act is repealed.".

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this amendment is to repeal the limitation on the commission's power to remove sex discrimination. It removes the outdated subsection in the principal act—that is, the Industrial Relations Act 1988. With respect to helping to prevent and eliminate discrimination in our society, a glaring inconsistency exists in the Industrial Relations Act 1988. This occurs in section 113(2B). That allows discrimination against women to continue in awards if it is `in the public interest'. We consider this exemption to be a remnant of a bygone era. The Sex Discrimination Act does not require the commissioner to take into account economic or other factors in determining whether or not discrimination should be allowed, so why should the Industrial Relations Commission be allowed such leeway? Accordingly, this amendment subjects industrial awards to the full force of the Sex Discrimination Act.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government accepts the amendment. Obviously, we share the objective behind the amendment, because it relates to a piece of legislation that we passed previously; otherwise we would not be accepting it. But there is some apprehension about it because section 113(2B) is designed to give the commission the opportunity to take into account a circumstance where there might be a discriminatory section which may be, for example, favourable in particular circumstances to a group of workers. But it seems inconceivable that the Sex Discrimination Commissioner would refer such a matter, so I think it is highly unlikely to cause a problem.

PARA.TAB: I give notice that the government will further examine whether there should be some provision which does allow positive discrimination or which allows discriminatory awards to be remedied in stages. We may need to look subsequently at further matters with regard to this. But the thrust of the amendment is consistent with what we are trying to achieve and we are therefore prepared to accept it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment. For the reasons outlined by Senator Margetts, we think it is appropriate that this amendment be made. We think it is not appropriate that at the moment economic considerations can be elevated above anti-discrimination principles. We do not think that is appropriate at this stage of the country's development, nor is it in concert with what is expected of a democratic society. The Greens' amendment would prevent economic considerations overriding the Sex Discrimination Act. We think that is thoroughly appropriate and we will support it.

—I would like to raise a question in relation to this matter. I know that when I have represented employees, a situation has often arisen where more favourable consideration needed to be given to women in respect of particular areas. I refer, for example, to women working in an environment containing lead. There has been a need to protect pregnant women in that regard. I understand and accept the spirit of the amendment. Senator Margetts did send a copy of this amendment to me but because I am trying to take one thing at a time I did not have the opportunity of raising the issue with her before now. I apologise for that.

PARA.TAB: In acknowledging and accepting the principle that she seeks to obtain, perhaps the minister could seek some advice as to whether in those circumstances the commission would be prevented from awarding a provision that would give that sort of protection. Another example is that in the factories, shops and offices act there used to be a provision in regard to the lifting of weights. That gave certain protection to women in respect of the lifting of weights in that employers were not able to instruct female employees to lift weights over a certain limit. I raise those points for consideration by the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to follow up what Senator Harradine said. Maybe the minister could give us a response on this matter. There was a case that went on in Mount Isa for some years. Mr Temporary Chairman, you may remember that from your industrial days. The company was actually sued because it would not put women in an area where there was a very high lead concentration. It knew, as everyone else knew, that it was highly dangerous for females who could potentially become pregnant to work in such an area as their children could be affected. I think it is only in the last three weeks that a decision has been made that enables the company not to employ women in that area of the mine. I would be most concerned if an unintended consequence of an amendment like this overturned that decision.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Both Senator Harradine and Senator Parer have raised an issue that reflected my initial reaction to the amendment. It is something about which I wished to reassure myself. I tried to address it in my initial comments in response to the amendment, but perhaps I was too cryptic. There are two safeguards against those concerns that have been raised and I will also make a further comment.

PARA.TAB: The first safeguard, of course, is that section 113 arises only if the Sex Discrimination Commissioner chooses to refer a matter to the Industrial Relations Commission. It seems unlikely that the Sex Discrimination Commissioner would choose to refer something which was discriminating positively in favour of women. That is the first hurdle—not of itself probably sufficient to reassure us, but it is a significant first element.

The second element—and I do not have the legislation in front of me—is that, consistent with other measures such as the Racial Discrimination Act, my understanding and advice is that there is a similar special measures provision in the Sex Discrimination Act that enables discrimination that is in favour of women in this particular instance; that is not, therefore, considered discriminatory in terms of the Sex Discrimination Act. If something would not constitute discrimination under the Sex Discrimination Act, it does not constitute discrimination under this section. So those are the two protections.

Our view at the moment is that those protections are sufficient, but I did say—because I acknowledge that other people share the concern which Senator Parer and Senator Harradine have raised—that the government will continue an examination of whether we need a provision which allows positive discrimination or enables the remedying of a discriminatory award in a staged manner. On the advice I have at the moment, this amendment achieves the positive purpose that we all support without the negative consequences about which Senator Harradine and Senator Parer have apprehension. I am advised that we can be confident that that is the case, but to be absolutely certain we will conduct a further examination in case there is a need for some qualification to deal with that risk.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding was that the reason the Mount Isa case went as far as it did and for as long as it did is that it was in breach of the Sex Discrimination Act. So when Senator McMullan is looking at the matter, I recommend that he take that point into account.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Clauses 13 and 14—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 15.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment (5) is, in effect, an additional government amendment relating to pay rates. The effect of the amendment as circulated is to omit this clause. So, in fact, we are opposing the clause.
—Opposing your own legislation!

—Manufactured outrage is getting a bit commonplace around here, Senator Chapman. I would not bother any more. This provision will appear in a different part of the legislation—under the paid rates award section. It has been separately set down, so it is no longer appropriate to have it here; it is not a limit of substance. If people have a pro or anti view about the substance, we will deal with it when we get to the paid rates award section.

—My comments on clause 15 will be brief and to the point. I think this is a classic example of how not to handle legislation. We made these points yesterday in the debate, in terms of the reference of this back to a committee, but we find ourselves in a position where even the government's own legislation is being re-arranged on the run as it hits the Senate. I just want to make the point that we on this side of the chamber believe it is a very unsatisfactory way to do business.

PARA.TAB: I also want to make the point that that committee, having done the work that it did in terms of what was supposedly the position of the government, found itself—and I say that as a member of the committee—having to revisit an enormous amount of the work that was done. In addition to that, we find that those organisations and individuals who submitted to that first hearing now find themselves in a position where what they were responding to has been significantly changed to the point where we find a new part being put into the legislation. I think it is unsatisfactory.
Clause negatived.
Clause 16 agreed to.
Clause 17.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 7.Clause 17, page 9, after proposed paragraph 150A(2)(a), insert the following paragraph:

"(ab) the award contains a provision which discriminates against an employee because of, or for reasons including, race, colour, sex, sexual preference, age, physical or mental disability, marital status, family responsibilities, pregnancy, religion, political opinion, national extraction or social origin;".

Clause 17 requires the Family Responsibilities Commission, when reviewing awards under the new section 150A, to remedy any discrimination provisions. It is consistent with the other anti-discrimination provisions in parts of the bill and is a response to a shortcoming that was identified by Senator Margetts. After some discussion, the position of the Australian Democrats was reviewed and we have proposed an alternative which we believe is a slight improvement. We thank the Western Australian Greens for drawing our attention to that shortcoming. Also, we think it is thoroughly appropriate to discuss, in some detail, alternatives to achieve the same ends.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government accepts this amendment for the reasons which were debated at somewhat great length previously.

—The opposition will not support this amendment. Again, it raises the question of sexual preference, which was debated at great length and which I will not go into in detail right now. We have here a provision which prevents discrimination in respect of race, colour, sex, age, physical or mental disabilities—which again was debated previously, as were problems associated with that in certain circumstances—marital status, family responsibilities, pregnancy, religion, political opinion, national extraction and social origin. Apart from the fact that the sexual preference side is bizarre, how will the government determine it? Will it ask everyone what his or her sexual preference is? Will people tell the government?

PARA.TAB: The amendment also talks about political opinion, but it does not provide for discrimination in respect of a person who may not be a union member. If the government is to be genuine about this matter, people must have the freedom to decide whether they will be a member of a union or not. For those reasons, which are multitudinous—and as the other items were debated at great length earlier in this committee stage of the bill—I will not go through the list again. This is the sort of nonsensical stuff that this country is plagued with. It is probably a major reason why we have some of the problems we have in Australia today and why we have disincentives for people to employ workers on a full-time basis. I think it is reflected in the work force. It is reflected in the fact that a lot more employers are employing people on a casual basis. It is because of these implications, restrictions and difficulties that occur and the regulations that apply when someone is employed on a full-time basis. It is a very sad reflection on where we are going.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Parer has said, this particular issue was debated at length this morning and I do not want to repeat in detail what I said, except to again express my concern that this amendment denies particular people the opportunity—or what ought to be their inherent right—to run their businesses according to their own individual consciences. That, I believe, is to be deplored. Whatever we might think about the particular attitudes of people, it ought to be their right to run their businesses according to their consciences. This amendment simply denies them that opportunity and, on that basis alone, it ought to be opposed.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Clause 17, page 9, after proposed paragraph 150A(2)(d), insert the following paragraph:
"(e) the award prescribes matters in unnecessary detail;".
I think this amendment is fairly self-explanatory and that most people will be sympathetic with what it seeks to do. If there is any debate on this amendment, I will respond subsequently.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 18 to 20—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 21.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3)Clause 21, page 12, after proposed subsection 170AE(4), insert the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "`(4A)Before making an order, the Commission must give each of the following an opportunity, as prescribed, to be heard in relation to the making of the order:
(a) the person who applied for the order;

SPEECH.PARA: (b) each employer of employees to be covered by the order.".
Once again, this amendment is self-explanatory. I am happy to enter into debate if anyone wishes to raise any concerns.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
