SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 21, page 16, after proposed subsection 170CA(1), insert the following subsection:

"`(1A) Without limiting subsection (1), the references in paragraph 170DF(1)(e) to sexual preference, age and physical or mental disability, have been included in order to give effect, or further effect, to:

PARA.TAB: (a)the Convention concerning Discrimination in respect of Employment and Occupation, a copy of the English text of which is set out in Schedule 1 to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 ; and

TAB.TAB: (b)the Recommendation referred to in paragraph 170BA(c).".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment inserts new grounds in the criteria under which employment can be terminated. It inserts a new subsection (1A). Without reading the whole of the amendment, it is again relevant to discrimination. To facilitate its passage, Senator Kernot will have some relevant comments to add when we deal with subsequent amendments which are all concurrent with this.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4)Clause 21, page 17, at the end of proposed section 170DB, add the following subsections:

PARA.TAB: "`(4)The amount of compensation instead of notice must equal or exceed the total of all amounts that, if the employee's employment had continued until the end of the required period of notice, the employer would have become liable to pay to the employee because of the employment continuing during that period.
"`(5) That total must be worked out on the basis of:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the employee's ordinary hours of work (even if they are not standard hours); and
(b)the amounts payable to the employee in respect of those hours, including (for example) allowances, loadings and penalties; and
(c)any other amounts payable under the employee's contract of employment.".

This amendment supplements the existing provision of the bill which generally requires a specified period of notice or compensation instead of notice for termination. The amendment makes it clear what amount an employee should receive and the amount the employee would have received if the employment had continued for the period. I think it is what most people would have expected, but it makes the position clearer.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4)Clause 21, page 18, after proposed paragraph 170DF(1)(b), insert the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(ba)non-membership of a union or of an association that has applied to be registered as a union under the provisions of the Principal Act;".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment prevents employers from terminating people's employment on certain grounds. It gives non-unionists the same rights on termination of employment as anybody else in the work force. We have heard a lot today about discrimination and fairness and equity between people and extensions. I believe it is an absolute and total blight on the government that it could bring in legislation which, in itself, discriminates against 70 per cent of employees in this country who do not wish to belong to a union or have chosen not to, for whatever reason. That is their business, and I do not want to go into that. The intention of this amendment is to put right that gross wrong.

PARA.TAB: I put it to the government that, if it is serious about the use of the word `fairness'—we have heard about that from the other side of this chamber tonight—the use of the word `equity' and about having harmony between those people who choose to join a union and those who choose the alternative of not belonging to a union, those people should at least have the same laws of the land applying to them when it comes to dealing with their termination or, for that matter, anything else. I put it to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) that this amendment is about fairness, equity and treating people in the same manner with respect to termination from the workplace. I commend this amendment to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by Senator Crane. Anyone who has ever worked in the business sector, whether it be from the union point of view or the employer point of view, will know only too well that over the years unions have pressured employers to dismiss workers who refuse to join in a closed shop arrangement. It has been a common practice. There has been an example of that in our own state, and it is nice to see Senator Kernot in here, where in the last couple of months Reg Gordge, a 62-year-old concreter working on the Coolum project—it was being built by Curry-Kenny Investments; that is, Lisa Curry and Grant Kenny, two sportspeople in Australia—had just pulled his boots on when he was told he could not work unless he joined the union.

PARA.TAB: The way the BLF and a lot of militant left wing unions work is to come along, as they did in this instance on the Gold Coast—I can quote other examples of this; it is not a single example—and say, `This is a construction site'. For those who are uninitiated, and a lot of small business people are, their question is, `What does that mean?'. The answer is, `It means that everyone on this site has to be a member of our union otherwise the site is declared black and all work will stop'. That is the way it works.

People can argue that that is not legal and all that sort of thing, but that is how it happens out in the real world. I had one small business person phone me up when this happened to him and say, `What do I do?'. I said, `Well, if you are a man of principle, you will resist it, but you will go broke'. An example is the Indy race at the Gold Coast, where the Queensland government was putting up the money for the work being done. Obviously, the business could expect no support from it, so the business paid up. The union works on the basis that the employer will pay to send it away. The union has no interest in the membership—the names of the people. A member could be called `Mickey Mouse' as far as it is concerned, as long as the money—a couple of thousand dollars—is paid over. In this instance, Reg Gordge said:
A BLF official was checking that workers at the 24-unit Pandanus Coolum project were members.
`They all joined. I was the only one who refused,' Mr Gordge said.
`It's just a principle to me. I can't see how any union can send you off a job'.

SPEECH.PARA: He learnt. They sent him off the job, all right. He also said that there was no sense in paying $136 in union membership fees when he only had three days work on the site. That is why earlier I made the point that the union would not care about that. It works on the basis that, when it puts the pressure on, the employer will often say, `Look, here's the money, so go away, leave us alone and don't declare the site black'.

PARA.TAB: This amendment prevents an employer from dismissing an employee for not being a member of a union. It does not affect the fact that, if someone is a member of the union, that person can stay on the job. There is nothing to prevent that from happening. It ensures that workers cannot be dismissed without redress, wherever they live.

In the House of Representatives, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, claimed that the amendment was constitutionally unsound because it went beyond the specific grounds listed in—here it comes again—the ILO's convention concerning termination of employment at the initiative of the employer. The coalition has been advised that, due to the structure of the convention—it hurts me to talk about conventions because we do not believe in using overseas conventions as the basis for domestic legislation—the amendment will be constitutional if the government's termination provisions are constitutional. That is the legal advice that we have.

Mr Temporary Chairman, it seems to me that if we really believe in democracy and freedom in this country—I was privileged to hear you talk about democracy in this country in an earlier debate—a person should not be dismissed for being a member of a union, nor should a person be dismissed for not being a member of a union.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations, as I understand it, said in the House of Representatives that he did not have any objection to the principle reflected in this amendment. However, he expressed reservations about the legal foundation for it, as Senator Parer described. Although Senator Parer feels uncomfortable about quoting ILO conventions, there is no doubt that the Commonwealth would not have the power to do this were it not for the ILO convention. Mr Brereton has sought the legal advice that he said he would seek. He undertook to examine Mr Howard's proposal further and to consult with unions and employers.

PARA.TAB: The legal situation is not crystal clear. There is some advice that goes in the direction that Senator Parer has indicated. These issues will need to be examined and we will need to continue to talk with the unions and the employers. That will be done. The government's position—which does not differ from our approach to the matter raised previously by Senate Margetts—is that the principle is okay. The balance of legal advice seems to be that it is something we can do, so we will accept the amendment, but we will have to have some further discussion and look at the law. If there is a problem, we will have to come back to the Senate—everybody acknowledges that—but we are accepting the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the advice from the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services that the government is going to accept the amendment moved by Senator Crane on behalf of the opposition. Undoubtedly, without that amendment, this clause writes large the one-sided nature of this legislation. Without that amendment, this clause lists the grounds on which an employer cannot terminate the employment of an employee. Those grounds include membership of a union and participation in union activities. It excludes the prevention of an employer terminating the employment of an employee because he or she does not belong to a trade union.

PARA.TAB: That is the essence of the amendment that has been moved by Senator Crane—to include non-membership of a trade union as a reason whereby an employer cannot dismiss an employee. That is a very important amendment to the legislation because it highlights the importance of the individual over the collective. Without that amendment, this clause, as originally drafted by the government, clearly elevates the collective over the individual. That demonstrates the priority of this government: it gives a much higher priority to the collective than it does to the rights of the individual. To some extent, although this legislation still remains very unbalanced, the amendment moved by Senator Crane will redress that imbalance to some extent. To some extent, it will redress the imbalance of a piece of legislation that has been drafted for the benefit of a mere 30 per cent of the work force in the private sector who are members of a collective—trade unions—as against the 70 per cent who prefer to retain their individuality and not belong to a trade union.

On that basis, I support the amendment and particularly welcome the government's willingness to accept it. It is good to see some sense and some measure of bipartisanship on this issue. It is a pity that the government does not exhibit the same sort of bipartisanship with the other sensible amendments that we moved earlier in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with a lot of interest to the 20-odd speeches on the second reading. I had intended to make some contribution at that time because I had many concerns—concerns coming from all sorts of angles—expressed to me by my constituents. For instance, only last week I was spoken to by furniture manufacturers in Tasmania who belonged to a particular religious group—and there were a number of contributions to that particular point today. I have had many communications from small business people in my state of Tasmania about their concerns with this legislation. Without getting into all the technicalities of this bill, I am quite pleased to hear that the government is supporting the amendment put forward by my colleague Senator Crane.

PARA.TAB: In the real world out there, having suffered a recession, small business is trying to survive and make a profit. When I heard the minister today talking about the rights of this group and the rights of that group, it made me wonder when someone was going to get back to reality and talk about the rights of a business person to make a profit. That is what this country is all about.

There are so many risk takers out there who have to survive. They have mortgaged their family homes and lifestyle to try to make a living the way people in this country were brought up to do. The people who are willing to work unlimited hours, not to be constricted by rules, regulations, red tape and all the rest of it, have made this country what it is.

I fear that the legislation in front of us today—there are 200 amendments to a bill that is three-quarters of an inch thick—is imposing on the workers and business people of Australia more regulations and telling them what they can do, who they can employ and what sex and sexuality their employees might be.

I wonder where this country is heading. Where have the entrepreneurs gone? Out the back door, I suggest. Where are those people who want to bring up their families, make a reasonable profit, work and do the sorts of things that our forebears did to make this country great.

Mr Temporary Chairman, and—through you—minister, I am pleased to hear that you have at least given those people who want to work and do not want to be members of unions the opportunity to do their bit for Australia. So many genuine concerns have been raised with me by small business people.

One small business, Alcast Distributors in Deloraine—a small wholesale distributor specialising in lighting, electrical and hardware—is only employing part-time employees because of our country's situation. Those small business people are hoping that when things improve they can employ these people full time. They believe that union interference will be detrimental to their business. They are urging me, through this parliament, to try to make their concerns known about this massive bill. They would like their lives made better so that they can improve their business and make those part-time employees into full-time employees.

The same thing goes for Arnott's Aluminium Windows at East Devonport. The people there believe, rightly or wrongly, that this bill, with all its ramifications, will affect their business. They believe that all the protection in this bill is for unions, not employers. That is why I am speaking tonight on this part of the bill. I am pleased that the minister is accepting one of our amendments.

This legislation is far different from what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) told the people earlier this year it was going to be. He told this country that enterprise bargaining was going to be the way we would see things go. But it has not turned out that way. We have ended up with a payback to the unions for the amount of work they did during the election campaign.

My only other concern—and it was raised today in question time—is how, with all this legislation, we are going to cope with militant unions. I would like the minister to tell me that. The Communications Workers Union, for example, is going to cut off our Christmas cards and everything else that comes into our offices, just because they believe, in this case, that they have been discriminated against by the government. I hope that in this industrial relations legislation there will be enough safeguards to protect employers and politicians against the actions of militant unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support this amendment. It is longstanding Democrat policy. We were very pleased to indicate to the coalition some time ago that we would agree enthusiastically with its amendment. I will not give a clayton's speech on the second reading, as Senator Calvert has done—perhaps wisely, as he did not contribute in that debate.

PARA.TAB: We heard several times from contributors such as Senator Parer and, perhaps, Senator Chapman that there are many industrial relations problems in this country at the moment. I made the point earlier that that is why we have an Industrial Relations Reform Bill, why I have spent so much time considering it and why I initiated one of the inquiries conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training in October 1992. Even that event gives the lie to the amazing circulation of the idea that this whole business has been rushed through this parliament without due consideration.

The amount of consideration is demonstrated by the fact that the coalition has examined the bill and prepared a number of amendments. One of them—this one—is particularly useful. We do not accept the government's almost excuse that there are some constitutional difficulties with it. I believe they can be—if not avoided—catered for.

What is demonstrated by this amendment is that the coalition can take an opportunity to improve industrial relations throughout Australia and address some of the fears expressed by Senator Calvert on behalf of his constituents, fears which may be genuine but which are probably misguided. These fears have been perpetuated by irresponsible journalism—I hesitate to call it journalism; it is writing—such as that which we saw in the Australian Financial Review recently. A column was addressed to termination payments and a so-called minefield which will confront employees seeking to terminate the jobs of their employees in certain situations. Most of the column was about an employee in a middle-management position being in receipt of a salary package, not being paid the award rate—mainly because there was not an award to cover the middle-management position which had been invented—usually in a company employing several hundred people.

I have received faxes and communications from all sorts of enterprises such as those Senator Calvert has described, small places employing probably three to seven people—sometimes a company employing just a few part-timers. These people have been alarmed by irresponsible scribblings which have sought to sensationalise this situation, suggesting they may be up for several thousand dollars when terminating people's employment. The first question I asked people—and I telephoned several dozen of them—was, `Do you pay your employees award wages?'. Many of them have had employees for 10, 15 or 20 years and have no desire to terminate their employment.

I asked, `If you did, would you comply with the award procedure?'. They all said they would because many of them pay above award wages. I said that I was sure they had no need to be alarmed by the irresponsible rubbish that had brought them to that position. They are the situations that need to be addressed when we look at our role in this place. People have had their fears inflamed unnecessarily by the suggestions of a couple of irresponsible journalistic expeditions out of the many hundreds that have analysed this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many people in this place who make decisions have actually employed people?
—Senator Calvert raises a question which I would like to address.
—Senator Bell, you can choose to ignore it. It is an interjection, it is unruly, and we have an agreement, it would seem, on this particular clause of the bill.

—I am well aware of that, and I would like to get on with it. A question often raised—it is a common fallacy—is that unless one has done it one cannot even consider it. Senator Calvert should recognise that, whether it is this legislation or legislation about pet animals, the content of legislation is based upon a great deal of advice from those who are experienced. It is not only advice from people who have been employed; it is financial, legal, social, physical, geographical and historical information. Whatever it is, the advice is the important thing; not what is in our brains. One of the few jobs in the world that a person can perform without any qualifications whatsoever is to serve in this place. All one needs to do is be capable of representing people.

PARA.TAB: That is a very important point because a great lack of representative skill has been demonstrated. If people think there has been no public discussion on this matter when we have had two public Senate inquiries into it, what have their representatives been doing? Have their representatives been telling them about it and seeking their advice and opinions on this matter? No. I think their representatives have been sadly lacking in not informing people of what has been going on with this legislation for over a year. While the Senate public inquiries have been conducted there has been a dearth of information shared amongst the people who will be directly affected by it. The reason for that lack of information is to be sheeted home directly to the failure of those who should be representing the people's concerns. Even though we do have agreement and even though we support this amendment, many issues have been raised by this clause which should be addressed.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Clause 21, page 18, proposed paragraph 170DF(1)(e), line 26, after "colour, sex,", insert "sexual preference, age, physical or mental disability,".

I want to comment on Senator Calvert's interjection of just a few minutes ago. I do so as one who has actually been an employer, at times employing a couple of hundred tradesmen. I cannot recall one occasion when I would have felt impelled to dispense with the services of an employee on any of these grounds unless there were other reasons to do so. I may have dispensed with the services of an aged tradesperson, but I would have done so for other reasons. I recall one tradesman of 58 years who was better than many of 25. Certainly, I would not have dreamt of considering whether or not I should employ a person depending on his or her sexual preference. I did not know; it was of no interest. I welcome this opportunity to move this amendment and look forward to the government's support of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said before, it was not my intention to speak to each clause and amendment—
—We have had this debate.

—Just wait a little while. As we have had a substantial reaffirmation of what Senator Spindler said before in this chamber, I thought I should clear up a point that I made earlier which I believe was deliberately misunderstood by a number of people, including one or two journalists. I said that the opposition's position was that there was already a provision in the other acts.

PARA.TAB: We had not had sufficient time to consider these amendments because we received them yesterday at 11 o'clock. It is quite nonsensical for Senator Bell to say, as he did a few moments ago, that we have had plenty of time to consider all the ramifications of the amendments to this particular legislation. We have not had time to deal with them on this side of the chamber. This issue is causing a number of people a lot of heartache. Had we been given the time to consider these amendments properly we could have worked through the concerns that a number of people have expressed to us.

Quotes have been taken out selectively from some letters. I have received some 550 letters now and I could pick out points from those letters and emphasise them. But the one overriding message that comes through those letters, whether they be from employees or from employers—I think the tally is now running at 20 percent from employees and 80 percent from employers—is that there is a massive concern about the impact of this legislation in the workplace; particularly its impact on the small business sector where the vast majority of the letters come from. The Senate is in a position to give proper and adequate consideration to the legitimate concerns that have been raised with me and other senators. I want to make that point absolutely clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not detain the Senate for long. I point out to Senator Crane that I am informed by Senator Bell's office that the drafts of my amendments were sent to Mr Howard six days ago.

—That is an exercise in provocation. I was also involved in discussions with Senator Bell on the amendments. He informed us that the Democrats were not completely certain—he can confirm this—about when the amendments were going to be finalised. As soon as that happened sometime yesterday, Senator Bell and I had a discussion on the telephone as to the final form of those amendments. The same thing happened with our amendments. We ticked off those amendments on which we were going to support one another.

PARA.TAB: Until such time as we have the final form of the amendments in front of us, we cannot be making decisions about where we are heading on a particular amendment. There were changes to the Democrats amendments and there were changes to our amendments in terms of the original draft form. Once again, when other amendments were moved, which came from Senator Margetts, there were changes and we then adjusted some of our amendments. So until we get the final form of those particular amendments, we cannot come into this place and say, `You had the draft amendments five days ago or six days ago'. That is part of the discussion process which occurs between the various participants in a debate such as this one and which comes to a particular conclusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is still going to accept the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 21, page 18, at the end of proposed section 170DF, add the following subsection:

"`(3) Subsection (1) does not prevent a matter referred to in paragraph (1)(e) from being a reason for terminating a person's employment as a member of the staff of an institution that is conducted in accordance with the doctrines, tenets, beliefs or teachings of a particular religion or creed, if the employer terminates the employment in good faith in order to avoid injury to the religious susceptibilities of adherents of that religion or creed.".

SPEECH.PARA: This is a matter that we had some discussion about earlier in the day. They are amendments which modify the anti-discrimination provisions of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill to provide two exceptions to those provisions. The amendments duplicate the exceptions that are already set out in the definition of discrimination in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act. The first exception is already in the bill, and we debated it earlier, but only for the restriction on termination of employment. So the additional amendments will add the same exception to the anti-discrimination provisions concerning the commission's role in certifying or approving agreements. We will have similar amendments in two places in clause 31. I will not speak to them then, I will just formally move them.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 8.Clause 21, page 26, at the end of clause, add the following Division:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Commission to consider and make recommendations about carer's leave

SPEECH.PARA: "`170KAA. (1) This section applies unless an application is made by 1 March 1994 to the Commission for a test case to establish entitlements for employees to leave of absence to provide care or support for a member of the employee's immediate family who is ill.

"`(2) As soon as practicable after 1 March 1994, the Commission must conduct a hearing to determine the circumstances in which such leave should be granted, the persons to whom it should be granted and the entitlements which should be provided in relation to such leave to give effect, or further effect, to the Family responsibilities Convention and the Workers with Family Responsibilities Recommendation.
"`(3) The Commission must after making such a determination provide the Minister, as soon as practicable, with recommendations for legislation to give effect to the determination.'.".

This amendment deals with leave to care for immediate family. This amendment requires the commission to hold hearings and to make recommendations to the government on the provision of minimum entitlements to carer's leave. It is designed to provide Australian workers with leave of absence to look after members of their immediate families in times of illness.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this amendment is to ensure that Australian workers with family responsibilities are properly catered for in the conditions of their employment. It has been made especially necessary by the growth of the number of women in the workplace. It is no longer the case that most women stay at home. Through choice or through economic necessity, women work in paid work as well as in unpaid work. This has led to the entirely unsatisfactory situation where women and men often have to pretend that they are ill in order to look after a child or an aged parent who is dependent on their care and support.

In our view, and in the view of many Australians, it is time to stop pretending, to address this need and to recognise that there must be provision for employees to take leave to care for members of their immediate families. It is not just in the interests of workers, it is also in the interests of employers that their staff are not faced with that unmanageable conflict between their private and their working lives.

However, this amendment does not attempt to proscribe the forms of leave that should be granted by way of minimum entitlements. It leaves that difficult and complex task to a better qualified body—namely, the Industrial Relations Commission. Under the terms of this amendment, unless a test case is lodged with the commission by 1 March next year, the commission will be required to hold hearings and to make recommendations for legislation to the government. The government has undertaken to legislate the commission's recommendations for minimum entitlements to carer's leave, whether they are made in the context of a test case or whether they are through the operation of this new division that we are hoping to insert.

The Democrats envisage two forms of carer's leave. The first is a form of short-term leave similar to sick leave where a child or an aged parent contracts a virus or another complaint which requires the worker to stay at home and look after them. The second is a form of long-term leave, extending possibly to several months, to care for a family member who has a much more serious and chronic ailment. A previously independent parent may suffer a stroke unexpectedly and institutionalised care may not be readily available. We all know of the deterioration in community infrastructure that has happened in Australia in recent years. Other examples are that a spouse may be dying from a terminal disease or a child may be seriously incapacitated by an accident.

The legal basis of this amendment is ILO convention 156—the family responsibilities convention—and the associated ILO recommendation 165. The recommendation spells out what is clearly envisaged by the convention—namely, that leave of absence to care for a member of workers' immediate families should be available. ILO convention 156 leaves the definition of the worker's immediate families to the countries which are party to that convention. The Democrats strongly believe that to confine that definition within narrow legal and biological boundaries would be unfair to many workers. For example, it is not unheard of for two sisters or two friends to live in a platonic relationship for many years. If one falls seriously ill, the other should not be prevented from providing care because they are not legally married. Similarly, one partner of a gay or lesbian couple should not be prevented from caring for the other in such circumstances.

We hear a lot of debate in here and in the wider community these days about what is a family. I thought I would quote from Families in the 1990s: a challenge for future policy approaches from the Australian Institute of Family Studies, published in February this year. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Family is not so much a matter of form, or type, or who is in it, as it is a matter of sharing, caring, emotional closeness, mutual support, creating and passing on values and traditions to the next generations.

We would have preferred that the Industrial Relations Reform Bill included a definition of the worker's immediate family which reflects the many and diverse forms of families which exist in Australia today. To do otherwise would unreasonably exclude far too many Australians from the entitlements envisaged in our amendment. It would be unfair and impractical not to face that reality. The government has raised the question of the constitutional soundness of our proposed definition of a worker's immediate family. We have some of our own legal advice, which Senator Spindler will raise in a moment. But we are prepared to allow the commission to take submissions on that point and to make its own judgment.

PARA.TAB: If we look at the changing composition of the family in Australia, we will find—and my source is the Australian Bureau of Statistics—that the total number of household families in Australia is 4,775,200. The percentage of all couples is 26 per cent. Defacto couples with dependants as a percentage of all couples is 10 per cent. Step and blended families as a percentage of couple families with children is eight per cent. Lone parent families as a percentage of all families is 13 per cent. Working married couples with dependent children comprise 53 per cent of two-parent families.

We, as a parliament, ought to be very interested in the future of families in all their forms. We ought to be very interested in the way in which we, as a parliament, have failed to legislate for appropriate change—change which keeps up with the pace at which family life and family needs have escalated in the last decade because of the participation of women in the work force.

The Australian Institute for Family Studies is keeping a very close watching brief on this issue. I think it is instructive to look at some of its conclusions. For example, a review of absenteeism research conducted by Don Edgar in 1987 concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . close to 50% of all days absent were likely to be caused by family-related problems. Studies of employers in large and small businesses acknowledge that family concerns affect workers' productivity.
That was research by Wolcott in 1991 and 1993. Research by Adie and Carmody in the Australian Institute for Family Studies book indicated:

Increasingly, Australian employers are implementing alternative working arrangements such as job sharing and `telecommuting', providing family leave and days to care for sick dependents and child care options.
Quoting again from the Australian Institute for Family Studies:

. . . if employers took more notice of the fact that 42% of male employees are fathers and that most men have (or will have) ageing parents to look after, perhaps a better balance between work and family would be seen as a male issue as well as a `women's' one, as a matter of best practice in employee relations.

This is a very important issue. I am pleased that the government is willing to at least address it in this way. I believe that this amendment is a major step towards enlightened management of the Australian work force. I believe that it will enhance enterprise relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two reasons why this amendment ought not be supported and why the coalition will not support it. The first is that it is unnecessarily prescriptive to define in legislation what minimum leave entitlements ought to be with regard to the care of family members.
—Why is that?

—I was about to elaborate on that. The reason is that the whole supposed purpose—as I have said on several occasions during this debate, I believe it is a charade—of this legislation is to get a more flexible industrial relations structure into place. Yet here Senator Kernot wants to write into legislation specific prescriptions with regard to leave entitlements to care for family members for sickness or other reasons.

PARA.TAB: I can well accept that there are circumstances where employees ought to be treated favourably by their employers and given leave to care for members of their family, but that is a matter that ought to be part of an enterprise agreement. It ought to be a matter that is capable of negotiation at the individual enterprise level, depending on the particular nature and structure of that enterprise. What might be quite appropriate in making family care leave available in one enterprise could well be entirely inappropriate in another enterprise. It is a matter that simply ought to be left to the individual enterprise, the individual employer, and to the employees to work out themselves in regard to their own circumstances. That is the first point that needs to be made.

The second reason why this amendment ought not be passed concerns the definition of `family' that is involved. I believe that it is an absolute travesty to include lesbian or homosexual relationships within the definition of `family', as this amendment seeks to do. That is an abuse of the term `family' which is simply not acceptable to me or to my coalition colleagues. To downgrade the definition and the structure of family to that degree is simply for the term not to have any meaning at all.

If we are going to give support to families then it ought to be to the normal traditional family structure, which certainly needs nurturing in the sort of climate that we are experiencing in Australia today where the circumstances of families have been downgraded, where the lack of support for traditional families is quite evident and where traditional families certainly find it hard enough to continue their satisfactory existence, particularly single income families—

TALK.START.PARA: —We cannot legislate for traditional families.

—I cannot hear what Senator Kernot is saying, but it would be irrelevant anyway. The simple fact is that it would be an absolute travesty to define a family in this way. It is unacceptable to the opposition for the family to be defined in this way. If we are to provide family care leave, then certainly it ought to be on the basis of a traditional definition of `family'. Single income families in particular are finding it difficult enough to survive and to care for their family members.
—There was no mention of single income families.

—I was about to mention that. As I said, single income families are finding it difficult enough to survive and to care for their family members as it is with the economic plight in which this country finds itself, largely as a result of the policies of the government that is presently in office. As Senator Parer interjected, we did not hear one word from Senator Kernot about single income families and the plight in which they find themselves. Of course, it is single income families which are attempting to maximise the care they give to their family members by at least having one parent available for the full-time care of children, despite the fact that it is often economically difficult and, in terms of the standard of living they are able to enjoy, particularly difficult for single income families to be able to provide that sort of care. As I have said, the amendment is unacceptable on those two grounds. It ought not be supported, and the coalition certainly will not be supporting it.

—I enter this debate very briefly, mainly to give my colleague Senator Crane a bit of a break for the good work he has been doing this evening. When it comes to definition of `family', I like to enter the debate. With regard to obligations on employers, Senator Kernot is a very experienced employer and should know what an employer has to go through. That was not meant as a joke; it was meant to point out her lack of employing experience.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot should stop tongue-lashing when I am speaking. I did not interrupt her. She is not tongue-lashing her husband now.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. On behalf of my husband I really have to ask for that to be withdrawn. It is most offensive.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McGauran)—Senator Panizza, I ask you to withdraw. Family relationships probably do not come under any particular standing order, but just as a matter of courtesy I would ask you to withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, I would like to know whether it is unparliamentary. I will stand by your ruling, and I will eventually withdraw if it so offends Senator Kernot, but I would like to know under what standing order you are asking me to withdraw.

—Could I speak to the point of order? As you correctly said, Mr Temporary Chairman, obviously it is not unparliamentary. I think we are all too madly sensitive about this. The tradition has developed, for reasons known only to the Senate itself though, that when senators find words offensive other senators withdraw them, even when they are not unparliamentary. I even had to withdraw once after calling a member of the opposition an ignoramus. It was terribly offensive to me that I had to withdraw it, but the honourable senator was offended so I withdrew. I think perhaps in this instance it would be appropriate, even though I accept that your ruling is correct, Mr Temporary Chairman. It is not unparliamentary.
—I will withdraw, but I will certainly find something to be offended about in due course. I have no problem with the legislation before us. I have no problem with that.
—Hey, steady.
—I did not say the whole bill, I am talking about the particular section, but when it comes to—
—Just make it clear.

—I am talking about clause 19, lines 22 to 26. I have no problem with that. However, I find many problems with the Democrats' amendment to expand the prescription in this clause. I believe in giving employees time off work to look after their immediate family. As an employer, I have given such time off without any argument.
—Good for you.

—I have done it without any argument. In certain cases my employees have not had to ask me because I have suggested they take time off to deal with family health problems. However, I do not believe in prescriptive legislation to cover the sort of extended family that Senator Kernot talks about. I will leave aside for one moment homosexual and lesbian families. That does not mean I agree with that, but I will refer to that again in a moment.

PARA.TAB: Most employers are very receptive to employee requests for time off to look after the mother and father, the grandmother, grandfather, sister-in-law, aunts and uncles. That does not mean that such situations should be prescribed in legislation for leave to be granted to employees to look after people way outside the immediate family. An employee is in the work force to provide for his immediate family, his common law or de facto wife and children. I would bar homosexual partners, but such relationships in this day and age are aided and abetted by the Democrats and, sometimes, the Greens.

An employee's immediate concern is his wife and children. Parents are not totally the employee's responsibility. That is an immediate concern amongst most ethnic groups. I come from a background where looking after the family and indeed the extended family is paramount. Look at what happens in Italy. The traditions there are carried on in Australia. The grandparents help look after the grandchildren. But that does not mean it has to be built into legislation. I have no problem with legislation prescribing leave for an employee to look after the immediate family, but I do not agree that it be extended into the sacrilegious areas of homosexual couples and so on.

In this case the opinion of the Democrats is pretty irrelevant. I ask the minister how anyone can legislate for such leave outside the immediate family. Extended families do get looked after—employers are very sympathetic to the whole story—but why should the government attempt to cover these situations in legislation?

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you guarantee that?
—Guarantee what?
—That employers will all allow this carer's leave.

—It is ridiculous to build it into legislation. If we let this sort of thing go, how long will it be before the prescription is expanded to include the family dog? Some have that theory—and the Democrats are going down that path. When will it include the family dog or the family horse? Maybe an employer will give an employee time off to look after pets, et cetera. I do not want to see that in legislation and nor should it be in legislation.

PARA.TAB: It must be remembered that, at times, an employer's greatest asset is an employee. As an employer, I know that. Senator Kernot lacks experience as an employer, so she probably would not know. I know that in business my biggest assets, generally, are my employees. Regardless of whatever accusations are made against me, I have had an employee of 31 years and I have had employees of 16 or 17 years. We have not worked on things through legislation. We have worked things out and kept our association going for years and years. I never had any trouble with employees. All those things we have worked out together have not been in legislation. I do not think it is necessary to have these things in legislation.

I have no problem with lines 23 to 29—and Senator Chapman will be my witness. I have strong objections to extending the mandatory carer's leave provisions to parents, grandparents, aunties and uncles—and homosexual and lesbian relationships because those sorts of relationships make me sick in the stomach. That is why I object to the Democrats' amendment which, as Senator Chapman said, we will oppose.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the prescriptive nature of the amendment most objectionable. There may be instances where it could apply: for example, the Public Service and Senator Kernot's old profession of teaching where spare teachers are provided by the public purse to fill in.
—Come on!

—This is true. The amendment is put forward to produce a soft and fluffy feeling—a warm feeling in the heart. It has been moved by someone who has never worked in the private sector. The Democrats are suggesting a prescriptive, paid minimum entitlement for people who have problems. I have spent all my life in the private sector, but I have yet to see anyone who has not had to take given time off.
—It is unpaid leave to start with.
—Where does it say unpaid leave?
—It is for the commission to consider.
—Where is unpaid leave referred to?
—The commission does not need to say whether the leave ought to be available or not. It considers it; there is no prescription for anything.
—Once one goes down the track of getting the commission to be proscriptive—
—It is not proscriptive.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, could you stop the rabble on my left from rabbiting on.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McGauran)—I ask Senator Bell to discipline himself or he will be disciplined by the chair. Some latitude has been granted for interjections during the committee stage, but I would ask Senator Bell to curtail his interjections.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish the Democrats would listen, but they are obviously not prepared to. Once one goes down the track of prescription, one faces the problems caused by such things as attendance money. Attendance money was once paid, but with the passage of time it became part of the wage structure. Sick leave is another example, but with the passage of time it has become accumulative. In most cases I do not object to that. It is good that it is accumulative because if people do go off on sick leave it increases the costs of production because someone has to replace the person on sick leave.

PARA.TAB: I have always been in favour of it. But the original intent was to take account of those people who, through no fault of their own, had to take time off work. There are some instances where it really does not matter. As I mentioned, there are certain cases in the Public Service where it does not matter. But once we go into the private sector and start talking about minimum entitlements for sick leave then they eventually develop along exactly the same lines.
Consideration interrupted.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McGauran)—Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:
That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I would like to raise an issue. Earlier in the week there were discussions about tonight and Tuesday night, and we indicated that we would be prepared to sit until midnight on both Tuesday and tonight. I wonder whether that is an agreement which still exists. If it is, of course we will be happy to sit on until midnight. If not, we would expect the Senate to conclude now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have indicated to the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill), I am very keen to see this matter concluded. A motion has already been moved that would allow the introduction of new business tonight. It is not my intention, as I have informed the Senate on very many occasions in relation to negation, to see the chamber sit through the night. There is going to be, as a result of a decision taken by the Senate this afternoon to proceed with debate on the Native Title Bill, a need for us to deal with not only the Industrial Relations Reform Bill that is before us now but also the 12 other packages and then the Native Title Bill. I think all honourable senators would want to see us complete this program by a reasonable hour on Thursday night of next week.

PARA.TAB: I am hopeful, if debate continues the way it has over the last couple of hours, that we might be able to see this matter concluded at a reasonable time tonight. I think that is achievable and I would ask for the cooperation of honourable senators in that regard. It seems to me that the logical way for us to deal with the business in this instance—this is the plan I have outlined to Senator Hill, Senator Reid, the Australian Democrats, the minor parties and the Independents—is to deal with the Industrial Relations Reform Bill at a minimum tonight; the remainder of our legislative program, with the exception of the Native Title Bill, on Monday; leaving three clear days for debate on the Native Title Bill.

There is a certain logicality about this. I think most honourable senators have accepted that. I do not have a crystal ball which would enable me to say whether debate on this particular bill can be completed by midnight. I would like to see the chamber continue to debate this bill in the constructive way it has this evening, and I think it can be completed at a reasonable hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you define a reasonable hour?

—I do think debate can be completed—as I think most honourable senators would agree—some time hopefully around midnight. Senator Chapman is asking me to make an ironclad commitment when it depends on the cooperation of all honourable senators. I accept that cooperation has been given so far in this debate, and I would ask for it to continue. I think that what I am saying has a certain logicality and sense to it. I do believe that if honourable senators continue to approach this matter in the way they have so far then we can see this business concluded, if not at the stroke of midnight then perhaps a little before or not too long after. I think that is a reasonable position. I would ask the opposition to look favourably upon it, and ask for cooperation from honourable senators.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I would like to speak to the same matter, Mr Temporary Chairman. I might say, with respect, I think everyone in the chamber is showing goodwill except the minister. What he is asking for is an open-ended commitment that the chamber keep sitting for as long as he likes tonight. We think that is intolerable. He has a responsibility to plan a program within reasonable hours. The Senate started sitting at 10.00 a.m. today and we have said that we are prepared to sit until midnight. For the government to expect more than that, we believe, is unreasonable. Even the minister has acknowledged that the debate tonight has been approached positively and some progress has been made.

PARA.TAB: The minister relayed what he said to me. I indicated to him that provided he stuck to his original agreement of midnight I would do my best to urge some of my colleagues to move it along even faster. But he is not prepared to do that. If the government is not prepared to say that it will let the chamber rise at midnight then it cannot expect the same cooperation it has got from us so far tonight. We will therefore seek that the chamber adjourn now and at reasonable, appropriate opportunities through the rest of the evening we will further attempt to do so. But we do not want to. We said that we would sit until midnight. We sat until midnight earlier in the week—on Tuesday. We gave up our own business time today to help the government's program. We said last week that we would sit until midnight tonight as well. All of that had been agreed in a reasonable spirit of goodwill. But now the minister is demanding more. We say it is too late in the night to start demanding more and we will therefore oppose what he is seeking.
Question put:
That progress be reported
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we are considering is the Democrat amendment which would require the commission to make a recommendation in respect of carer's leave. I make the point that during the division Senator Bell pointed out to me that the intent of the Democrats amendment was to fit in with the ILO convention and that it did not prescribe paid minimum entitlements, long term or short term. That may well be so in the case of the ILO convention, but what would come out of the commission may well be something different.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this legislation, as I understand it, was to make enterprise agreements available throughout Australia. Initially, the minister said that it was not just for the union work force but for the non-unionised sector. I will not go into detail on this matter, but it seems to me that the main aim was a pay-off to the trade union movement. What it was meant to do, via enterprise agreements, was to rope in the non-unionised sector of the work force, particularly the 70 per cent in the private sector who were non-unionised and did not want to be unionised.

What concerns me about this amendment is that it is yet another nail in the coffin of enterprise agreements. When one looks at the legislation as a whole, one can consider, for example, things like the prescriptive requirements on redundancy. No one denies that when people are put off work, every effort should be made to cushion that. I have yet to see in my working lifetime an employer who enjoys putting people off. It is a devastating experience. It causes an incredible amount of stress and it is only done, in the main, 99 per cent of the time, because of economic circumstances.

When it comes to actually putting people off, there is a minefield to go through. Each of these requirements is something that should be considered by a reasonable employer. When we then add to this the possibility that, incorporated in an enterprise agreement as recommended by the commission will be an additional prescriptive item, whether it be paid or unpaid, of sick leave, short term or long term, it will guarantee that there will be very few genuine enterprise agreements. At a time when there are about 1.6 million unemployed people in this country, what we must have is an encouragement to employers to invest and create full-time employment. Government senators should not just rely on my word; they should go and ask any of their small business friends and they will tell them that the more we go down this track—

TALK.START.PARA: —More regulation.

—The more prescription and regulation we have, the more there is a disincentive to employ people full-time and an incentive to employ people on a casual basis. As I said, do not just rely upon me for that. I am surprised that that sort of consultation has not gone on, whether it is between the government or the Democrats and those people in the private sector, the small business people, who employ the majority of Australians.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I point out that these are the reasons why we do not support the amendment. We do not oppose its concept. This concept, as far as I know—I have yet to see examples where it has not happened—occurs on a day-to-day basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —What enlightened management.

—Senator Kernot says, `What enlightened management'. What the government is doing is exacerbating the problem—the very problem that has plagued this country for the past 20 years—that state and federal governments—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! For the moment, we are hearing from Senator Parer.
—He is not qualified.
—You have not employed anyone in your life.
—That is not true.
—You don't know that.
—Order! Senator Bell, Senator MacGibbon and Senator Kernot, gracious as I am, I wonder whether you might respect my request that we hear, for the moment at least, from Senator Parer.
—Thank you very much, Mr Chairman. I was saying that what we have seen in this country is—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order. I point out to you that I cannot hear Senator Parer because Senator MacGibbon keeps interrupting and interjecting in my direction.
—Mr Chairman, I rise on the same point of order.
—Senator Panizza, I think I am capable of making a decision now but, if you think you can assist me, I would be glad to hear from you.
—All right. If you are capable of making a decision, I will sit down.
—A perusal of Hansard tomorrow will show that I asked Senator Bell, Senator Kernot and Senator MacGibbon to all cease interjecting. I hope that that is understood by everybody.

—I was saying that one of the major problems we see in this country—I was in fact responding to a remark by Senator Kernot—is that, over the past 20 years, governments at all levels have made legislation for a tiny minority of people, which has had a deleterious and adverse effect on the majority.

PARA.TAB: This is another example of that. I think Senator Kernot said, by way of interjection, that there are always a few bad ones—or words to that effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that.

—Senator Kernot said words to that effect. The thing is that the vast majority of people already put this into practice. As I said earlier, once we make it prescriptive—whether it be paid or unpaid—it is another nail in the coffin of full-time employment. It is a guarantee that the intent of the government—if that is its intention for enterprise agreements—will be a failure.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is my first contribution to this rather lengthy debate on this amendment, and it is the first contribution by the government side. I thought I would make a short contribution. A lot has been said about this amendment. If all the things that have been attributed to this amendment were true, I doubt very much that the government would be supporting it. We are supporting the amendment because of what it actually says rather than the hypotheses that have been posed about it by some who have spoken against it. Upon reading the amendment we find that it says that early next year the Industrial Relations Commission should conduct a hearing to determine and make recommendations about the circumstances in which leave should be granted for people to look after ill relatives.
—No, it says immediate family.

—Yes. I am not trying to define it exactly. What I am trying to get exactly right is the fact that the amendment proposes that the Industrial Relations Commission should have a hearing and make a recommendation. Some people seem to be very concerned that the Industrial Relations Commission should do that. I am not. Even if those opposite are concerned, the intention of the government is that the legislation which should apply to that entitlement nationally will of course come back here. If people are worried about what the provisions might be, the parliament will get a chance to determine what it considers the national entitlement will be if a proposal comes forward from the government at that stage.
—More regulations; more bureaucracies.
—Get excited if it happens.
—It will happen, all right.

—It may well happen, but get excited when it happens. There is plenty of time. People are concerned that we are sitting very late. We would proceed more quickly if fewer straw people were being erected and fewer lengthy debates were being conducted to knock them over. Look at what is being proposed.
—You shouldn't bring in legislation with so many amendments before you even get it into the place.

—I regret to say that, while I admire Senator Brownhill's enthusiasm, this is not a government amendment. Very few of them are, and none of the debate to date has been about them. So let us just relax a bit. This amendment proposes that the Industrial Relations Commission will hear evidence and make some findings about matters. If this amendment is not passed, it is still overwhelmingly likely—it is almost certain—that the Industrial Relations Commission will hear such a test case because the ACTU has made it clear that it will take such a case to the commission.

PARA.TAB: If those opposite are concerned that in some way there should not be a hearing, they are doomed to disappointment—irrespective of what happens here. If they are concerned that, after the Industrial Relations Commission has made a recommendation, the parliament should not legislate, let us deal with it when the parliament tries to legislate. The concerns those opposite have are not part of what is in this proposal. They may have passionate views about matters. There are plenty of forums and plenty of opportunities in which to express them. Get up in the adjournment debate. The rest of us can go home while those opposite make their speeches about what they think about some of those issues, but let us deal with what is actually in this amendment and not the hypotheses people have about what might happen if somebody has a hearing, makes a recommendation and we legislate about it on some future occasion.

We cannot stop, nor should we, the Industrial Relations Commission having a hearing about this matter. It will have a hearing whether or not we legislate for it. We cannot now sensibly debate the legislation which might flow from any such recommendation because nobody knows what it is. So let us get on with the substance of what we are here for. This amendment is a very modest proposal. I really think it is time we seriously got on with the business before the chamber and discharged some of our obligations to taxpayers, instead of indulging ourselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a brief contribution on the constitutional question. Like Senator Kernot, I am rather regretful that the government saw fit to do this in this particular way—on a step by step basis rather than by biting the bullet, as it were, and legislating under the powers that I believe are available to it. We have dealt before with ILO conventions 111 and 156. There is respectable legal opinion that the combination of those two conventions would be sufficient to enact such provisions for carers leave. However, it has been put to us by Mr Anthony Morris QC that it would be possible, in his view, that section 51 (xxxv) of the constitution—the arbitration power—could be used if a particular structure were employed. I want to briefly put that on the record.

PARA.TAB: The view is that it could be brought under that section of the constitution if a number of steps were taken. The first is by amending section 3 of the act to include as one of the objects of it the provision of minimum benefits to workers with family responsibilities so that any such worker may obtain leave of absence in the case of illness of another member of the worker's immediate family who needs the worker's care or support. The phrase `who needs the worker's care or support' answers some of the questions that were raised before about the content of this provision. This should be the criterion. It should not be whether a particular person fits a strict formula of `a family' but whether a particular person living in the unit of that prospective carer needs that care and support. Surely that is the substantive beneficial definition of a family.

The second step would be the insertion of a definition of worker's immediate family. Such a definition was suggested by the Australian Democrats to include any person with a high level of dependence on or interdependence with the employee and who is, or may in the event of illness become, primarily dependent on the employee for care and support. The final step is the insertion in part VI, division 1 of the bill of a provision requiring that in the performance of its functions the commission shall, notwithstanding any other provision of the bill, take into account and have regard to the desirability of providing minimum benefits to workers with family responsibilities so that any such worker may obtain leave of absence in the case of the illness of another member of the worker's immediate family who needs that worker's care or support.

It is suggested by Mr Anthony Morris QC that amendments along the lines proposed above would probably be upheld by the High Court of Australia as being constitutionally valid. I would like the minister's assurance that, if the test case or the ruling of the commission indicates that such a provision as is envisaged is constitutional, the government will proceed to legislate for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyone who has studied sociology knows that the definition of family is not set in concrete. It depends on the nature of the society and, in a changing society like ours, the definition of family is also changing. I think it shows an ignorance on the part of those who are opposing this amendment of what a family means and what it is defined as in sociological and realistic terms. We support the principles of this amendment, and we will be supporting the Democrats.

—I rise to support my colleagues. In particular, I support the comments of Senator Panizza on this amendment. He hit the nail right on the head when he talked about the extension of the so-called family. I also wish to pick up a couple of the comments that the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) made when he referred to straw men.

PARA.TAB: It is quite obvious, having listened to Senator Spindler quote letters from QCs and highlight what can be done with regard to the constitution, that this matter before us is not a straw man. I guess the correct terminology is straw person these days. It is anything but a straw person. The people at the end of this chamber do not seem to understand that we are supposed to be dealing with industrial relations legislation which will free up the labour market with certain minimum standards being put in the legislation.

We are consistently seeing more barriers being put in the way of employers. That is an absolute tragedy when at this time we have such a high level of unemployment in this country. There is no relief from that situation or hope in sight for those people. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) has stated on a number of occasions that he cannot see there being significant changes in the level of unemployment—I have heard him say that there may be a small drop—yet propositions are being put before us which will exacerbate the problem.

Do honourable senators at the end of the chamber not care about the unemployed people in this country? We on this side of the chamber certainly do. We are concerned about them. We are concerned about encouraging and assisting business to employ more people, to get them into the work force and out of the horrible situation they are in through absolutely no fault of their own.

In going through all this paraphernalia about the commission—I take note of what Senator McMullan said about a test case—we are in effect virtually instructing the commission to proceed with a test case and to come back with recommendations to this parliament which will put more barriers in people's way. I want to know what the heck we are on about.

I have worked for a lot of people and employed a lot of people, and I still do. We did things by a handshake. When we were working shifts to bring the crop in we would knock off for 15 minutes and have a cup of coffee at half past 10 at night. What do we do in this damn place? We stay in here and crucify ourselves dealing with things that will exacerbate the whole problem of unemployment in this country. I find it absolutely remarkable, when we are looking at reforming the situation and trying to create an atmosphere where we can actually focus on unemployment, that we are putting more and more in the way. It is obvious from Senator Spindler's comments that, even though this is the Democrats' amendment, an arrangement has been made between the Democrats and the government as to how this—

TALK.START.PARA: —They haven't been rented again, have they?

—Yes, rented again. It is obvious that an arrangement has been made between the Democrats and the government on this amendment. I do not believe the government supported the original amendment, so it has taken the soft option—probably in some arrangement or some deal, although I do not know what it is. If the government is serious about addressing our economic crisis, particularly the problems of those poor people who cannot enter the work force, to proceed down a road that will exacerbate that position is not something that we on this side of the chamber wish even to consider.
—To take up a point that Senator McMullan raised before, he said that the ACTU will be taking a test case to the Industrial Relations Commission. He said that, did he not?
—Yes, that's what they've said.

—That is what the minister said it has said. In that case, why does the government have to put it in legislation? When I was talking earlier about the family I asked why, when these things are done, is stuff unnecessarily put into legislation. I would like the minister to eventually tell me why, if the ACTU has taken this up, the government has to write it in the legislation and presumably make it mandatory to be taken up. It will probably go a lot further than we envisage here.

PARA.TAB: I know the minister has said the matter has to come back here. Neither the minister nor I would be silly enough to think that it will be rubber stamped by this place while the government has that sort of support down there. Whatever comes back—whether it is 12 months paid leave, paternity leave, maternity leave; whatever it is—it will go through.

TALK.START.PARA: —Carers leave.
—That is what I am talking about. The Democrats and the government will support whatever comes back here, and I would like the minister to tell me that eventually.
—Unpaid carers leave. Do you understand that?
—Mr Temporary Chairman, do you think I could be heard without interruption from the same honourable senator who was earlier objecting to someone interrupting her?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—Thank you very much, Senator Panizza. I also remind you that on a number of previous occasions when I was in the chair I have had to remind you to cease interrupting. I think that there is room for a degree of interjection.

TALK.START.PARA: —And when you ask me to do something, I generally do it. Can the minister also assure me that this was not the government's idea in the first place, as Senator Crane alluded to a moment ago? I would like those points cleared up. As Senator Parer said some time ago, these situations cover all employers. I know that the government's agenda and the Democrats' agenda is to hit employers.
—Oh!

—Do not deny it. Their idea is to hit all employers. When the ACTU and those opposite have argued with employers, it has generally been with the big employers. They need not deny that because it is a fact. When I picked up Senator McKiernan on this the other day, he said that he had been put off three times, or something like that. I presumed that he was talking about a fairly big employer. They need not deny that when trouble starts, it is generally with a big employer.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, when the government legislates to tie up big employers, it ties up the mum-and-dad employers as well. Even if the conditions are not a great penalty, they put fear into the mum-and-dad businesses that employ only a few people. I have to find wages every second Friday for seven employees, and what is going on and what may be around the corner puts fear into me.

The smaller businesses are the biggest employers in Australia. Senator McMullan does not deny that, but what is the government doing? It is putting more obstacles in the road, tying up the businesses with more red tape, putting more obligations on them and scaring them off. Why is the government doing that? I do not believe in discriminating between employers, but if the sorts of regulations that the government is trying to put into legislation applied to the big businesses, I could see some sense in it—even though I do not agree with the proposition. But the government is driving off the biggest employers in Australia—the small business people. Do not tell me that that is not a fact. That is why I cannot see the reason for more regulations and legislation. I listened to what Senator Margetts had to say about the definition of the family. We could stay here all night but she and I would never agree on her definition of the family.

TALK.START.PARA: —But your definition is right.
—That is right. I think that I would have 95 per cent of Australia agreeing with me rather than Senator Margetts.
—Try 99 per cent.

—I believe once you pass 90 per cent, winner takes all anyhow—after all, a company can be taken over with a lot less than that. I will stand judged by all of Australia—especially Western Australia, which elected me to this place. Far more people would agree with me than with Senator Margetts on the definition of the family.

PARA.TAB: The Industrial Relations Court has been asked to define the family. I suppose that it could come up with a reasonable definition. If it does come up with a definition, it would be the sort of definition most widely acceptable to Australians, not the sort of definition accepted by Senator Margetts. She can tell me whether I am wrong, but I do not think Senator Margetts has much—

TALK.START.PARA: —You're wrong.

—I am talking about a different point. I do not think that Senator Margetts has much of an idea of what it is to be an employer. If she has, could she please tell me? I do not think she has done much employing, but I could be wrong. I do not think that Senator Kernot has had much experience as an employer either, and nor have Senator Spindler or Senator Bell.
—You're wrong there.

—I have not heard Senator Bell say that he has had experience as an employer. He is certainly not an employer's friend now, or perhaps something went wrong for him as an employer. Their total experience—
—Come on.
—Senator Kernot, do not accept the bait. Let us keep it quiet and get on with this. It will be a long night.

—The Democrats' total experience as employers is minimal. Yet they sit here in judgment of what should be loaded onto employers around Australia. The more they load on employers—whether Senator Kernot likes to believe this or not—the less full-time employment there is. We will go from full-time employment to part-time employment, from part-time employment to no-time employment. It is as simple as that. I therefore ask the minister to reconsider his situation on this and not to put too many extra obligations on employers that would stop them employing. If the ACTU is going to do that, let it and we will see what happens, but we should not be legislating for that to happen.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The world will not end if the Industrial Relations Commission considers and makes recommendations about carers leave. I would like Senator Panizza to stay and listen to this because I have to answer some of things that he said. It will not take long. He is always accusing me of leaving the chamber and not listening to him, so I would like him to listen to this answer. I ask him not to assume that everybody in the world has a confrontationist approach to effects on employment.

PARA.TAB: I cite the example of Belgium. In Belgium, government and business actually consider themselves to be in partnership. Employees seeking carers leave negotiate unpaid leave. That is a minimum standard. The government then intervenes through legislation to require that the person taking leave is replaced in the business by an unemployed person. That is an enlightened example of how, by all parties working together, communities can meet the twin needs of those who need to take leave and those who need training or employment.

I absolutely reject the notion that, by granting the right to leave, we automatically add to unemployment. I remind Senator Panizza that we are talking about unpaid carers leave. We are not attempting to legislate for traditional families, non-traditional families or anything else. We are saying that the Industrial Relations Commission will consider and make recommendations about carers leave and that we as a parliament will then consider those recommendations. That is all we are talking about.

I want to address Senator Panizza's remarks about who in this place has ever been an employer and who, therefore, has a right to speak on matters relating to employment and unemployment.
