Senator Panizza and others on his side wilfully misrepresent the position of other people in this place who have been employers. Equally valid is the fact that it does not matter whether I have been an employer or not—and I have been. I can validly speak from the perspective of an employee who has needed carers leave to look after my daughter. That is no less valid. I remind the chamber that all we are doing is addressing a need that is very important for modern families—men and women—and is a part of enlightened management.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you get the leave?

—No. The final thing I would like to say to Senator Panizza is that we are only trying to make sure that minimum conditions are met. There is no guarantee of enlightened management or that all employees, particularly women in part-time work, will have the negotiating status necessary to bargain their way to this sort of entitlement. Because that cannot be guaranteed—and never will be—it is only fair that we put in place some minimum protective conditions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Next year is the International Year of the Family. That is what this is all about. When most of us think of family we think of something very different from the view that seems to circulate in the very small spaces between the ears of some of our Australian Democrats friends.
—I take a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. Under standing order 175, I draw your attention to the continuing disturbance in the gallery.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—No disturbance was noticed by the chair. But I am alert to your remarks and will be watching for it. From the gallery there can be no interference with the proceedings of the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. I did not notice anything—and I have the floor. It is interesting that the Democrats have a completely different view from ours of families. They would say that this is a pluralist society; and that is their right. We may or may not agree with that. It was interesting to see the view they have of traditional families. That is the flip side of the coin. It is fine for them to say that they believe in a pluralist society but how do they deal with real, traditional families? The other night Senator Spindler said the following about traditional families:

PARA.TAB: The principle that we need to look at is the very nature of the family and what family means to us. Should it be a traditional construct that says that a family is nothing but a husband, a wife and 2.2 children behind the white picket fence or are we looking at the family as basically the caring unit of our community.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Spindler said last night probably is pretty offensive to just about all men and women who work their guts out to make their family environment work and who make a commitment to bring their children up and help them develop as individuals. Senator Spindler characterises that as `nothing but a husband and wife and 2.2 kids behind the white picket fence'. That is the sort of offensive attitude we are getting from the Democrats.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats ask us to support this amendment. Why should we? The question is: what is behind this amendment? About half an hour ago, Senator Spindler said that it is a great shame that this is the way the government wants to proceed, instead of biting the bullet. That seems to indicate there has been a bit of discussion between the government and the Democrats as to exactly what the Democrats would like to do and what the government is willing to live with at this time. Senator Spindler clearly wanted something more than this amendment. But the government was not willing to bite the bullet. Instead of the proposal that Senator Spindler was going to move originally—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that proposal?

—It is a very interesting proposal; and I will get on to it in just a couple of minutes. Instead of the original proposal—plan No.1—we go to plan No. 2. Plan No. 2 is, `Let's require the commission to have a hearing on all these things; but we will write the legislative requirement in such a way that we will be told where to look for the answer'.

PARA.TAB: That is what the Democrats want to do. They say in this amendment that the commission should consider to whom leave should be granted and the entitlements we should be providing for such leave to give further effect to the family responsibilities convention and the workers with family responsibilities recommendation. Instead, they have tried to portray it to this chamber tonight as the commission deciding what is reasonable and in line with community values, what employers can afford to pay, what the community wants employers to put up with, or what arrangements are proper.

TALK.START.PARA: —They want a bit of social engineering.

—They do. We should get former Senator Siddons back. He can provide them all with a spanner and they can go to work on it. This is social engineering. Senator Chapman is absolutely correct. It is not as though the commission will have an open opportunity to decide the matter on the basis of what ordinary Australians think; it will be told to work out how to give effect to the recommendations. These recommendations, and the conventions to which they allude, are the back door for plan No. 1. So we do not get plan No. 1 up straightaway.
—This is the fall back, is it?
—Yes, we go to plan No. 2. Plan No. 2 is to keep everybody busy at the front door while we bring plan No. 1 in through the back door.
—They are very sneaky.

—Yes, they are. Let us consider plan No. 1. It was the plan we heard about on television. The Democrats proposed, amongst other things, parental care for homosexual/lesbian couples who want to adopt children.
—They didn't say that, did they?
—That was on the news.
—And you believed it all.

—Senator Kernot berates me for believing it. I have heard some pretty crazy things from the Democrats. I am willing to believe anything that is said about what they want to do because, usually, that is a fairly conservative estimation of what they come up with. It was clear that nobody was going to live with this crazy proposal for homosexual-lesbian couples to adopt kids—and be encouraged to do so because they would have the certainty of getting parental leave.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot said, `Do not be afraid'. But, although she prevented Senator Panizza from leaving the chamber, she does not have the good grace to stay to listen. They said that the minimum standard is unpaid parental leave—unpaid carers' leave. If that is the minimum standard, everything above it must involve something more than no cost. In other words, it must involve cost. That is what it is all about. This is the minimum standard. Everything above this is an added cost to the employer. But even the minimum standard is a cost to the employer because it disrupts business, employment and training—and it does not create jobs. The impediment it creates puts people out of jobs.

It is fine to sit here in coward's castle where we are all guaranteed a job for X number of years, provided we are not thrown in gaol or thrown under a bus. We can even get thrown out by our party and still have a job here. Even Senator Burns has a job in this place. It is fine to sit here in coward's castle and talk about the bare minimum—but out there, in the real world, this is a major issue. This will cost real people's real jobs. That is what the Democrats do not seem to understand. Senator Kernot berated Senator Panizza, who has a lifetime's experience in employment and a lifetime's experience successfully running businesses—

TALK.START.PARA: —Creating wealth.

—Yes, creating wealth of a wide variety. Why did she berate him? She said he had a confrontationist approach. It is garbage to suggest that of Senator Panizza—because he would not be a successful businessman if he did.
—He is a peaceful man.

—He is, except when roused to anger by stupidity. Senator Kernot advocated instead not a cooperative approach, but a collaborative approach. She said we should be more like Belgium where government and business actually consider themselves to be in partnership. I think that is wonderful. Maybe they can get a carer's arrangement. Maybe government could take six months off and then business could take six months off; they could get carer's leave.

PARA.TAB: But I was reminded of another country where government and business actually considered themselves to be in partnership. That country was Argentina under Peron. I happen to know a fair bit about Argentina because I spent a reasonable chunk of my life trying to clean up its bad debt problem. That problem started when Peron got government, business and unions around a big table and they were all in partnership.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit like WA Inc.

—A bit like WA Inc; a bit like that process of consensus under Mr Hawke; and a bit like this accord process, except in the accord process we have only unions and government in the partnership. But in Argentina everybody got around the table and everybody got what they wanted, except the poor people who had to live with the consequences.

PARA.TAB: When I was dealing with Latin American debt we had a daily struggle with Argentina. We would be all set to sign a contract to assign some debt over and then at about three o'clock or four o'clock London time the bank would ring and say, `I'm sorry, you can't do this transaction tomorrow because tomorrow is a bank holiday'. The reason why it was a bank holiday was that there was so little confidence in the Argentine economy that people kept their money not in australs but in greenbacks. To stop inflation, the banks were closed the next day so that people could not take out their greenbacks, change them into australs and buy their groceries. That took the extra demand out of the economy.

The reason why this is relevant is that this is what happens when, instead of taking a cooperative approach, one takes a collaborative approach; when one tries to corral business or unions or both into the same position as government, which is run by a whole heap of ideological idiots. This is the problem we are going to face in this country. If we do not wake up to it now—

TALK.START.PARA: —We have got it now.

—It is the start of it. This is plan No. 2. They are knocking at the front door, but look around at what is going to happen at the back door. If we do not wake up to ourselves this country will be like Argentina. Senator Parer has said eloquently in this chamber what the consequences of these stupid policies will be on the wealth of Australians. Remember how 20 years ago nobody bought a Japanese car because it was said that it was built with cheap Jap labour. In 1993—not 1973—the average income in Japan is $48,000 a year. The average income in Australia is $26,000 a year and Japan has a lower marginal rate of tax. We have to ask ourselves: when is the slide going to end? I believe the slide should end here.

PARA.TAB: This is just a flimsy excuse to try to set up a situation where the commission will be obliged to recommend that a pair of fellows living together or a pair of sheilas living together who want to adopt a kid can get 12 months off so they can bring the kid up. This is what it is all about. They fix it up so they know exactly what the commission will have to recommend because they tell the commission the only things it is allowed to look at. Then those opposite come in here and I am sure will tell us that if we do not enact legislation to give effect to these recommendations we will be breaching another one of these international conventions; we will be the pariahs of the world because we do not allow a couple of sheilas to adopt a kid and get 12 months parental leave to look after it.

For goodness sake! There are real families—husbands and wives—who would love to adopt a child and who wait years and years because they are just not able to adopt. Yet here we are encouraging homosexuals and lesbians to adopt kids. We are encouraging this by putting these sorts of policies in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a policy; it is a recommendation.

—And the recommendation will be that if we do not do this we will be breaching our international convention obligations and we will be the pariahs of the world. I can almost see the crocodile tears of those opposite. I can almost hear the weeping, wailing and gnashing of teeth. And if those opposite do not have teeth, then there will be the weeping, wailing and gnashing of gums. I can almost hear it now. That is what this is all about.

PARA.TAB: I do not believe we should support this amendment. I think it is morally reprehensible. I think there are much better things that this government, this parliament and this society ought to be doing to try to help the real families with real children and real ambitions who are struggling under the burden of all the nonsense, the garbage, the red tape and the bureaucracy that the government and the Democrats have built up over past years. That is why I do not believe this amendment should be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address Senator Kernot's Belgian option very briefly. It is a pity she did not remain in the chamber; I was here to listen to her argument. But I will talk to her chair—not you, Mr Temporary Chairman—and I think it might have the same result.
—The empty chair.

—That is right. Senator O'Chee used the Argentinian example. But it is a case of Argentina saying `Don't cry for me any longer' because Argentina's economy is turning around strongly. I do not think even Senator McMullan would deny that.
—Because they have turned their policies around.

—Of course. Senator O'Chee mentioned how some time ago we would not buy a Japanese car. In 1960 Australia made more cars than Japan—I am not talking about commercial vehicles and trucks. But look where we are now.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot explained how the Belgian option worked and how people agree to take time off and are replaced by unemployed people. But she did not go on to say whether there were any costs involved. As she did not mention costs, I presume she did not think there were any.

But, as an experienced employer, I can tell honourable senators that there is a cost. When an employee goes on four weeks leave he arranges with his employer to take his holidays at a convenient time so that that employee will not have to be replaced. But when an employee is on extended leave for 12 months or so, he has to be replaced. As Senator Kernot said, in Belgium that person has to be replaced from the pool of unemployed persons. The position would be the same in Australia because nobody would leave one job to go to another that would last for only 12 months or so.

But there is a cost. Whether it is Belgium or Australia, unless the employer is very lucky, the replacement will have far less experience in the job. It is my experience that an employer will have to employ somebody with far less experience. If the employer believes he will have that employee for a long time, he will put a lot more time into training. Perhaps he may need another employee down the track. But if the replacement has to be put off at the end of a 12-month period, the employer has put a lot of effort into training without enjoying the productivity gains which come further down the track.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the retrenchment pay or the temporary staff?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Senator O'Chee, Senator Panizza does not appreciate interjections.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take Senator O'Chee's point about retrenchment, but I am not going to worry about it. I am saying that, especially in the short term, the employer has a far less productive employee. At the last election we had the jobsback policy. We were slayed because it was said that employers would put off older people to put on younger people and pay them less. The Labor Party and the Democrats ran that line. But how stupid it would be for an employer to do that because he would get somebody with far less experience who could cause damage to machines and who would be a lot less productive. No employer was going to be stupid enough to put off a long-term or medium-term employee to put on someone much younger.

PARA.TAB: As I said, I have to find the money for seven pays at the end of each fortnight. I have employed one of those people for 31 years, and some for only three or four years. But how stupid would I be to put someone on for $100 or $200 a week less? It would be utterly stupid, because the new employee is not experienced in the place or on those machines.

I will give one small example to prove my point. This happened in a mining site. A young fellow was being trained in a pit, and he was itching to get onto a dozer. The boss probably let him go on too early. The young man was so excited to be allowed to handle that machine on that day—a big D10—that he did not notice that the ripper on the back, instead of facing down, was sticking out. What did he do? He charged off backwards. A dump truck was about 25 metres straight across from him, and the ripper went straight through the tyre—$5,000 damage before he had made one scrape. Now, that did happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet he was a member of the Liberal Party.

—That happens; I do not care where a person comes from. That example shows just how stupid the argument is to put someone off to save a little pay. Let us get back to Senator Kernot's suggestion about Belgium. If we do what she says, there is a cost involved. She did not mention there would be a cost. But I am telling her, from the examples that I have given, that it can be quite a big cost. So because of that, she has to include that as an extra burden on employers. She has to account for that cost, unless an employer is mighty lucky and an experienced person walks in, is put on that machine and does exactly the same job. A past employee might come back again. If an employer is reasonable, he will get those who come back again after trying somewhere else. An employer might be lucky, but he will not be lucky every time. If he has to put someone in the job with less experience, a cost will be involved. The minister has to admit that a cost is involved, and it has to be accounted for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not said anything about clause 21 until now but, unless I am very wrong, I do not think it is really worth arguing about. If honourable senators have a look at the proposed clause, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: This section applies unless an application is made by 1 March 1994 to the Commission for a test case to establish entitlements for employees to leave of absence to provide care or support for a member of the employee's immediate family who is ill.

We have been told by the minister—and most people who are industrially literate will know—that the ACTU will initiate such a test case. So proposed subsections (2) and (3) in this particular clause will, therefore, have no effect. Whether this clause is agreed to or not, as I understand it an application can be made to the commission for certain types of leave. They include compassionate leave, parental leave—they are already occurring—and I suppose, in a particular way, carer's leave; call it what you like.

PARA.TAB: But the interesting part about this amendment is that proposed subsection (1) says that leave of absence will be provided for an employee to care for or support a member of the employee's immediate family who is ill. It is, of course, incumbent upon the commission, in any of its considerations, to have regard to what the view of the legislature is about particular words and particular clauses. In respect of 170KAA (1) the commission will have to have regard to what the legislature means by the word `family'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The immediate family.

—Yes, I will come to that. The commission will have to determine what is meant by `immediate'. In some award provisions, compassionate leave, for example, does extend to a funeral for a mother-in-law. What I am saying is that the commission will need to have regard to what the legislature means by the word `family'. The legislature has made it perfectly clear what it means by `family' and will do so again next week in respect of the child-care rebate. So I really do not think—and I might be wrong—that this debate is worth all of the time that has been spent on it so far. Again, I might be wrong, but I thought I would just offer that opinion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I deliberately yielded to Senator Harradine because I highly respect his ability to interpret industrial legislation. I believe he is a man of great integrity, but I had difficulty in following his argument because he said that we have to leave the decision to the industrial commission.
—No, I didn't. I said that it has to have regard to what the legislature believes is the definition of a family.

—I understand that. So if his arguments run true, why should we support this amendment that is moved by the Australian Democrats? I enter this debate in sorrow rather than anger because I do believe—I may be overemphasising this—sometimes the Democrats try to help. But, because they are inexperienced, I think most times they hinder rather than help. They remind me of ideological people that mean well, but they run through the legislation and cause absolute chaos because they are not practical people; they are idealists. If we lived in a perfect world, if everyone loved each other and if we all lived by the Bible—as no doubt Senator Woodley would tell us—then I think they would have some place in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: I believe this amendment needs to be knocked down because it does not define what a family is. I am an elected member of parliament. I am elected to represent the views of the people of Australia. I stand under the National Party banner every six years or every three years—whatever the term is—my colleagues stand under the Liberal banner, others stand under the Democrats banner, the Green banner and the Labor banner, and we espouse the policies that we believe in. The people know what our various parties stand for. They elect us to make decisions. They do not elect an industrial commission to define a family. Members of industrial commissions are not elected. Australian people do not elect an international organisation to define a family; they put their faith and trust in their members of parliament.

The electorate makes its judgment every three years or every six years, and it expects us to define `family'. My party believes the family consists of a man, a woman and children. That is what I am going to support here in this parliament because that is what my constituency wants me to support.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you believe it.

—And I believe it very firmly. Unless I have defined what `carer' means so that I know what it means, then I will not give anyone—the Industrial Commission or the International Labour Organisation that has its headquarters in Geneva—carte blanche. I do not care what the Belgians do; it does not really matter to me. We cannot translate the Australian situation into the Belgian situation; there are many variables in it. For that reason, I will vote against the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Another reason I will vote against it is that I have employed people. I am not suggesting for a moment that the Democrats have not; they may have. Looking around at the various people and basically knowing their backgrounds—they are school teachers, pastors and—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler is a businessman.

—Senator Spindler may have employed people. I know how hard it is because I have employed people for 18 years. I never worried whether they were in the union and I never stopped them from being in the union. It did not particularly worry me whether they were in the union or not; they made that decision. If they were broke or their daughters were getting married I lent them money, and I always got it back. We had a great business-employee relationship.

PARA.TAB: In the whole of my 18 years as an employer I think I had to sack two people, and it was the most difficult thing that I ever had to do. I hated it. I never did it when I could possibly avoid it. It is always difficult, even when we have to do it as a member of parliament. It is one of those gut-wrenching things that we try to avoid at all costs.

There was enough imposition on business 11 or 12 years ago when I sold my business to move into parliament, and there is more now. Ninety-two businesses out of every 100 will not survive a period of eight years. Of every 100 businesses that start out, 92 fail in eight years. We have seen record bankruptcies every year over the last five years. This clause will not help people to get a job; it will not help people to hold a job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why won't it help them to hold a job?
—It will not help them to hold a job at all because, if people are given leave for a year or for 18 months, they will have to be replaced.
—If they take the leave they might have to be sacked. You might have to look after your—

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Senator Bell, you are not assisting the process of the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is certainly not helping. I support my colleagues in voting against this amendment because it does not define what a family or a carer is. It leaves the gate wide open for the Industrial Relations Commission to interpret it. I cannot quite understand Senator Harradine's line: I would have thought he would have wanted a definition of `family'.
—But the interpretation of the law requires the commission to have regard to what the legislature means by `family'. That is what I am saying.
—Why do we not define what a family is?
—We have in various legislation.
—Through you, Mr Temporary Chairman—because I respect Senator Harradine and I am listening to him—why do we not define what a family is in this amendment?
—Do you want to call Senator Harradine to respond to the question?

—Yes. I do not want to extend this debate any further. I know Senator McMullan was saying he wanted to get to bed. I urge the chamber not to support this amendment. I think it is a nonsense amendment. It will not help unemployment; in fact, it will increase unemployment, which is what the rest of this Industrial Relations Reform Bill will do.

—I am also concerned about this amendment. I have been following the debate very closely on the in-house monitor. My colleagues have put the arguments very well and I really cannot add a great deal to the debate, except I feel that I ought to make an observation about the stupidity of these sorts of amendments which have been put up by the Australian Democrats. I would be surprised if the Democrats' colleagues in the right wing of the Labor Party did not support it.

PARA.TAB: It is very evident that the Democrats have no feel and no understanding of what business is all about. It was stated that Senator Spindler was involved in some sort of business. If he were, I am surprised at his attitude to business. The rest of the Democrats have had no experience, and it comes through. There is nothing wrong with being teachers. Perhaps Senator Faulkner was a teacher too. Teaching is a noble profession, but it is fairly clear that these people have never had to worry at the end of the week whether they have done enough business that week to pay the wages. Business people worry all the time about whether they will be able to stay in business, whether they will be able to pay the wages or whether they will be able to keep it going. Each day they struggle through a ream of bureaucratic form filling-in or of new taxes being imposed practically monthly by governments such as this one.

We can understand from the government's legislation that people such as Senator McMullan have never employed anyone—they always get their cheque at the end of the week. Senator Kernot always got a cheque at the end of the week. It did not matter how hard she worked or did not work, it did not matter whether she was sick or whether she had a few days off—the cheque was always there. When people do not have to worry about that they bring forward stupid legislation such as this, which just puts further imposts on business and makes it more and more difficult for people to get their businesses going, to expand their businesses, to employ people and to create wealth and employment.

It is very clear that the only way to get the country to expand is by getting small business to have the confidence to put its money into it, to expand its business and create new jobs. That is the only way the country will get going. The more we have clauses such as this from people who have absolutely no idea of what it is all about, the more difficult it becomes for small business to continue to operate.

If Senator Spindler was in business, I am disappointed that he cannot convince his colleagues that these sorts of proposals do nothing at all to help small business. They are just more taxes and greater imposts—they do the exact opposite. I am very concerned that the Democrats have put up these amendments. They have no idea what it is like to run their own businesses and they have no idea what it is like to have to worry at the end of each week where the money is coming from. I hope the chamber by majority will reject this amendment.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Kernot's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 22 to 25—by leave—taken together and agreed to.
Clause 26.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6)Clause 26, page 2, paragraph 7(c), after the proposed definition of "industrial situation", insert the following definitions:
"`paid rates dispute' has the meaning given by paragraph 170TA(1)(b);
`paid rates functions and powers' has the meaning given by subsection 170TA(1);".
It is merely a consequential amendment to the major paid rates award amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Motion (by Senator Reid) put:
That progress be reported.
(The Chairman—Senator N.A. Crichton-Browne)
Question so resolved in the negative.
Clause 27.
Amendment (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:

SPEECH.PARA: (7)Clause 27, line 37 (page 27) to line 4 (page 28) omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "27. Section 95 of the Principal Act is repealed and the following section is substituted:

PARA.EMPHASIS: No automatic flow-on of terms of certain awards and agreements

PARA.TAB: `95.(1) The Commission does not have power:

TAB.TAB: (a)to include terms in an award that are based on the terms of a certified agreement or of an enterprise flexibility agreement; or
(b)to include terms in an award that are based on the terms of a paid rates award;

SPEECH.PARA: unless the Commission is satisfied that including the terms in the award:

TAB.TAB: (c)would not be inconsistent with principles established by a Full Bench that apply in relation to determining wages and conditions of employment; and
(d)would not be otherwise contrary to the public interest.

PARA.TAB: `(2) In this section:

SPEECH.PARA: "award" does not include a certified agreement or an enterprise flexibility agreement.'.".

PARA.TAB: Clause 27, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 28.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5)Clause 28, page 28, lines 5 to 16, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Power to grant preference to members of organisations etc.

SPEECH.PARA: "28. Section 122 of the Principal Act is amended:

PARA.TAB: (a)by omitting from subsection (1) `The Commission may', and substituting `The Commission may not, unless the organisation is one which has been granted exclusive representation under section 118A,';
(b)by omitting subsection (3) and substituting the following subsection:

TAB.TAB: (a)the Commission has directed under subsection (1) that preference is to be given to members of an organisation of employees or to persons who have applied to become members of such an organisation; or
(b)a certified agreement or enterprise flexibility agreement provides for preference to be so given;

SPEECH.PARA: an employer is not required, because of the award, order or agreement, to give preference over a person in relation to whom a certificate under section 267 is in force or over an employee who is not a member of an organisation.'.".

This amendment amends section 122 of the principal act which gives the commission the power to grant preference to trade unionists by prescribing preferences in all situations except those in which unionists are members of a union which has been granted exclusive coverage under 118A. This amends section 122(3) to say that preferences cannot be awarded on the grounds of non-union membership, effectively confining preferences to members of one union over members of another union.

PARA.TAB: This amendment is about creating a situation whereby people who choose not to be a member of a union do not have to be subject to awarding of preferences by the commission. We believe that in terms of the direction in which the government is going as far as this bill is concerned it is only reasonable that those people who choose not to be members of a union should not be subjected to a preference being awarded over them which will effectively, in the medium and the longer term, force them to join a union.

That will be the practical effect of the situation as the legislation currently stands. The coalition believes that what will flow from the government's position should not be allowed to occur. Individuals who choose not to be members of a union should not be affected in such a way as to force them to become members of a union.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government, and the Democrats, too, in this Industrial Relations Reform Bill heavily base their legislation on the ILO conventions signed by Australia. I have to say that the conventions they have used are selective and it would be more convincing if they applied them consistently rather than in accordance with their own interests, which are incredibly transparent. Preference clauses—and this is what this issue is all about—which buttress compulsory unionism are in conflict with the United Nations Declaration on Human Rights.

PARA.TAB: The opposition is totally opposed to the use of conventions to determine legislation in this country. I point out that if the government wants to use conventions, it should use them consistently. I refer the government to the United Nations Declaration on Human Rights, which states that everyone has the right of peaceful assembly and association. We do not disagree with that; we support that concept. The next sentence states that no-one may be compelled to belong to an association. If this government were genuine in referring to conventions it would also have referred to that particular convention and therefore it would not have brought in this clause.
I also draw to the committee's attention that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, claimed in the House of Representatives that:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 122 is not, as the opposition would have people believe, a charter for either closed shops or compulsory unionism.
He went on to say:
. . . that power has been used very sparingly by the commission. It is not an everyday practice—far from it.

The minister's assertions were clearly wrong. I will assume it was due to ignorance; I do not know whether it was or not. A recent study of the journal of industrial relations showed that closed shop arrangements covered 57 per cent of all employees in unionised workplaces. So much for the fact that the power has been used sparingly by the commission! According to the same study, preference clauses were the cause of the closed shop arrangements in 11 per cent of the workplaces. The two other major causes were formal agreements between management and unions and custom and practice. It is likely that these last two causes were buttressed themselves by preference clauses. I draw that to the committee's attention because the statement made by the minister in the House of Representatives was quite clearly wrong. (Quorum formed)

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a well-known issue which has been debated on a number of occasions. It is not the time or the place to reiterate—
—It is the place, but this is not the time.

—I am not sure about either. There are long held but often recited alternative views about this. For at least a decade Liberal coalition governments proposed and Labor oppositions opposed—and vice versa—matters to do with this issue. There is very little new to be said. I thought Senator Parer's statistics actually disproved his own argument because he talked about the extent of closed shops and then proved how fundamentally irrelevant to them or how minor a role preference clauses played in it.

PARA.TAB: The exception proposed in the amendment relating to section 118A is not sufficient to attract government support for the amendment. I think the Industrial Relations Commission has a history of using the power conferred on it by sections such as this in a very reasonable manner and we do not have any intention of taking that power away from it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The clear effect of section 122 of the existing act is to give preference to members of organisations—that is, to members of trade unions. Again, it is an example of how the legislation as it currently stands serves the interests of the minority against those of the majority. As we know only too well, less than 30 per cent of employees in the private sector now belong to trade unions; 70 per cent choose not to belong to trade unions. But those 30 per cent are to be given preference under this legislation. Quite simply, that is a position that the opposition believes is quite untenable and that is why, on behalf of the opposition, Senator Crane has moved this amendment to reverse that preference and prevent the commission having the power to grant preference to unionists; certainly, to ensure that preference cannot be awarded on the grounds of non-union membership.

PARA.TAB: The only circumstance where preference will be capable of being granted is where preference is granted to members of one union over another under an award, but not between members and non-members of trade unions. Again, that is a further move by which we seek to give a genuine freeing up of the industrial relations system. As I have said in earlier debates tonight, that is supposedly the intent of this legislation. We do not believe it is the intent, but that is the argument the government has put forward—that the intent of this legislation is to move towards greater flexibility in industrial relations, to allow for enterprise flexibility agreements and generally to free up the system. One cannot free up the system while one has this preference for unionists remaining as part of the legislation and that is why this amendment ought to be passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice the minister, in his response, said that the statistics I quoted supported the view expressed by Mr Brereton. Let me repeat what Mr Brereton said:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 122 is not, as the opposition would have people believe, a charter for either closed shops or compulsory unionism . . . the power has been used . . . sparingly . . . It is not an everyday practice . . .

Yet the study in the journal of industrial relations showed that closed shop arrangements cover 57 per cent of all employees and union workplaces. I would like him to explain to me why those statistics do not bear out the fact that what the minister said in the other place was wrong.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to quote one example of a union jumping the gun before this legislation is even through the parliament. I have a letter from a group called Signet, at Wakerley in Queensland, which has drawn to my attention its concerns about the Industrial Relations Reform Bill. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: I recently received two letters regarding enterprise bargaining. The first is a threatening letter from the National Union of Workers.

It has included a copy of that letter from the Queensland branch of the National Union of Workers. That letter was sent to the manager of Signet Identification Systems. It is a group that I do not know and I do not know what size it is. The letter states:
The Union request that you respond to its claim for an Enterprise Agreement dated 5 November, 1993 within 7 days of the date of this letter.
A refusal by your company to enter into meaningful negotiations within that period will not be viewed favourably by the Union and its members in your employ.

The implication is that there are a few union members in its employ. The union wants to jump the gun on the legislation, rope in the rest of the employees and have an enterprise agreement that may or may not be acceptable to the employees of that particular company. This clearly is the sort of thing that we can expect. It is a concern that I have. I have made my point very clearly in my speech during the second reading debate that neither I nor people on this side of the chamber would be opposed to voluntary unionism—people deciding voluntarily to become members of a union.

PARA.TAB: What we do object to is coercion and intimidation because that, in itself, would signify that this is not a free country. People should have the right to join, not join or resign from any organisation they like—even a political party. I know it is difficult for honourable senators on the other side of the chamber to accept this, but that should be the freedom available to most people. I draw that to the committee's attention because it is the sort of thing that is happening even before the legislation is passed.

There is another point that I would like the minister to respond to. It seemed to me that Minister Brereton was wrong in what he said about section 122 being used sparingly and that it was not an everyday practice. Yet the study by the journal of industrial relations showed that closed shop arrangements covered 57 per cent of all employees in unionised workplaces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The letter to which my colleague Senator Parer just referred is similar to a letter that I have received dealing with the same issue. Apart from the points that Senator Parer has made in relation to this letter, what it really points out is the nonsense that we are going through as far as this government's administration of industrial relations is concerned. As I said a few moments ago, the government says that it is about achieving enterprise agreements and enterprise flexibility agreements. Surely the central requirement of an enterprise agreement is that it is an agreement entered into by the employer and the employees of a particular enterprise and, indeed, ought to be initiated by the employer or the employees of that enterprise—otherwise, it has no meaning as an enterprise agreement.

PARA.TAB: Yet what do we find in this letter? It is a letter from the Queensland branch of the National Union of Workers demanding that this particular firm, Signet, respond to its claim for an enterprise agreement dated 5 November 1993 within seven days of the date of this letter. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: A refusal by your company to enter into meaningful negotiations within that period will not be viewed favourably by the Union and its members in your employ.

It is the union demanding the enterprise agreement, not the employees of that particular firm. As I say, that simply highlights the absolute nonsense of the government's notion of enterprise agreements.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the lack of response from the minister on this, I think there are a couple of points that I would like to bring out in this particular debate. I was expecting, because of the importance of this issue, a more comprehensive response. This amendment before the committee will greatly assist the facility to free up the labour market. It will remove one of the greatest fears that many employees and employers in small business have. I think it is worth putting that on the public record because it removes the commission's ability to grant preference at its discretion. It confines preferences to members of unions who have been given 118A coverage. It removes the commission's power to grant a preference on a union, non-union basis. I think that point is worth underlining and emphasising.

PARA.TAB: It confines preference to union basis so that an award can no longer be created on a union, non-union basis. A flow-on effect of that is going to severely limit or restrict that terrible practice that has grown up in parts of Australia of what is known as double and treble ticketing. That is the case where an individual happens to be a member of a union, or maybe not even a member of a union. But before that person can get onto a site—and this particularly applies to the building industry—to carry out whatever function, there is an unwritten law on that site and a `no ticket, no start' situation where that person has to join a union. That flows through into other situations. There are many examples of double and treble ticketing. It is something which, in my view, is a total breach of the freedoms and the rights of the individual and it is applied purely and simply by coercion. This amendment, while it will not completely cut that out, will certainly restrict the ability for it to happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crane mentioned that that type of activity—which is not condoned, I should not have thought, by anybody here—arises because of an unwritten law and, therefore by definition, is not going to be assisted by the amendment. The provisions which enable the commission to award preference are not responsible for that type of activity. I did not want to enter this debate, but Senator Crane was a bit unfair to the minister when he said that the minister had not really responded to him. I think I heard him say something to the effect that this issue had been debated for the last 10 years. In fact, it has been debated a bit longer than that—culminating, I think, in the establishment of the Senate Standing Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation. I happen to have a copy of its report in my hand, but I do not know whether it is the only copy extant. That committee was established by this chamber in early 1982. It reported to the Senate in October 1982. There were a number of members of the committee.
—Tell us who they were, please.

—No, we have too much on. I happened to be the chairman of that committee at the time and we talked about this issue of preference. Senator Crane realises as well as I do that there are provisions in the Industrial Relations Act in respect of conscientious objection. People's rights are preserved. In fact, their rights in respect of promotion and all of those areas of preference are preserved, as I understand the situation.

PARA.TAB: We looked at the situation where there might be what we termed a less fundamental objection to union membership. I am rather surprised that that has not been taken up by the opposition over all of those years. The opposition could perhaps look at that. It has not taken it up and does not take it up in this proposal—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's your opportunity for an amendment.

—I had hoped that I was not going to enter any of the debate on this bill. I will not say why. I think I told Senator Crane why when I said that originally. I thought I would mention the fact that Senator Crane was a little hard on the minister when he said he had not responded. What he was referring to, of course, was the body of argument that had been going to and fro for 10 years and more about this matter. (Quorum formed)

—I thank Senator Harradine for his advice. I will certainly have a look at that. I will call on his good services. I did not think the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, Senator McMullan, would require any support in his defence, but no doubt he appreciates it. On the issue of double and treble ticketing, I cannot agree, with all due respect to Senator Harradine, with the proposition he put to us because the effect of granting preference over a non-union work site will lead in time to that site becoming unionised. There is no doubt in my mind at all about that. Of course, the flow-on effect is that these practices, which I absolutely and totally disagree with, will grow.

PARA.TAB: The other reason for my getting to my feet at this time is that last night when Senator Bell and I exchanged positions on these various amendments he indicated that he would be supporting us on this amendment. Since Senator Bell has not spoken on the amendment, I would like to hear his views, as the representative of the Democrats, as to why they decided to support us.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this amendment, as I understand it—we have done it this way and I would like the minister's reaction to it—is that, if an organisation has exclusive representation, under section 267 an employer is not required to give preference to a member of the organisation over a person who holds a conscientious objection certificate or over a person who is not a member of an organisation.

PARA.TAB: The conscientious objection provision is clear. The amendment provides that an employer with a union granted exclusive representation—which remains—would be obliged to give preference to members of that union over any other union but would not be obliged to discriminate against non-unionists. That is the sole purpose of that amendment. I would be interested in the minister's view of that, with advice if necessary.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not wish to be discourteous. Senator Parer asked me a question and I intended to respond to it, but not until everybody else had concluded. I do not really have anything to add. We have a different interpretation of the statistics and people have to judge whose interpretation they accept on the record. I do not have any reason to disagree with his interpretation of the amendment. I simply do not agree with it.

—I have been invited to respond and will do so. Senator Crane tells the situation as it was at our last conference on this matter when I indicated that support would be forthcoming for the amendment as it had been described to us. The problem we have is that, just as Senator Parer indicated, the purpose of the amendment is not in, as we have been advised, concurrence with the effect.

PARA.TAB: We have been advised that what had been described to us will not be the effect. We are particularly attracted to—in fact, we believe strongly in—those who subscribe to enterprise flexibility agreements not being subject to preference clauses. We sincerely hope that the government will consider the question of enterprise flexibility preference clauses in the future legislation. As this does not deal exclusively with EFAs, it does not have the effect which we at first believed it would have. So we will not be supporting this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask Senator Bell to reconsider because, as I have indicated, and I think as Senator McMullan indicated, the effect of that amendment is simply twofold. I do not think there is any objection to this. I am interested in Senator Bell's reasoning as to why he will not accept the amendment. One effect is that an employer is not required to give preference to a member of an organisation over a person who holds a conscientious objection certificate—I do not think he will have any problems with that—or over a person who is not a member of an organisation.

PARA.TAB: It is accepted that a union may be granted exclusive representation. For example, in my state of Queensland, the AWU could be granted exclusive representation over the shearers. That would give preference to members of the AWU over any other union, because that preference clause is already there. It would also mean that the employer would not be obliged to discriminate against a person who was a non-unionist. That is it.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Crane's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very strongly against this clause of the bill and bring to the attention of this chamber and the Australian people the big doublecross that has just been done. It is a fact that no-one can trust a Democrat. To emphasise what we know about them, because it must be got across, I hold up a newspaper article which shows how the Australian Democrats have grabbed the publicity. The headline to that article says,`Non-unionists get sacking protection'.
—Who said that?
—Senator Bell.
—Which way did he vote?

—We have just seen which way he voted. We have seen the big doublecross. I am so infuriated by what has just occurred in this place, not because we lost the amendment—although I am furious about that—but because we exchanged information on our positions and were told a certain thing. We came into this place to find—
—Then you go public and put it in the paper.

—Yes, I know. They went public; they put their position and what they were doing in the paper. Their actions are beyond my comprehension. They did not even have the courage to telephone us and say that they had changed their minds and why. They did not have the courage or moral fortitude. There is no consistency in dealing with things in this place. Those opposite can laugh about it all they like. They think they have had a victory.

PARA.TAB: The tragedy is that the 70 per cent of people in the work force who choose not to belong to a union will now be coerced and intimidated into joining unions. The fact that our amendment has not been carried will totally undermine enterprise flexibility and the agreement process that this government was trying to put in place. Those opposite and the Democrats know darned well that any small business that is non-union will not go near an enterprise flexibility agreement. No-one could blame them for that. It is about time the Democrats started showing a little honour—

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't know the meaning of the word.
—That is right.
—They don't know the meaning of `enterprise' either.
—No, they do not. But they know the meaning of putting in place legislation that will result in people who not want to join a union being intimidated and coerced.
—Treachery.

—That is absolutely right. They know the meaning of that. It is tragic for the vast majority of the work force, decent Australians, that they have been doublecrossed. The Democrats will be condemned to the depths of hell for what they have done, because this type of action is absolute and total treachery.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Hill) put:
That progress be reported.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 29 to 30—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 31.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6)Clause 31, page 32, proposed paragraph 170MC(1)(a), line 4, before "employees", insert "majority of".
I defer to Senator Parer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposed paragraph 170MC(1)(a) in clause 31 states that the commission cannot certify an agreement unless:

SPEECH.PARA: wages and conditions of employment of the employees covered by the agreement are regulated by one or more awards—
as defined in subsection (6)—
that bind their employer, or their respective employers;

The section has been incorporated into the bill because the no disadvantage test in proposed paragraph 170MC(1)(b) tests the fairness of the agreement against the existing award. Paragraph 170MC(1)(b) states the commission cannot certify an agreement unless:
the agreement does not, in relation to their terms and conditions of employment, disadvantage the employees who are covered by the agreement;
The meaning of `disadvantage' is set out in subsection 170MC(2). The commission must first of all decide whether:
certification of the agreement would result in the reduction of any entitlements or protections . . .

that the employees enjoy under an award, including a state award, or any other law that the commission considers relevant. If the commission decides that such a reduction would occur, it must then determine whether a reduction would be contrary to the public interest. The public interest test is supposed to ensure that a company would make an agreement that would reduce the wages of a group of employees in return for, say, a share of the company's increased profits at a later date. I think we saw an example of that at SPC in Victoria where a similar sort of agreement was entered into.

PARA.TAB: Most companies today employ their executive managerial staff under individual contracts rather than awards, as people would know, in what I described before as the post-industrial era. In fact, the latest ABS statistics show that 33.7 per cent of managerial and executive employees are covered by awards. Companies wishing to rationalise their industrial arrangements by placing all their employees under a single certified agreement would have to go to the trouble of applying for an interim award for their senior staff before the agreement could be certified by the commission.

The coalition amendment adjusts the threshold in paragraph 170MC(1)(a) downwards so that the commission can certify an agreement if the majority of the employees concerned are covered by awards. That would allow companies with non-award managerial and executive employees to go to a certified agreement without first seeking an interim award.

I might say that this was raised in a submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training by a company in my own state of which Senator Kernot would be aware, the Metway Bank. It is in a unique situation in that it has an enterprise agreement which has been very successful but it has 577 senior staff who are not covered by an award. As a result, the bank would have to go to the time and expense of obtaining an interim award for such staff before it could obtain a certified agreement. There are many other people in that sort of category, more so in the white collar area. It is for that reason that the opposition is proposing this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 31 demonstrates very clearly why this legislation is inadequate. The claimed purpose of this legislation is to promote enterprise agreements. This is in fact the key clause as far as enterprise agreements are concerned; yet it prescribes and circumscribes the situation regarding enterprise agreements so severely that they simply will not happen. This really demonstrates that this legislation is the very antithesis of what is required for enterprise agreements.

PARA.TAB: The essence of enterprise agreements is, firstly, that the employer and the employees will give thoughtful consideration as to what is in their peculiar and mutual best interests, which will always involve the maximisation of the quality of products; and, secondly, that the employer and the employees are free from any set of rules imposed upon them, as would be the case with an award, and may agree on terms and conditions of employment unique to their own circumstances. Yet this clause refers to the requirement for awards to be in place before one can have an enterprise agreement and, of course, we debated earlier the minimum standards and so on that are all part of this legislation. This clause is entirely inadequate to bring about the claims which are made for this legislation.

The legislation in no way reflects the requirements for genuine enterprise agreements. As I said, the requirement is that there be an award in place, that there be trade union involvement in the development of the enterprise agreement, that there be Industrial Relations Commission involvement in the development of an enterprise agreement, that there be a no disadvantage test applied to the development of an enterprise agreement. It even envisages the use of industrial action—strike action—rather than logical personal negotiations between the employer and the employees for the development of an enterprise agreement.

When we were debating this clause in the committee stage we heard time and again that all of this simply makes the achievement of enterprise agreements far too hard and they simply will not happen. If enterprise agreements are not achieved we will not get the productivity improvement that is desperately required among businesses in Australia to restore the economic well-being of our country. Businesses will not be able to prosper and therefore will not be able to create more jobs to deal with the one million or more unemployed in this country.

The imposition of union involvement in enterprise agreements where it is not wanted by the employees, let alone the employer, is directly contrary to the concept of genuine enterprise agreements. What we need to remember is that unions remain wedded to the concept of comparative wage justice. Comparative wage justice is the very antithesis of genuine enterprise agreements. This system ought to be arranging wages and conditions of employment according to the nature and success of an individual enterprise.

Under this legislation enterprise agreements will be so controlled that it is inevitable that comparative wage justice will remain prominent as part of those agreements. The result of that will be a wages scramble, which we have seen so often in the past, and inflationary consequences which will result in jobs being destroyed instead of being created.

In that context it is worth noting that many of the certified agreements that have recently gone before the Industrial Relations Commission at federal and state level have involved agreements for wage increases based on changed work practices which will supposedly increase productivity. Those opposite may say, `That is fair enough. These agreements are about getting increased productivity and trading off the improved productivity to the employees in the form of wage increases.'

However, it turns out that in many instances these changed work practices that have been promised by trade unions in return for wage increases are identical with the changed work practices that were promised some years ago under the second tier wage increases that were obtained in the 1980s under the accord. That is one of the last bright ideas this government had with regard to industrial relations.

It is quite clear that the productivity increases that were supposed to be obtained in return for the second tier increases given in the late 1980s were never delivered. Now we find the unions have the hide to go back to the Industrial Relations Commission and attempt to get a certified agreement to seek further wage increases on the basis of delivering the productivity increases that were supposed to have been delivered several years ago. It is no wonder this country is in the sort of economic mess that it is in when that is the approach of the trade unions.

We need to look only at the proceedings of this year's ACTU congress to see the deep seated hostility on the part of union officials towards genuine enterprise agreements and real enterprise bargaining. Its attachment to the arbitration system is firmly entrenched. That is hardly surprising because it is the centralised system and the arbitration system in Australia which gives much of the power which trade unions enjoy. That is no doubt one of the reasons why this legislation circumscribes the way in which enterprise bargaining will be undertaken.

We ought to note the recent review of national wage principles conducted by the Industrial Relations Commission. Grant Bellchamber, representing the ACTU, said that the restructured award system—he is referring to the restructured award system which will occur under this legislation, under this supposed move to enterprise agreements—will be capable of accommodating a more highly structured centralised system at some future time. In other words, the trade union movement is looking at returning to a more centralised system at the earliest opportunity.

It is a real tragedy that this clause fails to implement the changes that are required in the conduct of industrial relations in Australia. That change is desperately required if we are going to generate the jobs to overcome unemployment. Of course, the government clearly recognises that this legislation will do nothing to provide more jobs and help solve the unemployment situation, because we find it is now looking at a so-called jobs levy, which is an income tax increase by another name.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds like the Democrats.

—We have heard the Democrats propose it. Now the ACTU is proposing it and the government is looking at it. Given the way in which the government succumbed to the ACTU demands on this legislation, particularly this clause, undoubtedly it will cave into the ACTU demands for this equally stupid concept of a jobs levy. The government does not seem to recognise that it is small business—
—But you do not know—
—I say to Senator Kernot that small business offers the best chance of increasing job opportunities.

PARA.TAB: I want to refer to some research, the results of which are now available, which was undertaken by Professor Judith Sloan from the National Institute of Labour Studies. She pointed out that from May 1990 to May 1992 employment in companies with more than 100 employees fell by 15 per cent. For companies employing between 20 and 99 employees, employment fell by nearly nine per cent over those two years. But for companies with fewer than 20 employees—the quintessential small business—there was a growth in jobs of three per cent over that same two-year period. In fact, almost four out of every 10 workers are employed by businesses with fewer than 20 employees.

This proposed jobs levy, like this legislation and this clause in particular, will be yet another impost on small businesses which will prevent them from having the capacity to generate more employment. If, as suggested, this levy applies at a rate between one and five per cent on incomes, it will certainly have a very detrimental effect on small business.

I recall Senator Macdonald saying earlier that the Democrats—and it would seem the government—have very little understanding of how small business operates and the practical requirements of small businesses. Most of the profits of small businesses are withdrawn by the proprietors to cover their living expenses. If they have anything left over, that goes back into redevelopment; it is reinvested—as Senator O'Chee says—in the business so the business can grow, so it can be more productive and so it can employ more people.

If we have another tax in the form of a jobs levy levied on the profits of small businessmen, the money will simply not be available to put back into the business to provide more jobs. We will simply not get the job increases that small business would otherwise be capable of producing.

What we need is not what is provided in clause 31 which, as I said, is a very tight circumscribing of the way in which enterprise agreements can be developed. In fact, we need a much more open and freer system so that we have an industrial relations system based on the needs of this country in the 21st century, not on the experiences and the history of the 19th century, on which this legislation seems to be based. Therefore, this clause ought to be opposed. To the extent that it can be improved, the opposition's amendments ought to be supported.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem with this amendment is that inherent in it is the fact that there will be employees for whom there is not a benchmark award for the purpose of a no disadvantage test. That means that the no disadvantage test is of much less value, if any, to those people. I think the intention of this amendment is actually quite positive, but I think the outcome of it would not be so and therefore we are not going to accept it.
—Tonight is a very interesting night because we are seeing philosophies change all over the place on the other side of the chamber.
—And a bit of double crossing too.
—There has been a little of that too, but I do not want to talk about that because I am a charitable man.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Senator MacGibbon should not talk about it either because he is not sitting in his own chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I am sure the moment got away with him. What I am interested in is the concept of pluralism. Earlier on this evening we were encouraged to adopt all sorts of positions about the family, or what I call pseudo-families, in the interests of social pluralism. Yet what we have tonight is an opportunity, in this amendment moved by the coalition, to truly support the concept of pluralism.

PARA.TAB: By inserting the words `majority of' before the word `employees', we can create a pluralistic workplace. It is quite interesting. I can see the faces of those opposite and their jaws have dropped. It is a new concept to them. Many concepts are new to Senator Murphy. Here is the possibility of really supporting pluralism. Let us support pluralism in the workplace by supporting this amendment.

This amendment creates the possibility for the commission to ratify an agreement provided that the majority of employees are covered by an award. What the clause as it stands would require is that every single one of them has to be covered by an award. In other words, there is no pluralism; there is no co-existence. It all has to be tightly controlled. Yet here we are supposedly reforming the industrial relations system.

It is a good thing the people opposite were not on the long march with Chairman Mao—because a long march starts with a very first step and those on the other side would take the first step backwards. That is what they would do. Their idea of reform is to take a step backwards.

TALK.START.PARA: —You'd take about 15.

—I cannot take 15 steps backwards because I would be acting contrary to standing orders because I would not be speaking from the right place. Senator Foreman has been in this chamber long enough to know that, and I do not think he ought to be advocating that. As an office-bearer of the Senate, he has some responsibility to ensure that good conduct is observed in this chamber. His estimable colleague Senator Jones recognises that and I think Senator Jones would prefer us to proceed in the manner in which we are going at the moment.

PARA.TAB: What we on this side of the chamber do not want is to proceed down the path that those on the other side have given us. They say, `Everything has to be controlled by the award. Unless it is controlled by the award—heavens!—we can't trust people because they might make a decision that's in their own interests and that we do not agree with'. This is what it is all about; it is about control. It is about control of workers—because unions do not trust workers.

As far as unions are concerned, the terrible thing about workers is that they do not always agree with the union. And then heaven help us. What is going to happen? If they do not all agree with the union, maybe you cannot pull them out, brothers. Maybe you cannot force them all to come out on strike. We are advocating a pluralistic system, a system that has a little bit of flexibility.

I know a little bit of flexibility is too much flexibility for some of the people on the other side of the chamber. I will give those opposite a compliment: they have all got backbone. The only problem is that they do not have those little bits that go in between the vertebrae. So they are thoroughly rigid from top to bottom—lots of backbone, but no flexibility. That is the problem of those on the other side of the chamber.

We are advocating a more flexible system of employees and employers working together. More importantly, we are advocating a system under which we do not have to have each and every member of the business covered by an award. Provided there is a majority, we believe that there are sufficient grounds for the commission to be able to ratify an agreement.

We do not support a system whereby the commission has to satisfy itself that everybody is covered by an award. That is absolute nonsense. If the people on the other side, with their entrenched views, took the opportunity to look at it for just a couple of seconds, they would recognise that there is merit in the proposal that we are putting forward.

Maybe we might even increase union membership. The funny thing about unions is that when people are compelled to join them, they do not want to join. But, when people are given freedom of choice, they can start to make a decision based on the merits. I believe that unions may have something to offer in the future, but only if they reform themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't offer much now.

—They do not offer much now. It is only if the unions reform themselves and start to offer people some real incentives, unlike the incentives that are usually offered, that people will join. I have told the chamber before, but I think it is apposite to mention it again—
—Imagine you as a recruitment officer.

—If I were a recruitment officer, the unions would have a hell of lot more members than they have now. I would not stand over people with a big baseball bat and say, `Brother, you're going to join the union'. I would not do what they did to my brother when he was a 16-year-old putting the colour inserts in the Sunday Sun, a paper which went defunct two months after the government's union brothers went and visited the establishment. He was a 16-year-old, earning 70 to 80 bucks a week for three or four hours work, and he was quite happy. They said to him, `Brother, you're not a member of the union'. He said, `I don't want to be a member of the union'. They said, `You don't understand; you have to join or you lose your job'. He said, `You can't sack me'. They said, `No, but we'll fix it so that you do get sacked'. That is the recruitment policy that Senator Murphy's friends use. Maybe—
—That is what the taxpayers are going to be funding—the training in that in the next little while.

—Of course. We will be funding the training so that these fellows can get to use a baseball bat a little better. What Senator Murphy and his friends should understand is that backbone is good, but flexibility is a little better. If the government offered people an incentive to join a union, instead of a disincentive if they do not, maybe union membership would go up.
—A bit of carrot instead of so much stick.

—Yes, a bit of carrot instead of so much stick. The amazing thing is that if we got more people genuinely interested in unions, we might even get a better standard of union official. Heaven help us! It cannot be that difficult. Look at the standard we get on the other side of the chamber.
—We could have a better standard of Labor politician.

—We might even get a better standard of Labor politician. There are a couple of good politicians on the other side, but the government brought the three stooges in recently and, frankly, I think the standard is dropping pretty rapidly. I advocate that those opposite should go away, look at this and say, `There is real genius in what the coalition is advocating; there is some basis for supporting this'. For the first time they might start to revitalise that morally and legally. I cannot work out what Senator Murphy, who is trying to interject, wants to rub apart from his own back. Maybe if he rubbed his head and stimulated his brain, he might recognise that there are benefits in what we are offering and that is why this amendment should be supported.

—The minister, in his response to me, said that the government was opposed to this amendment because it would have allowed non-award people to have a certified agreement. My understanding of enterprise based agreements is that they are to offer flexibility. The government itself has non-award agreements with its own senior executive service for these contracts that it is now introducing. That occurs within the states as well.

PARA.TAB: There is little difference between a contract, which is becoming popular these days among senior members of the Public Service, and the non-award managerial employees with a certified agreement, which is in the interests of the employees and, naturally, in the interests of the companies. But it is something that they willingly want to involve themselves in without the involvement of the third party.

I just make that point because I think that is something that Senator Bell should take on board. There is nothing wrong with the sort of flexibility that this amendment would introduce. The net result of it all, I suppose, will be that those people who want to go that route will do it, but they will do it at great expense, having gone through the interim award first and then going to the certified agreement. I would have thought that one important aspect of any piece of legislation that comes into this place is that it introduce an element of efficiency which represents cost savings, which makes our businesses more competitive and which, in the long run, is in the interests of the employees, the company and, ultimately, the nation.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Crane's) be agreed to:
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

PARA.TAB: That progress be reported.
