TALK.START.PARA: —Now we really are getting into what one might term the guts of this bill and what it really should be called—the union enhancement bill. The government, the Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine had an opportunity, which they have let pass, to have a little bit of democracy in this place tonight. The rights of the individual could have been protected in a situation where there was a majority. That came through and was expressed, but of course this government is not interested in that. It is interested in enshrining more power in the ACTU. It is interested in centralising the whole of industrial relations back into Canberra under its control, its mates and its masters. That is what is contained in this part of the bill that we are dealing with now. It amazes me that the Democrats in particular—in view of what they supposedly stood for—can be part of that process and can be bought so easily to go down this road. They are totally infringing the rights of the individual.
—I raise a point of order. I call upon your guidance with reference to previous rulings on the use of words such as `bought' in the way Senator Crane used it.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—Senator Crane, it would be better if you did not use expressions like that. I do not uphold the point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I am absolutely amazed that they are so easily offended. There is no doubt that former Senator Button was right when he said they were the fairies down at the bottom of the garden. Look at them down there—they are not even blossoming tonight. And they take offence at such a thing! Well, they were rented.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. The opposition knows very well the meaning of corruption. To suggest that we could be bought is to suggest that we are corrupt, and it is totally unparliamentary to make that suggestion. I ask you to ask him to withdraw that remark.
—Senator Crane, I have already asked you to refrain from—
—I thought I had. If I did not make it clear already—

—Order! Senator Crane, I have asked you to refrain from that kind of remark. I am not upholding the point of order at this time, but I will not ask you a third time. I would ask you now to direct your attention to the clause in the bill which you are speaking to.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. Could I just ask you a question? Would the word—
—No, Senator Brownhill. Do you have a point of order?
—Would the word `purchase' have been applicable rather than `bought'?
—Order! I call Senator Crane. I will not rule on hypotheticals.
—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. I thought I had withdrawn the word. I did not believe I used it again. If I did, I apologise to you because it was not intentional to do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Gough Whitlam said in December 1972, `It's time'. In a moment I propose to move that the committee report progress. First, I wish to outline to honourable senators the framework of our routine of business and business program for the next sitting week, as a result of discussions with parties in this chamber. The proposal is that the Senate deal with what remains of the committee stage of the industrial relations bill and all remaining packages before it—with the exception of the social security bills and those bills that can be dealt with as non-controversial legislation on Thursday morning—by the close of play on Monday so that they will be completed on Monday. For the remainder of our sitting

SPEECH.PARA: week we will deal with the Native Title Bill and the social security bills.

PARA.TAB: I think this will entail, as I have discussed with the opposition whip and some others, a need for us to commence earlier on Wednesday and Thursday of next week. I think we will probably have to kick off at 9 a.m. on both those days. Also, I think honourable senators ought be warned that, with the exception of Wednesday night, there obviously may be a need for us to negate the adjournment during the last sitting week in order for us to ensure that the whole of the program is achieved within the four sitting days that are available to us.
Progress reported.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Taxation Office: Video and Audio Cassettes

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What type of video and audio cassettes were produced by Radiowise Media Networks, North Sydney for the Australian Taxation Office (ATO).
(2) What was the total cost of these video and audio cassettes.
(3) How many were produced.
(4) To what purpose were they put.
(5) Have video and audio cassettes of this nature been produced previously for the ATO; if so when and what was the cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Radiowise Media Networks provided the video and audio components of the Child Support Agency's educational kit for high schools. They were awarded the project following a selection carried out by the ATO and the Office of Government Information and Advertising of the Department of Arts and Administrative Services.
(2) The total cost, which includes writing the script, filming, hiring actors, providing locations and other production costs, post production, supplying and copying the tapes, was $109,770.55.
(3) Three thousand audio and three thousand video cassettes were produced.

(4) The audio and video cassettes are a key component of educational kits designed to inform high school students of their rights and responsibilities as parents in the future. 2,700 of these kits have already been ordered by educational institutions and they have been distributed free of charge.

(5) The ATO has produced two earlier education kits for use in schools, although not on Child Support matters. The Insiders was produced in 1988 to inform young people of their rights and obligations as taxpayers. The cost was $120,000. HECS—the video, about the Higher Education Contribution Scheme, was produced in 1991 for the cost of $80,000.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 18 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the average `performance bonus' for a `superior' public servant and how many payments have been made in this category to date.
(2) What is the average `performance bonus' for an `outstanding' public servant and how many payments have been made in this category to date.
(3) What is the average `performance bonus' for a `fully effective' public servant and how many payments have been made in this category to date.

(4) What are the details of payments, by classification for: (a) each department; (b) defence forces—Royal Australian Air Force, Army, Navy; and (c) statutory bodies, Government agencies subsidiaries and corporations, for example, Qantas.
(5) What is the estimated outlay for `performance bonuses' in the 1993-94 financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)(2)(3) A report prepared by the Department of Finance, titled "Report on Performance Pay in the Australian Public Service", which I tabled in the House on 28 October 1993 contains aggregate service wide data on the payment of performance pay. From the information contained in this report I can inform you that in the 1992/93 assessment year, in agencies which made performance pay payments, an estimated 18,005 senior officers and all equivalent classifications were eligible for a performance payment. Of these, 16,476 senior officers and equivalent classifications received payments which varied depending on the available maxima for each classification. The overall average payment was $2,435 and the total paid was $43,835,727 which is the only aggregate information available to me. This information was obtained from the Finance Pay System. As this system does not contain information about ratings given to individuals I am unable to provide answers to questions (1), (2) and (3) on the bonuses awarded for ratings.

For further information on `performance bonuses' and the ratings attached to these bonuses, I refer the honourable member to the Report by the Australian National Audit Office and the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration titled, "Performance-Based Pay"—A Report on a Survey of the Implementation of Performance-Based Pay in the Australian Public Service published by the Committee at its hearing on 20 August 1993.

(4)(a) Information on the bonuses paid for ratings for each agency is not collected centrally. However, individual agencies' Annual Reports will contain information on bonus payments. Under the Government's reporting guidelines for the introduction of performance pay in the Australian Public Service, Annual Reports are required to provide information on the bonuses paid to all the classifications in the senior officer and senior executive service groups where there are three or more staff eligible to receive performance pay. This information is to show the aggregate amount paid to each group and the total number of eligible individuals in each group. Where the number of officers in a group is six or more the distribution of recipients in the group is to be shown according to the percentage of maximum permissible performance pay received by individuals. There is no requirement to report ratings.
(b) Performance based pay has not been implemented in the Australian Defence Force.

(c) For statutory bodies and Government agencies covered by the APS Agreement (Improving Productivity, Jobs and Pay in the Australian Public Service) information on performance-based pay will be available in the Annual Reports as described in (a) above. For other statutory authorities, Government agencies, subsidiaries and corporations which have independent staffing powers, the introduction of performance pay, if it has occurred, has not carried with it any new or separate reporting requirements.

(5) Under the APS Agreement the estimated outlay in budget funded agencies for `performance bonuses' for senior officers and equivalents in the 1993-94 financial year is $43.8 million and for the Senior Executive Service is $9.5 million.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to fringe benefits tax and car parking, is there a minimum acceptable fee, for instance, an overnight parking fee, that is acceptable to the Australian Taxation Office for the purpose of discharging an employer's responsibility under the fringe benefits car parking legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: There is no minimum acceptable fee in determining the taxable value of a car parking benefit. A car parking fringe benefit may be valued using either the "commercial parking station" method or the "market value" method. When using the "commercial parking station" method any fee charged for a continuous period of 6 hours or more on a day, including night parking fees, will be acceptable.

However, on 28 October 1993 the Assistant Treasurer announced that the fringe benefits tax law will be amended, from 1 April 1994, so that the value of a car parking fringe benefit under the "commercial parking station" method will be calculated only by reference to an amount charged for a continuous period of 6 hours or more between the hours of 7.00 am and 7.00 pm.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 2 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Were approximately 550,000 new bicycles sold during the 1991-92 financial year.
(2) How many new cars were sold during the 1991-92 financial year.
(3) How much federal funding was allocated to the construction and maintenance of roads during the 1991-92 financial year.
(4) How much funding was allocated to the survey, construction and maintenance of bicycle tracks during the 1991-92 financial year.
(5) Was any funding allocated from the Better Cities Program; if so, how much.

(6) Have any feasibility studies been conducted into the possibility of excising 3 metres or so of land running alongside the safety fences of railway lines specifically for the construction of bicycle tracks.
(7) Will the Government consider jointly funding a national co-operative bicycle path construction team involving Local, State and Federal Government.
(8) Could hundreds of socially, medically and environmentally useful jobs be created if such a co-operative tri-partisan venture was undertaken.

(9) Would it be possible to employ older under-employed architects, planners and engineers and have them supervise younger unemployed labourers and landscape workers in the construction of such bicycle tracks.

(10) Is the Minister aware of the publication entitled `Cycling Towards Health and Safety' by the British Medical Association highlighting the significant contribution to the health of a nation possible through cycling.
(11) Will steps be taken to ensure that the needs of cyclists, together with the benefits to the nation, are represented in the next Federal Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) According to the Bicycle Industry and Traders Association (BITA), approximately 670,000 bicycles were sold during the 1991-92 financial year.
(2) According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS), 437,075 new passenger cars were registered during the 1991-92 financial year.
(3) A total of $1,246.8m was expended under the Australian Land Transport Development (ALTD) Fund for the construction and maintenance of roads during the 1991-92 financial year.
This includes funding under the Black Spot program. It does not include local roads funding which was untied from 1 July 1991.

(4) The survey, construction and maintenance of bicycle tracks is, in the main, the responsibility of State, Territory and Local Governments and the Commonwealth holds no information on expenditures of such a kind by these Governments.

The National Bicycle Strategy, endorsed by the Federal, State and Territory Governments in 1992, requires Governments to consider cyclists when decisions involving the whole transport system are being made. It does not specify separate funding for bicycle facilities.

In endorsing the National Bicycle Strategy, the Federal Government allocated $3.9m in 1992/93 to the construction of bicycle facilities under the Australian Land Transport Development Program (ALTD), and $29.2m in 1992/93 under the Local Capital Works Program (LCW). The ALTD and LCW Programs do not provide funds for the ongoing maintenance of bicycle facilities.

(5) Under the Better Cities Program, the Commonwealth Government provides funds for Area Strategies to encourage a strategic planning approach. As additions to General Purpose Capital Assistance these untied funds facilitate capital works projects but do not extend to the ongoing maintenance of infrastructure.

The distribution of funds between elements within each individual Area Strategy is a matter for the relevant State or Territory Government. Better Cities agreements with the following States/Territories indicate that there are bicycle track elements that will be funded under the Program:
the Ultimo/Pyrmont Area Strategy in New South Wales;
the Inner North East Area Strategy, and the South Townsville Area Strategy in Queensland;
the Southern Area Strategy in South Australia; and
the Hobart Area Strategy, and the Launceston Area Strategy in Tasmania.

Due to the untied nature of the Program, funding details for specific elements of Area Strategies are not available to the Commonwealth but can be obtained direct from the respective State Governments.
(6) The Department of Transport and Communications has not conducted such a study, and I am not aware of any such studies.

However, the Federal Government contributed $1.473m in 1992/93 under the Australian Land Transport Development (ALTD) program and the Local Capital Works (LCW) program for a bicycle path within the rail reserve between the Hobart CBD and Glenorchy. The Hobart to Glenorchy cycleway will be officially opened on 5 December 1993.

Utilisation of the railway reserve became possible when the Australian National Railways Commission (AN) granted both the Hobart City Council and the Glenorchy City Council permission to utilise the reserve for a bicycle path.
AN has also agreed to the construction of a bicycle path alongside the railway line between Tanunda and Nuriootpa in the Barossa Valley.

(7), (8) & (9) The National Bicycle Strategy, endorsed by the Federal, State and Territory Governments in 1992, requires Governments to consider cyclists when decisions involving the whole transport system are being made. It does not specify separate funding for bicycle facilities.
(10) Yes. This issue is picked up in the National Bicycle Strategy.

(11) The Federal Government is continuing in its objective of improving the efficiency of land transport infrastructure and services, which includes the implementation of the National Bicycle Strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 4 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) When was the drug Lorexane (1 per cent Lindane—Gamma Benzene Hexachloride) first listed for use in Australia as an S2 drug.
(2) What advice was provided when the drug was reviewed in 1986.
(3) Please provide the advice referred to in (2).
(4) Since the review of the drug in 1986, how many adverse drug reaction reports have been made to the Adverse Drug Reactions Advisory Committee or otherwise to the department.
(5) Please provide a listing of the adverse drug reaction reports referred to in (4).
(6) When was the drug withdrawn from use.
(7) Please provide the advice upon which it was decided to withdraw the drug from use.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Gamma Benzene Hexachloride (lindane) was first recommended for a Schedule 2 classification in Australia in preparations for external human therapeutic use in March 1981 by the Drugs and Poisons Schedule Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council, for adoption into States' and Territories' poisons legislation. The subsequent dates on which the various jurisdictions adopted this recommendation into their legislation and applied it to the product Lorexane are not known.

(2) The advice was contained in an updated toxicological profile of lindane prepared in 1986 in conjunction with a generalised review of the organochlorines used as insecticides. This review was considered by three NHMRC Committees—the Committee on Toxicity, the Pesticide and Agricultural Chemicals (Standing) Committee and the Drugs and Poisons Scheduling (Standing) Committee.
(3) The advice was that there was no apparent reason to alter the Poisons Scheduling of products containing lindane.
(4) & (5) There have been no reports of adverse reactions specifically associated with the Lorexane brand of lindane made to the Adverse Drug Reactions Advisory Committee (ADRAC) since 1986.
A printout of adverse reactions to another brand of lindane received by ADRAC since 1986 is attached.
Apart from the ADRAC reports, the department has received correspondence from the parents of one child who experienced convulsions in association with use of Lorexane.
(7) The manufacturer has advised the department that it withdrew Lorexane from the market for business reasons only relating to diminished demand for the product.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 19 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which sporting and other events have been granted exemptions under the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992.
(2) Which events have been refused exemptions.
(3) What are the terms and conditions applying to the exemptions which have been granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The following sporting events have been granted exemptions under Section 18(2) of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992:
Telecom Rally Australia, Western Australia;
Foster's Australian Formula One Grand Prix, South Australia;
Australian Ladies Masters, Queensland;
Whitbread Round the World Yacht Race, Western Australia;
Australian Motor Cycle Grand Prix, New South Wales;
Australian Challenge, One Australia—America's Cup Challenge, Queensland and possibly other States.
(2) None.
(3) Terms and Conditions for each of the exemptions have been published in the Commonwealth Gazette, copies of which have been supplied to Senator Lees.
